column16:
f.140v: Cum tibi verborum fructum quis colligis horum,
Hic ut aratoris vescens messorque satoris,
Ut sis scriptoris studii memor atque laboris,
Nomen et intendas te queso vicemque rependas,
Respondens horum quod origo versiculorum,
Ait fert querenti dubium dat scire volenti.
Dispicito quales sint litterule capitales
Unde cito nomen concurret tale per omen.
Sicut et a primo versu cernis in imo.
Gree d i •m iis hah s veu ras n” -0s rr es ad-vade rbua ss everas (= Chunradus)
column18:
f.140v: When you, who gather the fruit of these words,
Feed here like the reaper and sower of the ploughman,
So that you may remember the diligence and work of the scribe,
I ask you, consider his name and repay him in turn.
The origin of these little verses, answering to those who ask,
Declares it to the seeker and gives knowledge to the willing.
Consider what kind of letters are capital,
From which a name will quickly appear as a sign,
Just as you see at the bottom of the first verse.
Gree d i •m iis hah s veu ras n” -0s rr es ad-vade rbua ss everas (= Chunradus)

column16: f.Item dyt boech is geeyndet int iaer ons heren xv ind ix op den sondach nae sancte peter ind paulus dach der heiliger apostelen gode zo eeren ind synre liever moder ind der alre heilichster moder sancta Anna Ind alle die gene die dys boechs gebruchen sollen gedencken Der schyrverschen myt eynen pater noster ind ave maria der heiliger moder sancte Annen zo eeren dat sy ur wil erwerven gracie ind genade in dieser tzijt ind nae deser tzijt de ewige vroude AMEN. Ur naem is suster gretgen smytz.
column18: f.I: This book is finished in the year of our Lord 1519 on the Sunday after the day of Saint Peter and Paul, the holy apostles, to honor God and His beloved mother and the most holy mother, Saint Anne. And all those who shall use this book should remember the writer with a Our Father and Hail Mary to honor the holy mother Saint Anne so that they may obtain her grace and mercy in this time and after this time, eternal joy. Amen. Her name is Sister Gretgen Smytz.

column11:
(ff.1; 8-9; 198-199)
[Apparamment il faut comprendre que Sustef a préparé le livre pour Fye. Au f.9v°, elle donnait les obits de son père, d'un frère et d'une sœur (1467-1477); plus tard (?) elle (?) ajoutait ceux de l'oncle Ansse (1468; sans doute le père de Fye), de deux autres frères (1468, 1481) et les noms d'une sœur et de Suster elle-même (ces deux étant encore en vie). Une autre main (celle de Fye?) a noté le décès de ces deux dernières (1509, 1510) ainsi que d'une autre personne de la famille (1519).]
column16: F.lv°: cercles computistiques partant de 1400 mais avec l'indication Intjaer ons heren Mcccc ende Ixxxij (cf.Introduction p. 8). f.9: Item dit boec hoert toe Fye anssen dochter woenende tot amsterledam totten elf dus ent maechden Bidt Bidt voer di ghene die hier een arm bezorghester of gheweest heeft om gods willen Suster mouwers dochter woenende te naerden lot sancta marien int cloest
column18:
f.Iv°: Circular calculations starting from 1400 but with the indication "In the year of our Lord 1482"
f.9: This book belongs to Fye Anssen's daughter residing in Amsterdam at the Eleven Virgins. Pray for those who have been a poor caretaker or attendant here, for God's sake. Sister Mouwers' daughter residing near the lottery at St. Mary's in the convent.

column11: Dutch translation/adaptation by Geert Grote. Contains calendar for the diocese of Utrecht (feasts in red include August 25: St. Eusebius, patron saint of the Church of Arnhem) - Hours of the Virgin - Hours of the Eternal Wisdom - Hours ofthe Cross, long version - Hours of the Holy Spirit - Seven Penitential Psalms - Litany - Prayers - Vigils of the dead
column16: Localisation and date are based on a note on f.227r: "Inden Jaer ons heren dusent cccc ende lxix is dit boec gescreven. Ende geeyndet omtrint sunte laurens mitter hant Suster Margariet blocks. Nonne toe bethanien buten Arnhem"
column18: f.227r: "In the year of our Lord one thousand four hundred sixty-nine, this book was written. And finished around the feast of Saint Lawrence by the hand of Sister Margariet Blocks, nun at Bethany outside Arnhem."

column11: f.3ra-111ra: Kunigund Niklas
column16: f.237rb: Dicz puch ist auSSgeschriben worden do man czalt von unsers lieben herren Jhesu Cristi gepurd M. CCCC. und in dem XXXVII jor an dem heiligen krewcz abent als ez gefunden ward in dem herbst (= 13 Sept). Pyt got fu/e/r die schreyberin die dicz puch geshcriben hat daz ir got genedig sey hie in zeyt und dort in ewigkeyt amen.
column18: f.237rb: This book was copied in the year of our dear Lord Jesus Christ 1437, on the evening of the Feast of the Holy Cross, when it was found in the autumn (September 13). Pray to God for the scribe who wrote this book, that God may be merciful to her here in time and there in eternity, amen.”

column10: The Claricia Psalter takes its name from one of the initials, which depicts a young girl in secular dress swinging from the initial "Q," who has "Claricia" written around her head. It has been suggested that the image represents a novice artist who signed her work, but there are many other theories, and none are certain.

column16: (muz dir got geben daz du alle zeit seist mit ym Amen) unn ich auch M. Wisentaverinn (Margarethe von Wiesenthan, fut abbesse des clarisses de Nuremberg jusqu'en 1403). HKOL says: f.183 Schl.: 'vnn mvz dir got geben daz du alle zeit seist mit ym Amen.' Dann mit rother Tinte umrändert: 'vnn ich auch M. wisentaverinn.'
column18: “(May God grant you that you are always with Him, Amen) and I as well, M. Wisentaverinn (Margarethe von Wiesenthan, former abbess of the Poor Clares of Nuremberg until 1403).” HKOL states: f.183, Schl.: ‘and may God grant you that you are always with Him, Amen.’ Then outlined in red ink: ‘and I as well, M. Wisentaverinn.’”

column16: f.162v-163 Das puch ist aussgeschriben worden, do man czalt noch unsers lieben herren Iesu xpi gepurt 1451 iar, acht tag vor sant Maria Magdalenatag. Pit den almechtigen god und...s. Katherina fu"r die schreiberin, die dise legent geschriben hat in ir. HKOL says: f.163: 'Das puch ist au ssgeschriben worden . Do man czalt noch vnsers lieben herren iesu cristi gepurt Mo. CCCCo. Vnd in dem LI. jar acht tag. Vor sant Maria . Magdalenatag.' Darunter: 'Pit den almechtigen Got Vnd . . . . sant katherina für Die schreiberin die dise legent geschriben hat in irer lieb Das der almechtig got davon gelobt werd' u. s. w. . . . 'Das werd war . Amen.'
column18: f.162v-163: This book was copied in the year of our dear Lord Jesus Christ, 1451, eight days before the feast of St. Mary Magdalene. Pray to Almighty God and St. Catherine for the scribe who wrote this legend in her love, so that Almighty God may be praised for it, etc. HKOL says: f.163: ‘This book was copied. In the year of our dear Lord Jesus Christ 1451, eight days before the feast of St. Mary Magdalene.’ Below: ‘Pray to Almighty God and St. Catherine for the scribe who wrote this legend in her love, so that Almighty God may be praised for it, etc. Let this be true. Amen.’”

f.163r: Das puch ist au ssgeschriben worden . Do man czalt noch vnsers lieben herren iesu cristi gepurt Mo. CCCCo. Vnd in dem LI. jar acht tag. Vor sant Maria . Magdalenatag. 
Darunter: Pit den almechtigen Got Vnd … . sant katherina für Die schreiberin die dise legent geschriben hat in irer lieb Das der almechtig got davon gelobt werd u. s. w… . Das werd war . Amen.
column18:
f.163r (Colophon):
This book was written out in the year of the birth of our dear Lord Jesus Christ, 1451, eight days before the feast of Saint Mary Magdalene.

Below that:
Pray to Almighty God and to Saint Catherine for the scribe who wrote this reading out of love, that Almighty God may be praised through it, etc… This is true. Amen.

column16: f.171r: Ich swester Alheit von Streytperg han daz puch geschriben... unn ze eren den dreyn geswister ... Maria Mag. Martha. Lazarus. unn ich pit begirlich alle ... daz si mein ze gedanken. un meiner liben swester Petersn ... und swester Ma/ Rabenekerin.
column18: “I, Sister Alheit von Streytperg, have written this book… in honor of the three siblings… Mary Magdalene, Martha, and Lazarus. And I earnestly ask all… that they remember me, and my dear Sister Petersn… and Sister M[a] Rabenekerin.”

column11: Bamberg, fr. Franciscus presbiterorum, fr. (s) and Dorothea Marchionissa (proof) at time of Katharina Sensenschmidin)
column16: Presens opus cum alijs XII voluminibus incepit fr. Franciscus Mathie de observantia O.Min. sub vicario provinciali patre utique rev. Iohanne de Lindefelcz apud s. Claram in Bamberga in cenobio seu domuncula confessoris virginum atque sororum s. Clare sub abbatissa Katharina Sensenschmidin Iudoco Cutzenbach confessore bene digno cuius anima requiescat in pace. a. incarn. ... 1498 circa festum assumptionis Marie v. et feliciter determinavit manu propria prememoratus fr. Franciscus presbiterorum minimus in litera non (!) illuminatione reliigatione atque correctione sub rev. p. Iohanne Keller proviciali vicario generosa abbatissa Dorothea Marchionissa patre Frederico Gerberstorfer confessore pro tunc existente utique famoso a. salutis 1501 in vig. festi purificationis Marie immaculate virg. (etc.)
column18: “This present work, along with twelve other volumes, was begun by Brother Franciscus Mathie of the Observant branch of the Friars Minor, under the provincial vicar, the reverend Father Johannes of Lindefelcz, at St. Clare’s in Bamberg, in the small monastery or residence of the confessor of the virgins and sisters of St. Clare, under Abbess Katharina Sensenschmid, with the worthy confessor Jodocus Cutzenbach, whose soul may rest in peace. In the year of the Incarnation 1498, around the feast of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary, it was happily completed by the same Brother Franciscus, the least of priests, with his own hand. The work was not (!) illuminated, bound, or corrected under the reverend Father Johannes Keller, provincial vicar, the noble Abbess Dorothea Marchioness, and Father Frederico Gerberstorfer, the well-known confessor at that time, in the year of salvation 1501, on the eve of the feast of the Purification of the Immaculate Virgin Mary (etc.).”
column26: Bamberg, Poor Clares Monastery Germany Bamberg

column16: "Disz bůch gehört Ambrosio zu der tzyt schultheisz zů Covelentz. Anno domini xv(c) unnd dry uff den dag Gregorii [= 12.3.1503] hat disz bůch geschrieben und volbracht mit allenn bůchstaben uszgemacht von Basel Dorothea schryberyn. Gott bewar ir crafft unnd synn».
column18: "This book belongs to Ambrosio, at the time the sheriff of Covelentz. In the year of our Lord 1503 on the day of Gregory [= March 12, 1503] this book was written and completed with all letters carefully written by Dorothea, scribe of Basel. May God protect her strength and effort."

column11: *Comina is not specified as a nun. She is listed as 'domina Iacoma' in the colophon - but the contents of the work - especially the Trattato dell'ubbidienza - suggest that she may have been a lay sister.
column16: f.95r: “Deo gratias. Amen. XVIII marcii. Deo gratias. Qui scripsit scribat, semper cum Domino vivat. Vivat in celis semper cum Domino felix. Ego Comina (Comina is erased and substituted with ‘domina Iacoma’ in a different but contemporary hand) scripsi istum libellum cum sua (word erased and substituted with 'mea' in same hand as made the correction above) propria manu. MCCCCLII. E ve pregi per carità che voliati pregare Dio per mi. Finito libro referamus gratia Christo.”
column18: f.95r: "Thanks be to God. Amen. 18th of March. Thanks be to God. May the one who wrote it always write, and always live with the Lord. May they live happily in heaven forever with the Lord. I, Comina (Comina is erased and substituted with ‘Lady Iacoma’ in a different but contemporary hand), wrote this little book with my own (word erased and substituted with 'my' in the same hand as made the correction above) hand. 1452. And I ask you out of charity to please pray to God for me. Having finished the book, let us give thanks to Christ."

column16: f.230v: Ein Ave Maria om gots willen vor den schryuer want hets oer vake suer geworden. >D<it boeck is geeyndet in den jaer ons heren Doe men schref xv C ende xxvj op S. Ambrosyus dach in der vasten toe viij vren Ende got hebbe daer ewich lof af >D<it Boeck heuet geschreuen Suster gertken opten koeten vor oer aelderen der oer jair getyde is op S. kiliaens hynrick opten koete ende else syn huysvrouwe ende oer kynder Ende sie en begert daer vor niet by sonder toe lesen Dan dat got daer in gelaeuet werde ende den susteren in den ketwich ynt gemeyne reventer toe gebruken Ende nummer mer wtten Conuente toe geuen Want sye heuet dat gespaert ende alle dattet gecoestet heuet betaelt ...
column18: “One Ave Maria, for God’s sake, for the scribe, as it was often difficult for her. This book is completed in the year of our Lord, when one wrote 1526, on St. Ambrose’s Day in Lent at eight in the morning, and may God be eternally praised for it. This book was written by Sister Gertken Opten Koeten for her ancestors in their yearly remembrance, particularly for St. Kilian, Henrick Opten Koete, and Else his wife, and for their children. She does not seek anything special in return other than that God be praised through it, and that it be used in the convent for common worship in the ketwich (devotional hours) of the sisters, and never given out of the convent, for she kept and paid for all its costs.”

f.1r: "desen psalter hoert thoe int convent den susteren tot Sinte katarinen dael binnen hasselt gelaten van onser ierster onder moeder suster katarina vander molen zeliger ende heeften gescreven met haerre properre hant ende sal vortaen bliven geleent vander eenre onder moeder op dander nu ende vortdaen" 
f.250r: "desen souter es op sondage ghescreuen men en machs niet vercoepen mer hi sal der heileger ermer ghemeynten hoeren di niet en hebben ende dien werdelijc ende reynlijc verwaren"
column18:
f.1r: "This psalter belongs to the convent of the sisters of Saint Catherine's Valley in Hasselt, left by our first prioress Sister Catherine Vander Molen, may she rest in peace, and it was written with her own hand. It shall henceforth remain lent by one prioress to another, now and in the future."

f.250r: "This psalter was written on Sunday. It cannot be sold, but it shall belong to the holy poor community who do not have it, and it shall be kept worthy and pure."

column8: Ms. Ricketts 198, Unidentified nun-scribe A, Bloomington, Indiana University
column10: Katharienconvent the convent catalogue entry describes the volume as having been made by the sisters.
column11: The Katharinenconvent was notable for its number of active scribes who were members of the community itself.Upwards of two dozen manuscripts survive signed by the nuns, significant in the history of female literacy. The best documented artist at the Katharinenconvent was Barbara Gwichtmacherin, fl. c. 1450-70
column16: f.116r: Colophon dates the completion of the manuscript to the Friday within the octave of the Visitation in 1458 [i.e. 7 July], repeating again that the translation was done from a copy in Basel in 1454.

column11: Breviary (ff.10rA-190rA containing the Proper of Time and ff.282rA-469vB containing the Proper of the Saints); other hands present in the ms. – another scribe identified in ff.194rA-273vB and 470rA507vA.
column16:
f.23v: Christus, Iesus Christus, Iesus Christus, per lo cui amore io sore Catelina del corpo de Christo in Ferara ò scrito questo breviario, exceto lo salmista e lo commune di santi e lo calendario. Christus
f.469v: Christus meus, Christus meus, Christus, pro cuius amore ego soror Chaterina explevi librum istum in monasterio sacratissimi corporis Christi, sub regula virginis preclarissimae [the letter of the second ‘a’ is uncertain] Clarae, humilis ancillae [corrected from "ancilla"] Christi et verae [corrected from "vera"] discipulae [corrected from "discipula"] et filiae [corrected from "filia"] serafici Francisci patris nostri M°CCCC°LII°, XI° die mensis iunii, in die sancti Barnabe apostoli. Laus tibi, Domine Iesu Christe, pastor bone. Amen.
column18:
**f.23v**:
"Christ, Jesus Christ, Jesus Christ, for the love of whom I, Sister Catelina of the Body of Christ in Ferrara, have written this breviary, except for the psalter, the common of saints, and the calendar. Christ."

**f.469v**:
"My Christ, my Christ, Christ, for the love of whom I, Sister Chaterina, completed this book in the monastery of the Most Holy Body of Christ, under the rule of the most illustrious virgin Clare, humble servant of Christ and true disciple and daughter of our seraphic father Francis, in the year 1452, on the 11th day of the month of June, on the feast of Saint Barnabas the Apostle. Praise to you, Lord Jesus Christ, good shepherd. Amen."

column16:
f.107: Qui scripsit scribat, semper semper [sic] cum Domino vivat, vivat in celis semper cum Domino felix. Servorum Dei humilis soror Illuminata peccatrix; f.108: Ego soror Illuminata de Bembis de Venetia, serva Dei indigna, composui hunc librum pro veritate pura et pro veneranda beata Katerina matre nostra et pro contemplatione mea. Laus Deo
f.Iv ex libris of the Monastero del Corpus Domini, hand of Illuminata Bembo certified by the abbess Laura Beccadelli.
column18:
**f.107**:
"May whoever wrote this always live with the Lord, live happily with the Lord forever in heaven. The humble servant of God, Sister Illuminata, sinner."

**f.108**:
"I, Sister Illuminata de Bembis from Venice, unworthy servant of God, composed this book for pure truth and for the veneration of our blessed mother Catherine and for my contemplation. Praise be to God."

**f.Iv**:
"From the library of the Monastery of the Body of Christ, in the hand of Illuminata Bembo, certified by the abbess Laura Beccadelli."

According to the obituary of the Holy Cross Monastery in Regensburg, Katharina Mentelberger died in January 1532 (Kuhlmann[1987] pp. 35 and 263).
I: 1 r –112 v , 224 r –279 r ; II [ Katterina Menttellwergerin ]: 113 r –220 r , 279 rb –293 v

column18:
**f.135r - copyist**:
"In the year of our Lord 1446, on the Tuesday of Pentecost, I began this book on the Seven Articles, and it was completed on the eve of Saints Peter and Paul. Pray for her who has completed it, for she remained in great virtue by God's grace. AMEN. 17 quaternions."

column16: f.295r: DIt boeck was ghescreuen ende volyndt int Jaer ons Heeren. M d xcij den xvij nouvember. Bidt om godts wille eenen Aue Maria voer suster Catherine wouters. die dit wt liefden heeft ghedaen Op dat die suete jesus tot alder vren. in synder goedertierende gratien haer wil ontfaen. Amen.
column18: f.295r: This book was written and completed in the year of our Lord 1592, on the 17th of November. Pray, for the love of God, an Ave Maria for Sister Catherine Wouters, who did this out of love, so that the sweet Jesus, in his merciful graces, may receive her into all bliss. Amen.

column16: f.407v: DIt boeck h[oert+eeft] [-toe] Suster Johanna Koenen ende ic hebt gescreuen en voleynt int iaer ons heren m Vc ende lxxxvi den xvi dach der maent Aprilis Ende het is gescreuen op donsagen ende heilich dagen daer om en willes toch niet vercopen Ende bidt toch om gods wil voer myn ziel getrouwelicken ende sonderlinge dier nae myn doot sal hebben want ic seer aerm van doechden ben Niet sonder godt.
column18: f.407v: This book belongs to Sister Johanna Koenen, and I have written and completed it in the year of our Lord 1586, on the 16th day of the month of April. It is written on Thursdays and holy days; therefore, it should not be sold. I earnestly request, for the sake of my soul, that those who possess it after my death pray faithfully for me, as I am very poor in virtues. Not without God.

column11: [8e priorin]
column16: f.385r: Desen boeck heeft ghescreuen suster ianne colijns in tijden die haer te goede hadde moeghen werden ende sij bidt eenen yegheliken dier sijn profijt wt doen sal om haers voer gode te ghedinckenne op dat haer ziele in rusten metten zalighen verblijden moeghe. Sij begonsten int Jaer ons heeren xvc ende vij op den xviii dach van Januario Ende hij was wt opt selue iaer inden mey op den iv dach al soe wert hij ghescreuen binnen drie maent ende xxiik daghen Deo gratias.
column18: f.385r: This book was written by Sister Janne Colijns during times that might have been favorable to her, and she prays that everyone who benefits from it will remember her before God so that her soul may rest in peace with the blessed. She began writing it in the year of our Lord 1507, on the 18th day of January, and it was completed in the same year in May, on the 4th day, within three months and 22 days. Thanks be to God.

column18: "f.77v: "This book belongs to the Regular Canonesses' monastery of Saint Elizabeth on the Mount of Zion in Brussels, kept by me, Sister Jane van Ophem. An Ave Maria to God for me and all souls."

column4: Brussels, Bibliothèque royale Albert Ier, II 651
column16: f.4v: Suster lijsken tack. Anno domini M vc ende vj den yersten dach in december is dit boeck vol eynt ter eeren gods Ende tot orbaer den ghemeynen zusteren vander derden regel van Sint Franciscj binnen Antwerpen diet orbaert die gedenct om gods wil der gheender ziele diet screef wt minnen Een Aue maria.
column18: f.4v: Sister Lijsken Tack. In the year of our Lord 1506, on the first day of December, this book was completed in honor of God and for the benefit of the common sisters of the Third Order of Saint Francis within Antwerp. Whoever benefits from it, remember for God's sake the soul of the one who wrote it out of love. Amen.

f.145v: Desen boeck heeft gheschreue(n) Suster Johanna Matthijs Anno mv°lxv die jare(n) haerdt(er) outheit by den lxxix tot ghu(n)st sust(e)r paulijnke(n) van vossel voer dancbaerheit haers mi(n)lijcke(n) dienst. Ad laudem dei 
Origin established from the mention of obit : Obiit in bethania iuxta merchliniam praedilecta soror nostra soror paula de vossel monialis professa (f.62v)
column18:
"f.145v: This book was written by Sister Johanna Matthijs in the year 1565, at the age of 79, as a gesture of gratitude to Sister Paulijnken van Vossel for her kind service. To the praise of God.
Origin established from the mention of obit: Died in Bethania near Mechelen, our beloved sister Sister Paula de Vossel, professed nun."

column4: Brussels, Bibliothèque royale Albert Ier, IV 133
column8: Ms. Brussels IV 133 Unidentified nun-scribe A, Bruges
column16: f.188v: Int iaer ons heeren M CCCC end xxxvj. Vp den helighen Assencioens auent so was desen bouc vanden helighen leuene ons heeren vul screuen Ter heeren van gode ende van sijnder saligher moeder ende magher Maria. Ende ic bidde alle die ghone die in desen bouc sulle lesen dat si willen bidden voer die ghone die desen bouc heeft ghescreuen dat haer god gheue dat eewighe leuen in sijn soete rike AMEN.
column18: f.188v: In the year of our Lord 1436, on the eve of the Holy Ascension, this book of the Holy Life of our Lord was fully written for the honor of God and his blessed mother, Virgin Mary. And I pray to all those who shall read in this book to pray for those who have written this book, that God may grant them eternal life in his sweet kingdom. Amen.
column19: Bruges, Sainte Anne (Sint Anna ter Woestijne)
column26: Bruges, Sainte Anne (Sint Anna ter Woestijne) Belgium Bruges

column4: Brussels, Bibliothèque royale Albert Ier, IV 242
column16: f.109v: Dit boexken hoort tee den clooster van sunte Gheertruden in tzhertoghen bosch. Ende suster berber hoernken heuet des sondaechs ende des heilighen daeehs gheschreuen doen si oudt was seuen en dertich iair. ende si begheert datmens niet en vercoope Ende oeck begheert si leuende ende doodt deelachtich te syn alle des goedts datter aff comt. Gheeyndt indt iair ons heren dusent .iiijC. ende lxxix
column18: "f.109 verso: This booklet belongs to the cloister of Saint Gertrude in 's-Hertogenbosch. And Sister Berber Hoernken has written it on Sundays and holy days when she was thirty-seven years old. And she desires that it not be sold. Also, she desires, both living and dead, to share in all the good that comes from it. Finished in the year of our Lord one thousand four hundred seventy-nine."
column26: s-Hertogenbosch, Sainte-Gertrude Netherlands s-Hertogenbosch

column8: Ms. Brussels IV 402 Unidentified nun-scribes, Brussels
column16: f.319v: "Hier ynden die sermoenen ons Eerweerdeghen paters welke ic van velen een weynich vergadert hebbe tot mijns selfs orbore ende der gheendere dier in believen sal te studeren. Ende sij waren volscreven int jaer ons heren m. cccc. ende. lxxxvi: op den xxiiii. dach in mey dat doen was des heilichs sacrament avent."
column18: "f.319v: "Here end the sermons of our Venerable Fathers, which I have gathered a little from many for my own use and for anyone else who wishes to study them. And they were completed in the year of our Lord 1486, on the twenty-fourth day of May, which was the eve of the Holy Sacrament."

column4: Brussels, Bibliothèque royale Albert Ier, IV 474
column16: f.287v: dit boeck is geschreuen Ter eeren gods ende sijnder gebenedider moeder ende tot lof van alle gods heilighe Ende is voleijnt bijder gracien gods Bij mij suster mariken pompen Int. iaer ons heeren doemens schref.M D XXX Vi den XIX october Bidt om gods wil voer mi Dat mij godt alle mijn sonden wil vergeuen Ende dat hij door sijn. lijden Mijn siele inder ewicheit wilt verblijden Amen Deo gracias. Deo gracias. Deo gracias.
column18: f.287v: This book is written in honor of God and His blessed mother, and for the praise of all God's saints. It was completed by the grace of God by me, Sister Mariken Pompen, in the year of our Lord 1536, on the 19th of October. Pray for me, that God may forgive all my sins, and through His suffering, may He bring joy to my soul for eternity. Amen. Thanks be to God. Thanks be to God. Thanks be to God.

column8: Martine van Woelputte, Bergen op Zoom
column16: f.235v - gekopieerd uit legger: "Ghescreven gheset ende volbracht metter gracien gods van enen armen sondigen mensche welcs name ic wilde dat bekent ware ende onvutdoenliken gescreven in dat boec des ewighe levens ende op dat dat gescien mach soe biddic alle den ghenen die dit of sijn uutscrift sullen sien oft horen lesen voir hem willen bidden Int Jair ons heren dusent vierhondert ende eenen vijftich als die gracie vanden gulden jare te mechelen was"
column18: "f.235v - copied from ledger: "Written, set, and completed with the grace of God by a poor sinful person whose name I would like to be known, and indelibly written in the book of eternal life, and so that this may happen, I ask all those who will see or hear or read this or its copy to pray for them. In the year of our Lord one thousand four hundred and fifty-one, when the grace of the golden year was at Mechelen.""

column4: Brussels, Bibliothèque royale Albert Ier, Ms.15069
column11:
This ms could have been written by more women (5 or 6?) sometimes changing in the middle of a page
Ce manuscrit a été commencé en 1471 par des conseurs (jusqu'au feuillet 174v) puis continué 18 ans plus tard par Catherine van Molenbeek.
column16:
f.192v: Aen dit beck heeft ghescreuen suster lijsbeth witjens. Ende suster magriet raes. Ende na dat ouer xviii. iaer was begonnen te scriuen Soe heuet suster kathlinen van molenbeke volscreuen ende gheint op onser lieuer vrouqen dach xv teappen. op Sinte cecielien auent. int iaer ons heeren. m cccc ende lxxxix. doen was sij out ontrint. 1. iaer. Wilt om gode eenen aue marie. hertelijc lesen voer hen drien. op dat hen god voer haren arbeyt. wil gheuen glorie inder ewicheit. 
f.1r (other hand): dit boec hoert toe den cloester der roosen gheplant in jherico binnen bruesel bij sinte kathlinen.
column18:
"f.192 verso: Sister Lijsbeth Witjens and Sister Magriet Raes have written in this book. After over eighteen years of writing, Sister Kathlinen van Molenbeke completed and ended it on the eve of Our Lady's Day of the 15th taps, on the eve of Saint Cecilia, in the year of our Lord 1489. At that time, she was approximately 51 years old. Please, from your heart, recite an Ave Maria for the three of them, so that God may grant them glory for their labor in eternity.

f.1 recto (other hand): This book belongs to the cloister of the Roses Planted in Jericho within Brussels, near Saint Kathlinen."
column19: Brussels, Cloister Notre-Dame of the Rose of Jericho
column26: Brussels, Cloister Notre-Dame of the Rose of Jericho Belgium Brussels

column16: f.249r: "Desen boeck wert gheschreven Int Jaer ons heren .xvc .x. van Suster Johannen Colijns doen sij out was .lvi. jaer. Ende sij schincten den convente In goeder minnen van Jericho opden viijsten dach In Julio alst viel haers incomst Jubileo Int Jaer .xv.c xi. Biddende haerer armer zielen ghetrouw te sine Op dat sij mach met christo leven ten fine. Amen. Desen boeck hout inne. xxxi. quarternen. ende daer es toe ghegaen .v. boecken panpiers ende .v. blaren"
column18: "f.249r: "This book was written in the year of our Lord 1510 by Sister Johanna Colijns when she was fifty-six years old. And she donated it to the convent out of goodwill from Jericho on the eighth day of July, when her income fell on the Jubilee Year of the year 1511. Praying for her poor soul to be faithful so that she may live with Christ in the end. Amen. This book contains thirty-one quaternions and it took five reams of paper and five leaves.""

f.166r: Wilt om gods wille bidden voer die arme scriuersse suster marie deghens.
f.166v: Dit boec heeft doen scriuen bruder wollem. [ y / (2nd hand) van sundert van] berghen opten zoem ten loue ende ter eeren gods ende allen heylighen voer den donaten ende familiaren brueders reefter des godshuys van gruenendale in zonyen gheleghen. inden welcken die selue brueder willem was. int iaer ons heeren M cccc ende lxi wilt daer omme voer hem bidden om gods willen. 
f.166v (2nd hand): Dit boec behoert toe den cloester van gruenendale in zonijen gheleghen ij mijlen van bruysel.
column18:
f.166r: "Please pray for the poor scribe Sister Marie Deghens for the sake of God.

f.166v: Brother Wollem had this book written [by / (2nd hand) from] Sundert van Berghen on the behalf and to the glory of God and all the saints, for the benefactors and lay brothers of the refectory of the Grünendale monastery located in Zonien. In which the same Brother Wollem was involved in the year of our Lord 1461. Please pray for him for the sake of God.

f.166v (2nd hand): This book belongs to the Grünendale monastery located in Zonien, two miles from Brussels."

column4: Brussels, Bibliothèque royale Albert Ier, Ms.15136
column16: f.266v: INt Jaer ons heren M cccc lxxii tich. Op sinte peeters ende pauwels dach in junio. Begonste suster katherina van ghiseghem profes nonne in onsen cloester te iericho aen dit boec vanden tabernakel te scriuen. Ende sij volyndet int selue iaer iiii dage in april op sinte ambrosius dach. die viel opten sondach. Dit heeftse ter eren gods ende om gemeyn stichtinge met groeter nersticheit bearbeit in allen wtgesochten tijden als sij int gemeyn werck niet sijn en moeste. doense was out xxvi tich iaer. Bidt om die minne gods voer haer ewige salicheit. Dit boec behoert toe. den cloestere van onser lieuer vrouwen rose geplant in iericho. bynnen bruesele bi sinte katherinen. der ordenen sinte augustijns. soe wie dat vint geeft den relygiosen ioffrouwen weder om gods wille.
column18: "f.266 verso: In the year of our Lord one thousand four hundred seventy-two. On the feast day of Saints Peter and Paul in June, Sister Katherina van Ghiseghem, professed nun in our cloister at Jericho, began to write this book on the tabernacle. And she completed it in the same year, on the fourth day of April, on the feast day of Saint Ambrose, which fell on a Sunday. She did this in honor of God and for the common edification with great diligence, working on it diligently at all chosen times when she was not engaged in communal work. She was twenty-six years old at the time. Pray for her eternal salvation out of love for God. This book belongs to the cloister of Our Lady Rose-planted in Jericho, within Brussels, near Saint Catherine's, of the Augustinian order. Whoever finds it, return it to the religious ladies for the love of God."

column16:
f.74v: Dit boec es volscreuen op sinte symon ende yuden auont Int iaer ons heren m cccc en lxxiiii van suster lijsbetk vliechs. doen si out was li iear bidt voer haer om gode. Dit boec hoert toe int bloester tot onser lieuer vrouwen te yericho dat men heet te sinte katerinen. 
f.164v (2nd hand): Dit boeck hoert toe te onser lieuer vrouwen der Roosen gheplant in iherico dat men heet te sinte katherinen binnen bruesele. Inden iaer ons heren. m cccc ende lxxiiii soe heeft suster lijsbeth vlieghe desen boeck volscreuen ende met groeten arbeyde op sinte symon ende iuden auont volyndet ter eeren gods ende tot stichtinghen ende salicheit alre deuoter menschen doen sij out was. li. iaer. Bidt ghetrouwelijc om die minne gods voer haer. want sij seer neerstelijc ende vlietelijc vele iaren ghearbeit heeft in vele goeder boeken te scruene.
column18:
"f.74v: This book was fully written on the eve of Saint Simon and Jude in the year of our Lord 1474 by Sister Lijsbetk Vliechs when she was fifty-one years old. Pray for her to God. This book belongs to the monastery of Our Lady of the Roses planted in Jericho, known as Saint Catherine's.

f.164v (2nd hand): This book belongs to Our Lady of the Roses planted in Jericho, known as Saint Catherine's within Brussels. In the year of our Lord 1474, Sister Lijsbeth Vlieghe completed this book with great effort on the eve of Saint Simon and Jude, for the glory of God and for the edification and salvation of all devout people, when she was fifty-one years old. Pray faithfully for her out of love for God, as she diligently and diligently worked for many years in writing many good books."

f.284v: Hier ynt dat yerste boeck. gheheeten malogranatum. dat volscreuen wert op sinte nychasius dach. Int iaer ons heeren m cccc ende lxxxv van suster katherinen van molenbeke. als si out was xliiii iaer. dit heeft sij om die minne gods ghedaen ende tot ghemeynder stichtinghen. waer af ons heere haer loen wil sijn inder ewicheit Amen.
(2nd hand): Dit boeck hoert toe den cloester der rosen gheplant in jherico binnen bruesel bij Sinte katherinen
column18:
f.284v: Here ends the first book called "Malogranatum", completed on the day of Saint Nichasius, in the year of our Lord 1485, by Sister Katherinen van Molenbeke, when she was forty-three years old. She did this out of love for God and for the common good. May the Lord reward her for it in eternity. Amen.

(Second hand): This book belongs to the convent of the Rosary planted in Jericho within Brussels, near Saint Katherine.

column16: f.141v: Dit boeck heeft doen scriven Gheerdrwt Ghijsbert Staden weduwe, en ghaeftet tot een ewich testament na hare doot suster Haes van Heeswijck ende suster Kathrijn van Werconden. hoer twe susteren ende ghemenen convent susteren thans woenende onder die swede binnen Utrecht. Int jaer ons heren 1442 opten paesdach den yrsten dach van april. Bidt voer Gheertrwt Staden om Gods willen Pater nr. ave Maria, voer Heinrich van Werconden, voer Ian van Heeswije, voer Ghijsbert Stade, voer Jan de Vroede.
column18: “This book has been written by Gheerdrwt Ghijsbert Staden, widow, and is dedicated as an eternal testament after her death to Sister Haes van Heeswijck and Sister Kathrijn van Werconden, her two sisters and the common convent sisters, currently living under the Swedes in Utrecht. In the year of our Lord 1442, on Easter Sunday, the first day of April. Pray for Gheerdrwt Staden, for God’s sake: Our Father, Hail Mary, for Heinrich van Werconden, for Jan van Heeswijck, for Ghijsbert Staden, for Jan de Vroede.”

2nd hand: Sister Bona de Houer was appointed Head Prioress. In the year 1564 until the year 1593 she held this position. Praise be to God for eternity.

column4: Brussels, Bibliothèque royale Albert Ier, Ms.4367-68
column16:
f.3r: "Hier beghint die prologe op die navolghende sermoenen die welke onse eerwerdige pater her jan storm hevet ghepredict in onsen cloestere te jhericho: doen hi ons commissarijs ende rector tsamen was. welke sermoenen onse werdige mater. doen sij noch inden staet der prelaturen niet en was. aensiende den swaren last ende arbeit des selven Eerbaren vaders crech minne ende devocie dese sermoenen te bescriven: op dat den arbeit des predicaers inder ewiger glorien met nyewen loene vergouden worde soe dicke als yemens devocie beweeght wert. uut aenhoerne oft selve te studeerne dese sermoene. Laet ons ghetrouwelijc bidden voer onsen eerwerdigen pater die den arbeit heeft ghedaen inder predicatien. ende voer onser ghemijnder mater: suster marie van pee god wil haer geven sinen ewegen vree die den arbeit heeft ghedaen om dit te bescriven ... soe hebic dit navolgende boec ghepijnt te vergaderen uut veel collacien die in onsen godshuyse gepredict sijn binnen vijf jaren ..." 
f.299r: "Hier ynden die sermoenen ons Eerweerdeghen paters welke ic van velen een weynich vergadert hebbe tot mijns selfs orbore ende der gheendere dier in believen sal te studeren Ende sij waren volscreven int jaer ons heren. M. iii[c]. ende lxvi. op sinte laureis des gloriosen maerteleers dach voer vesperen" 
f.330v: "Dit boeck was volscreven Int jaer ons heren doemen screef.Dusent. vierhondert. seven ende tsestich. des sesten daeghs in septembri. op enen sondach"
column18:
"f.3r: "Here begins the prologue to the following sermons which our venerable father, Brother Jan Storm, preached in our monastery in Jericho when he was both our commissary and rector. These sermons, our esteemed mother, while she was not yet in the state of prelature, considering the heavy burden and labor of the said Honorable father, received the inspiration and devotion to transcribe these sermons, so that the labor of the preacher might be rewarded with eternal glory as often as anyone's devotion is moved to listen or study these sermons. Let us faithfully pray for our venerable father who has labored in preaching, and for our beloved mother, Sister Marie van Pee, may God grant her eternal peace, who has labored to transcribe this... So, I have endeavored to gather this following book from many sermons preached in our monastery over five years..."

f.299r: "Here end the sermons of our Venerable fathers, which I have gathered a few of for my own edification and for those who wish to study. And they were completed in the year of our Lord, 1366, on the feast of Saint Laurence, the glorious martyr, before vespers."

f.330v: "This book was completed in the year of our Lord when it was written. Fourteen hundred and sixty-seven, on the sixth day of September, on a Sunday.""

column11:
The Las Huelgas archivists have recently changed the signature of this codex. When Nicolas Bell published his essay in 2004, the codex still bore the signature «MS IX»; today it bears the signature «MS 11".
The main corpus of the manuscript was copied by only one scribe (Scribe A). As noted by Higini Anglès, the calligraphic work of this scribe is characterized by a high degree of irregularity and inconsistency, as well as by frequent changes of pen and ink.

column10: The Consueta was written entirely from the nuns’ perspective, but the clearest evidence that confirms the female identity is the use of verbs in first person to refer to the activities performed by the nuns (Catalunya, 2016, p. 110)
column11:
The Consueta was compiled and copied by a single scribe (scribe A), who wrote the seven senions, in collaboration with another scribe who wrote the chapter headings in red ink (Rubricator A). According to Catalunya, “we can be sure that the two main scribes of Huelgas 6 (Scribe A &Rubricator A) were women. The Consueta was written entirely from the nuns’ perspective, but the clearest evidence that confirms the female identity is the use of verbs in first person to refer to the activities performed by the nuns (Catalunya, 2016, p. 110)
Later a secondary scribe (Scribe B) added three f.s at the beginning of the codex with a table of contents for all seven senions and annexed two consecutive bif.s at the end of the codex, on which the scribe B copied commentaries to the Rule of St Benedict. This scribe also corrected the text and the rubrics of certain chapters in the main body of the manuscript and added a foliation in red roman numerals on the right side of the upper margin of each recto. Written above it is a modern foliation in Arabic numerals, in pencil.
Many other secondary hands contributed with further corrections throughout the entire manuscript. This suggests that the codex was in use for some time after its compilation.
column16:
Colophon on f.53r-v describing the content of that particular portion of the codex. “Eneste escripto ay escriptos auros números en quatro vezes [...]. E para catar el aure
número cómmo vyniere enel anno que fuere presente, quien lo quisiere saber lo puede ff allar en vno ayuntando el aure número e la claue delos términos e la epacta e el concurrente e la indiçión.
E [...] deue catar en qué día es para poner las estorias e las vigilias e las fiestas delos ssantos e cómmo lean los libros enel rrefi tor e cómmo an de faser quando ouieren defunto e todas las
otras cosas que son menester del ordenamiento del coro por todo el anno. E quien lo quisiere catar, ff allar lo ha desta guysa commo está aquí escripto para lo catar en cada anno”.
column18:
The colophon on f.53r-v describes the content of this particular section of the codex:

“This writing includes golden numbers written four times […]. And to determine the golden number for the current year, anyone who wants to know can find it by adding together the golden number, the key of the terms, the epact, the concurrent, and the indiction.

And […] they must check on which day the stories, vigils, and saints’ feasts should be placed, and how to read the books in the refectory, and what must be done when there is a deceased [person], along with all the other necessary matters for organizing the choir throughout the entire year.

Anyone who wishes to consult it will find it presented in this way, as written here, to be consulted annually.”

column11: (This is not the Dorothea von Kippenheim OP mentioned in VL 2 [1980], col. 218; rather, it refers to another sister of the same name who lived in the Unterlinden convent in the early 16th century [VL 11 (2004), col. 380].)
column16: f.324v: Ich swester Dorothea uon Kippenheim ein conuent Swester deß wirdigen loͤblichen gotzhuß Sancti Johannis baptiste in vnderlinden zuͦ Colmar hab diß buͦch vß dem latin zuͦ tútzsch geschriben got zu lob vnd och zuͦ eren Sancto Sebastiano vnd den anderen lieben heilgen die doran stond vnd ich beger bemuͤticlich dz die alle got wellen fúr mich bitten die do werden leßen an dißem buͦch Amen); das ist nicht die in VL 2 (1980) Sp. 218 genannten Dorothea von Kippenheim OP (zu ihr die biographischen Notizen von moderner Hand 325r), sondern eine gleichnamige Schwester, die Anfang des 16. Jahrhunderts im Kloster Unterlinden lebte (VL 11 [2004] Sp. 380); rote Strichel und Überschriften, Lombarden rot, z. T. mit blauem Federwerk, blau, z. T. mit rotem Federwerk.
column18: f.324v: I, Sister Dorothea von Kippenheim, a convent sister of the venerable and praiseworthy house of God, Saint John the Baptist in Unterlinden near Colmar, have written this book from Latin into German for the praise of God and also in honor of Saint Sebastian and the other dear saints mentioned therein. I humbly ask that all who read this book may be willing to pray to God for me. Amen.

column11:
Produced, signed, and dated by the Spanish nun Maria Dies de Oña, this early sixteenth-century Spanish manuscript gradual contains the “propers” and choral chants for the Mass for Cistercian Use, according to the pre-Tridentine liturgical calendar. Although a complete volume, it is not a complete work as it contains approximately only the first third of the liturgical year, from the first Sunday in Advent to Palm Sunday. Given the size and format of this volume, the complete gradual for the entire liturgical year would have been represented by three or four volumes.

Produced by a female religious copyist for use by the female monastery of San Salvador de Oña in Burgos, this substantial volume is almost entirely composed of chant and does not include the long spoken portions of the Mass. Minor leaf repairs, occasional corrections, marginal additions, and instructions for following the text indicate that this manuscript was used on a regular basis.
column16: last page: "Este libro se acabò a vii. dias del mes de Noviembre. año de quinientos xxiii. escriviole Mari. Dies de Oña, monja professa deste monasterio."
column18: last page: "This book was finished on the 7th day of November in the year 1523, written by Maria Dies de Oña (a nun professed within this monastery)."

column10: According to Stooker & Verbeij 1997, no. 364 produced by the sisters of the common life of the Brandeshuis or the Kerstekenshuis in Deventer, or the S. Ursulenhuis, which was created in 1470 from the merger of these houses. Origin based on comparison of hands from Deventer: SAB, 101 D 2 KL, 101 D 5 KL, 101 D 6 KL and 101 F 4 KL. See also Rademaker-Helfferich, who also identifies these hands with each other and dates the manuscripts 101 F 4 KL and 101 D 6 KL to around 1485, so in the period after the merger. - According to BNM, f.47r-247v from the same hand as Deventer, SAB: 101 F 4 KL etc. and according to Rademaker-Helfferich and BNM f.3r-6r same hand as Deventer, SAB: 101 D 9 KL, copied in 1474 by a sister in the S. Ursulenhuis, 101 F 15 KL, copied in 1459 in the Brandeshuis and 101 F 3 KL, copied in 1464 by a sister in the Kerstekenshuis or Brandeshuis, the predecessors of the S. Ursulenhuis.

column10:
Same woman as Deventer, ms. 59 and 36
Origin of S. Ursulenhuis in Deventer based on notes on f.2r, 57v and 193r. Since the copyist wrote the main text as well as colophon and property notes, it is assumed that the manuscript was also written in the S. Ursulenhuis. According to BNM from the same hand as Deventer, SAB: 101 F 15 KL, copied in 1459 in the Brandeshuis, 101 F 3 KL, copied in 1464 by a sister in the Kerstekens- or Brandeshuis, which merged in 1470 into the S. Ursulenhuis, and 101 D 6 KL, f.3r-6r.
column16: Aantekening op f.2r (rubriek): "Dit boeck hoert den susteren in sunte vrsulen huys toe deuenter inder beghinen strate". - Aantekening op f.57v (rubriek): "Dit boeck hoert den susteren in sunte vrsulen huys toe deuenter. Inder beghinen strate". - Aantekeningen op f.193r (rubriek): "Dit boeck is geeyn[sic] op die octaue van sunte laurens [is dit boeck geeyndet, doorgehaald]." en "Int iaer ons heren dusent iiii hondert l.xxiiii." en "Biddet om godes wil een. Aue maria voer die arme scriuester. [die dit scref..., doorgehaald]" en "Dit boeck hoert den susteren in sunte vrsulen huys toe deuenter inder beghinen strate". - Vormde op grond van band en inhoud waarschijnlijk een set met Deventer, SAB : 101 D 8 KL (I, 38).

Hail Mary for the poor scribe. [who wrote this..., crossed out]" and "This book belongs to the sisters in Saint Ursula's house in Deventer, in the Beguine street."
Based on the binding and content, likely formed a set with Deventer, SAB: 101 D 8 KL (I, 38).

column10:
Localization of the IJssel region and Diepenveen monastery based on pen work. On f.34v is referred to as an "anebedester", a female reader. - Note on f.1r: "Suster Merrigen kindly accepts this book."
Sister Merrigen Goeden, who owned the book at some point, was a nun in the Diepenveen monastery. In 1578, she and her fellow sisters fled to Deventer due to war, taking the books with them.

column18:
Note on the front flyleaf, f.II verso: "This book belongs to Deventer, in Saint Ursula's house or otherwise called Brandes house."
Note on f.97 recto: "In the year of our Lord 1459."
Note on f.182 recto: "This book belongs to the sisters of Saint Ursula's house. Otherwise called Brandes house within Deventer. This was written in the year of our Lord 1459."

Based on these notes, the book was written and belonged to Saint Ursula's house, also known as Brandes house, in Deventer, in the year 1459.

Biddet om die mynne godes voer die arme scryfster die dit scref want sie in voelen gebreken bleef"en "Dit boeck hoert tot sunte vrsulen huus wilneer gheheiten kersteken brandes bynnen deuenter". - Aantekeningen op f.171r: "Dit boeck is gheeyndet bynnen die octaue van paesschen. Int iaer ons heren .m.cccc lx iiij. Biddet om godes wil voer die arme scriuester die dit screef want sie in voel gebreken bleef" en "Dit hoert te deuenter in sunte vrsulen huus inder beghinen strate".
column18:
Dating based on colophons on f.s 143 verso and 171 recto; f.s 1-143 were copied in 1462, f.s 144-171 in 1464.
Annotations on f.143 verso, both in rubric: "This was written in the year of our Lord 1462 within the octave of Easter it was finished. Pray for the love of God for the poor scribe who wrote this because she remained in many faults" and "This book belongs to Saint Ursula's house, commonly known as Kersteken Brandes, within Deventer."
Annotations on f.171 recto: "This book was finished within the octave of Easter. In the year of our Lord 1464. Pray for the sake of God for the poor scribe who wrote this because she remained in many faults" and "This belongs to Deventer in Saint Ursula's house in the Beguine street."

column16: 30r: [ Dysß bu e chly han ich arme swo e ster Vrsul Schanfiggin v i ch allen minen minen [!] reht lieben mu e tren vnd swo e stren ze sant Katrinen ze Nu e renberg von gro u sser minn vnd tru i w geschriben han [!] , [30v] vnd beger mit ganczem herczen, das ir min alzit ernstlich vnd getrw i lich gedenkint vnd fu i r mich bittent vnd fu i r miner hertz lieben mu o ter selgen sel vnd fu i r v i nsers erwirdigen getru i wen vatter meister Hansen selgen sel. Vnd vernement ir minen to u d, ach so lo u nd v i ch min armen ellenden sel durch got getru i lich alzit beuolhen sin.]
column18: On f.30r: "This little book, I, poor Sister Ursula Schanfiggin, have written with great love and faithfulness for all my dear sisters and sisters at Saint Catherine's in Nuremberg. I beg with all my heart that you always remember me earnestly and faithfully and pray for me and for my dear departed mother's soul, and for our revered faithful father, Master Hans, who has passed away. And if you hear of my death, oh then, I commend my poor wretched soul faithfully to God."
column26: Schönensteinbach, Dominican convent Germany Nuremberg

column10: Similar hands to other manuscripts associated with Norfolk nunneries: scribe II may also be the hand responsible for Cambridge UL MS Hh.I.11, f.45r-53v, 55r-60r. D. Wakelin, says all four scribes/correctors were nuns "who as women might not have been trained well" or were "copy[ing] hastily in very current handwriting (Wakelin, Scribal Corrections and Literary Craft, p. 170) . O'Mara disagrees that the scribes were nuns (V. O'Mara, A Study and Edition of Selected Middle English Sermons: Richard Alkerton’s Easter Week Sermon Preached at St Mary Spital in 1406, a Sermon on Sunday Observance, and a Nunnery Sermon for the Feast of the Assumption, Leeds Texts and Monographs, n.s. 13 p. 154-6, 162).

column11: The colophon on page 233 r proves that it was written in 1473 by three nuns. Although the fonts change, the text sections of these three writers can be identified according to their writings (see above). Their names were entered in the necrology of the Cistercian monastery in Kentrop (Berlin SB Ms. lat. qu. 297) in the late 15th century: Katharina de Westhoven on October 28th (page 34 r ), Anna Kyttelers on March 15th (page 34 ). . 15 r ) and Katharina Konnygs (Regis) on May 7th (page 19 v ):

a single added f.at the end of Edinburgh University Library, MS 59 that may with certainty be attributed to Mary.
The insertion of a final f.to compensate for one that had got lost at the end of a quire (the catchword ‘iudicare’ is found on f.115v) would support de Hamel’s thesis that it was Mary’s job as chantress to repair manuscripts that had missing text.

f.1
(Possession note):My dearest Sister Kunigunda, from me, Sister Maria Cleopha Duocherin, in the convent of Saint Clare in Villingen: I beg you, my dearest sister, please also pray to God for me — that I will also do, as long as I live. With this, may we both be entrusted to God, on the 15th day of April, 1611.
(In another hand below)
This belongs to the convent of Saint Peter in Schwyz.

column11:
Written by Dorothea von Hof at the age of 25
scribe, Dorothea von Hof, née Ehingerin
Dorothea von Hof (1458-1501)
From the possession of Margarete Ehingerin, née Neidhart (died 1513), married since 1482 to the Constance patrician Hans Ehinger (1456–1505), son of Heinrich Ehinger and Margarete von Kappel; cf.the alliance coat of arms Ehinger/Neidhart 2r and the ownership entry 357r: This book belongs to Margreth Ehingerjn in Mergstat. Contrary to earlier opinions, it was therefore not the older Margarete Ehinger, née von Kappel (died 1490?), but rather her daughter-in-law who owned this manuscript (cf.Gebauer [2010] p. 37 f.[with family tree]); she was thus likely also the sister-in-law of the scribe, Dorothea von Hof, née Ehingerin. Regarding three other manuscripts from the possession of the older Ehinger generation, see Nos. 36.0.2. (Einsiedeln Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 710), No. 43.1.55. (Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 283), and No. 59.2.5. (St. Gallen, Kantonsbibliothek, VadSlg. Ms. 343 c–d).
column16: 357r [Lang]): Do man zalt von der geburt unsere heren Christi 1483 an s. Silvestertag han ich Dorothe von Hof dis buoch ungeschriben und bin davor ze herbst an s. Frenentag im 1482 iar alt gesin 24 iar und ist gesin nün iar an s; Pallus bekert im 83 iar, das Jerg und ich elich zesamen kamen. Liebe überwint alle alle ding. Deo gratias. Item und do ich alt bin gesin 19 iar uf s. Verenatag, do gieng ich uf des hl. crütztag nächst darnach genden Einsideln uf ain engelwiche und Satz do den sturtz uf und let etliche weltliche claider und clainet hin, das ich yr nit me truog.

column10: Possession note. See Moreton: "I am making this attribution on the basis that the possession note, identifying it as belonging to the nuns of Santa Maria a Monticelli, is in the same hand as the text. Also the content, decoration, script and hand are very much in line with the production at other female houses in Florence in this period. Same hand and production as with Bernardo, Sermoni del Tempo, in volgare, Florence, Biblioteca Medicea Laurenziana, Acquisti e doni 12. MDI cataloger (Lisa Frantini/ Stefano Zamponi) refers to them as twin volumes (even though they have been trimmed to different sizes). Both codices were acquired by Domenico Moreni 18 February 1824."

column16: f.1rB-vA in hand of Raffaella: “Al nome di messer (Yesu) (Christo) [then ‘ella’ crossed out] e della gloriosa vergine Maria, madre di Dio, e di messere sancto Giovanni Batista, nel dì della cui conceptione questo libro s’ è incominciato, addì XXIIII di settembre 1488” f.72rB, in red: “Questo libro è delle monache del Paradiso, copiato da me suora Raffaella con assai mia faticha (et) disagii. Et è l’ottavo ch’io ò copiato, tutti a spirituale consolatione delle mie in (Christo) sorelle (et) non credo copiarne più eccetto la Corona de’monaci, la quale ò cominciato ‘n altro volume. E sse la lettera è rusticha l’auctore e lle parole son degni, et in però sia riguardato”; f.99rA: “Amen. Finito è a dì 23 di giugno 1496”
column18:
f.1rB-vA in hand of Raffaella: "In the name of Lord (Jesus) (Christ) [then 'ella' crossed out] and of the glorious Virgin Mary, mother of God, and of Lord Saint John the Baptist, on the day of whose conception this book was begun, the 24th day of September 1488."

f.72rB, in red: "This book belongs to the nuns of the Paradiso, copied by me Sister Raffaella with much effort and hardship. And it is the eighth that I have copied, all for the spiritual consolation of my sisters in (Christ), and I do not believe I will copy more except for the Corona of the monks, which I have started in another volume. And if the letter is rustic, the author and the words are worthy, and therefore it should be regarded."

f.99rA: "Amen. Finished on the 23rd day of June 1496"

f.191r in red: "End. This is the end of the book about the life of the blessed Jerome and his companions, written by me, the sinner Sister Petronilla Nelli. I ask you, devout readers, to pray for me."

I ask all those to whom it comes into their hands to return it, as it is very dear to her for the preciousness of the book and in memory of her sister who has passed away."

Colophon
 (= Angela Rucellai? Angela Miniberti? Angela Mineberti?)
column11:
Suor Angela has been identified as Angela de’Rucellai, Dominican nun of San Jacopo di Ripoli (Levi D’Ancona, Miniatura e miniatori, 11) or as another copist from the same monastery, suor Angela Miniberti or Angela Mineberti (Pini Gruppo di codici, 267-268) Latham states: “This manuscript, also called the Manuale, contained all the prayers, the antiphonals, and the hymns, used by the nuns in their religious services.
Bradley I 38: a nun of the monastery of St. James or Ripoli. Her family name was Miniberti
column16: f.203v: "Finito libro isto. Laus et gloria sit domino Iesu Christo. Iesus. Ego soror Angela indigna serva domini nostri Iesu Christi scripsi manu propria hoc collectarium. Deus sit laudatus et pro me deprecatus. Qui scripsit scribat semper cum domino vivat. Vivat in Coelis semper cum domino felix. Facta fine pia benedicat virgo maria."
column18: f.203v: "This book is finished. Praise and glory to our Lord Jesus Christ. Jesus. I, Sister Angela, unworthy servant of our Lord Jesus Christ, wrote this breviary with my own hand. May God be praised and prayed for me."

column11: 1483 September 29 (on ff.59vB-60rA, after Raffaella copies the Leggenda di san Girolamo which ends at end of quire 6); 1500 June 1 (on f.92vAB where she fills in space to finish up quire 9); The works in this ms. were completed at at least 2 different times – probably 3, since there appear to three large binding sections which were bound together (with improper collection) – Binding section 1. quires 1-6 (ff.1r-60v – though quire 2 should actually be bound in with its work at end of ms.); Section 2. quires 7-9 (ff.61r-92v – this section lacks initials, caps and decoration); Section 3. quires 10-17 (ff.93r-172v)
column13: Nun-scribe Mother Maria Benigna di Stiatta Cavalcanti
column16:
f.20v, in lower margin, in hand of Raffaella: “Questo libro è delle suore del Paradiso scritto di mano di suora Raffaella”
371 ff.59vB-60rA Raffaella’s hand: “Finito è il transito di sancto Ieronimo. Fu finito di scrivere a dì ventinove di settembre nel mille quatrocento ottanta tre (et) è questo libro del monasterio di Sancta Brigida detto il Pradiso. Amen” (See photo) f.92vAB Raffaella’s hand: “Questo soprascritto sermone è posto qui per non lasciare carte vote. Credo sarebbe utile leggerlo ogni dì e scriverselo nel cuore. Finito fu questo libro a dì primo di giugno nell’anno del giubileo 1500” (See photo) (the ‘aforewritten sermon’ would be Book VI of Anselm of Canterbury’s Meditations which she copied in the blank space left in the quire (on ff.90r-92v) after finishing the pseudo-Jerome’s Exortation to the Monks which ends on f.90rA. But she also adds two more short sermons on the last f.of the quire (f.92v) - Giovanni Dominici’s Regola del governo di cura familiare and Giannozzo Sacchetti’s Esortazione morale. The next recto f.(f.93r) begins Iacopo da Varazze’s Legenda aurea.)
column18:
"f.20v, in the lower margin, in the hand of Raffaella: "This book belongs to the sisters of Paradiso, written by the hand of Sister Raffaella."
371 ff.59vB-60rA in Raffaella's hand: "The transit of Saint Jerome is finished. It was completed on the twenty-ninth day of September in the year fourteen eighty-three, and this book is from the monastery of Santa Brigida, also known as Paradiso. Amen." 
f.92vAB in Raffaella's hand: "This above-mentioned sermon is placed here to avoid leaving blank pages. I believe it would be useful to read it every day and write it in the heart. This book was finished on the first day of June in the year of the jubilee 1500."

column16: f.204rAB hand of Suor Cleofe: Finiti sono di scrive i devoti libri de’ sacri Evangelii disposti. Iscricti con grandissima faticha (et) disagio, la maggior parte a llume di lucerna. Siavi racchomandato (et) chi ll’acacta con riguardo si llo tengha et alle monache del Paradiso si llo renda. Cominciosi a scrivere [re added above] nel 1502 addì 12 di novembre, fu finito nel 1504 addì 28 d’octobre. Laus Deo. f.206vB, hand of Cleofe: Questo libro è del monasterio di Sancta Brigida, decto Paradiso, chi llo leggie prieghi Iddio per chi ll’à scricto.
column18:
f.204rAB, in the hand of Suor Cleofe: "The devout books of the sacred Gospels are finished being written. Written with great fatigue and discomfort, most of it by the light of a lamp. Let it be recommended, and whoever acquires it should hold it with respect and return it to the nuns of Paradiso. It was started on the 12th of November 1502 and finished on the 28th of October 1504. Praise be to God."
f.206vB, in the hand of Cleofe: "This book belongs to the monastery of Santa Brigida, known as Paradiso. Whoever reads it, may they pray to God for the one who wrote it."

f.212v colophon in hand of scribe Raffaella: “Questo libro è delle monache del Paradiso, scripto da una di loro medesima” then by same scribe, in a different (cursive) script she adds “cioè suora Raffaella” 
Same f.f.212v, at the bottom of page she also writes, in the same cursive “Questo libro è di suor Raffaella e del convento (et) monasterio del Paradiso”
column18:
f.212v, colophon in the hand of scribe Raffaella: "This book belongs to the nuns of Paradiso, written by one of them."
Then, by the same scribe, in a different cursive script: "that is, Sister Raffaella."
At the bottom of the same page, f.212v, she also writes, in the same cursive: "This book belongs to Sister Raffaella and to the convent and monastery of Paradiso."

column16: ‘colophon’ f.ix verso: gives date of 31 January 1597 and is signed “Indeg[n]a e minima sorella nel Sig[n]ore Su[uor]a Justina Niccolini” scribe and author identified on ff.179 recto and verso in D. Agostino Rinuccini’s letter to the nuns.
column18: The colophon on f.ix verso indicates the completion date as January 31, 1597, and is signed "Unworthy and humble sister in the Lord, Sister Justina Niccolini." The scribe and author are identified on f.s 179 recto and verso in a letter from D. Agostino Rinuccini to the nuns.

column16: f.154vB in hand of Suor Cleofe: Finissi di scrivere il detto libro negli anni del Signore mille quattrocento novanta Quattro, addì X d’aghosto. Iscritto con gran faticha e disagio la maggior parte di nocte al lume di lucerna. Prieghovi non ghuardiate alla rusticità della lettera, ma pigliate la sana e verace doctrina data dalla bocca della verità e della sua gloriosa madre virgho Maria alla nostra madre sancta Brigida. Priegho che chi llo leggie con diligentia lo tengha e cchi ll’acatta sì lo renda in the lower margin of the same f.(c. 154v), possession note in the hand of Cleofe: Questo libro è delle suore e monache del Paradiso. Suor Cleofe.
column18: f.154vB, in the hand of Sister Cleofe: "I finished writing the said book in the year of the Lord one thousand four hundred ninety-four, on the 10th of August. Written with great effort and hardship, mostly at night by lamplight. I ask you not to judge the simplicity of the letter, but to take the sound and true doctrine given by the mouth of the Truth and his glorious mother, the Virgin Mary, to our holy mother, Saint Bridget. I pray that whoever reads it diligently may keep it, and whoever buys it may return it." In the lower margin of the same f., possession note in the hand of Cleofe: "This book belongs to the sisters and nuns of the Paradiso. Sister Cleofe."

column16: f79v: Finisce la solenne amonitione come si debbe a honore di Duo usar l'anima, el corpo, la roba, e figliuoli, e beato a chi la observera, copiata per me s(uor)a N. del monastero di Sancta Lucia di via di San Gallo***, compiuta a di 27 di septembre 1518. Laus Deo semper.
column18:
f.79v:
“Here ends the solemn admonition on how one should use the soul, the body, possessions, and children to the honor of God, and blessed is the one who observes it. Copied by me, Sister N., of the Monastery of Saint Lucia on Via di San Gallo, completed on the 27th of September, 1518. Praise to God always.”

column18:
f.i verso (in red): "Here begins the devout book called 'Specchio di Croce,' made and compiled by the venerable religious in Christ, Reverend Father Frate Domenico Cavalca from Vico Pisano of the Order of Friars Preachers, written by me, unworthy servant and slave of Jesus Christ, Sister Angelica of the said order." 

f.120v: "Let whoever writes here live always with the Lord, may they live in heaven always with the Lord, happy. With pious praise, Blessed Virgin Mary. This book was finished writing on the 2nd of June, 1460."

column16: Colophon on f.141v: 'Gloria laus et honor tibi Christe, simulque Senensi virgini Caterine benedicite. Qui scripsit scribat semper cum Domino vivat, vivat in celis soror Checha serva fidelis. Factum est anno Domini M° CCCC°LXVIII° die XXVI mensis aprilis'
column18: Colophon on f.141v: "Glory, praise, and honor to you, O Christ, and likewise, blessings to the virgin Catherine of Siena. May she who wrote this, write forever with the Lord, may she live forever in heaven, faithful servant Sister Checha. Done in the year of the Lord M° CCCC°LXVIII°, on the twenty-sixth day of the month of April."

column16:
in red or reddish-sepia ink, much faded, f.369 bottom of column of text: “[O]* llaude e gloria dello omnipotente Dio e della gloriosa vergine Maria et di sancto Benedetto, P.N. è finito parte di questo libro, cioè capitoli 40, per mano di suora Paula, indengna serva di Yesu Christo, a consolatione di chi lo leggerà, e a chi piacerà, farà prece a dio con quello affetto di carità col quale essa l’à scripto con licentia della sua superiora.” 
f.370 colophon continues at top of column of text: “Nell’anno della salutifera incarnatione del Nostro Signore Yesu Christo Mccccc90 e a dì X del mese di settenbre. Finis.”
column18:
"f.369 bottom of column of text: "To the praise and glory of the Almighty God and of the glorious Virgin Mary and of Saint Benedict, P.N., part of this book is finished, namely chapters 40, by the hand of Sister Paula, unworthy servant of Jesus Christ, for the consolation of those who will read it, and to whom it may please, she will pray to God with that affection of charity with which she wrote it, with the permission of her superior."
f.370 colophon continues at top of column of text: "In the year of the salutary incarnation of Our Lord Jesus Christ MCCCCXC, and on the 10th day of the month of September. End."

column11: This is a very special manuscript since it shows evidence of the shared work of Raffaella, as an experienced scribe, and Cleofe. See f.57r where Raffaella passes text to Cleofe. The rubric of the text is partially visible in the upper margin of f.57r, and see f.61v where hand changes from Cleofe to Raffaella in middle of page. It also attests to the exchange of books between male and female religious.

column16: Anno domini M.CCC. L.IIII. in Aprili wart diz selebu/o/ch gemachet dem closter ze sante Katherinen bi Friburg von suester Adelheit von Ma/e/ngen der scaffenerin und von suester Agnesen Kemphinen der priolinen und von suester Katherinen von Chu/o/nnehein der selmeisterin... [es folgt ein ausradierter Text, dann:} Anno domini M.CCC.L.IIII.IIII. idus Aprilis scriptus est liber testamentorum nostrorum a Johanne de Constancia sacerdote. Omnes orate pro eo amen. HKOLHagenmaeier 1988 p. 180-181
column18:
“In the year of our Lord 1354, in April, this book of wills was created for the monastery of St. Catherine near Freiburg by Sister Adelheit von Maengen, the steward, Sister Agnes Kemphin, the prioress, and Sister Katharina von Chounnehein, the cellarer. [A section of the text is erased.]

In the year of our Lord 1354, on the fourth Ides of April [April 10], this book of wills was written by John of Konstanz, a priest. Pray for him, all of you. Amen.”

column16: Dis buch wart gescriben in dem jare do man zalte von gottes geburte drizehen hundert jar und 9 jar. An sant Johannes tag baptisten. in dem ogsten. Und wart gescriben under einre priolin du hies swester Anna Trullmennin und screib es Fena Tulenhoptin. Die bittent das ir ir gedenkent zu unserem herren ihu cristo. Amerum." (no info on Fena's status) AQI Lindgren 2001 p. 81-2 and 186
column18: “This book was written in the year of the Lord 1309, on the feast day of St. John the Baptist, in the East. And it was written under a prioress named Sister Anna Trullmennin, and it was written by Fena Tulenhoptin. They ask that you remember them before our Lord Jesus Christ. Amen.”

column11:
The origin in a Franciscan convent is evidenced by:
	•	The feast of the stigmatization of St. Francis (135r) and the rubric on f.150r referring to von unßerm werdigen vader Franciscus (“our worthy Father Francis”).
	•	The suffrage for Severus, unserm Patrone (“our patron”) on f.162r, situated within the liturgical year sequence between November 11 and November 21, suggesting Boppard (Archdiocese of Trier).
In 1489, Franciscan sisters from Besselich settled in Boppard, known for their manuscript production (cf.J. Marx, Geschichte des Erzstifts Trier, vol. 2, part 2, 1862, p. 423, and K. Schlegel, Besselich am Mittelrhein, 1980, p. 19).

column16: p.464: "Item dit boeck is gescreven te maestricht int besloeten suster huis opter meechden dries. Ende voleindet Op sancte Cristina dach Ende het heeft gescreven ein arme susterken arm van doechden suster katrijn van rade int jaer ons heeren doe men screiff M°CCCC ende lxxxvii Bidt om gods wil voer die scrivers einen Ave marien van mynnen dat ich alle mijn gebreken moet verwynnen ende mijnen god getrouwelicken mynnen Ende men in mach dijt boeck niet vercoupen want daer op sonnendage ende heilige dage in gescreven is"
column18: p.464: "Also, this book was written in Maastricht in the enclosed sisters' house at Meerssener Dries. And it was completed on Saint Christina's day. And it was written by a poor sister, poor in virtues, Sister Katrijn van Rade, in the year of our Lord when it was written, 1487. Pray for God's will for the scribes. An Ave Maria in love, that I may overcome all my shortcomings and love my God faithfully. And this book cannot be sold because it contains writing done on Sundays and holy days."

column11:
Second hand: A littera textualis hand was responsible for certain sections of the manuscript, including table of contents, rubrics, headings, and old foliation. This suggests at least two phases of scribal work and emphasizes the manuscript’s organized structure.

column11:
Second hand: A littera textualis hand was responsible for certain sections of the manuscript, including table of contents, rubrics, headings, and old foliation. This suggests at least two phases of scribal work and emphasizes the manuscript’s organized structure.

column16:
f.1v: "Men sal oec weten dat alle dese sermoene sijn ghescreven uut der predicaren monde alsoe na ende ghelijck als men can van twee onse religiose susteren ... Der eender name es suster baerbara cuyermans ..." f.2r: "Die ander es ghenaemt suster elizabeth van poelke ..." 
f.2r: "... Nu com ic suster mergriete van steenberghen ... Ende hebbe ... desen boeck ghescreven ende vergadert met aerbeyde ..." 
f.255v: "Desen boeck es volscreven opden heileghen trinityt avent inden jaer ons heren dusent .cccc. ende lxxix. God sij gheloeft ende ghemint ewijlijck Amen"
column18:
f.1v: "It should also be known that all these sermons are written from the preaching of our Dominican sisters, as accurately and faithfully as possible, by two of our religious sisters ... One of them is named Sister Barbara Cuyermans ..."
f.2r: "The other is named Sister Elizabeth van Poelke ... Now I, Sister Margriete van Steenberghen, come ... And I have ... written and compiled this book with labor ..."
f.255v: "This book is fully written on the Holy Trinity Eve in the year of our Lord one thousand four hundred and seventy-nine. God be praised and loved eternally. Amen."
column19: Brussels, Cloister Notre-Dame of the Rose of Jericho
column26: Brussels, Cloister Notre-Dame of the Rose of Jericho Belgium Brussels

column16: f.236r: "Dit boec is ghescreven inden besloten regularersen cloester dat ghelegen is bynnen oestmal in dat mercgrefscap van hantwerpen Ende ghesticht is inder eeren der precentacien der saligher maghet ende ghebenedider moeder gods Maria Ende is gheeynt op die vigilie pasione petri et pauli der glorioser ende heiligher apostelen: van mi suster heilken jacops Een vanden vieren die dit cloester hebben helpen begynnen ter eeren gods: mer die mynste in duechden Enen Ave maria uut mynnen / Men en maech dit boec niet vercopen. want tis veel op heilighe dage ghescreven"
column18: f.236r: "This book is written in the enclosed regular cloister located in Oostmalle in the county of Antwerp and established in honor of the Presentation of the Blessed Virgin Mary. It was completed on the vigil of the Passion of the Glorious and Holy Apostles Peter and Paul by me, Sister Heilken Jacobs, one of the four who helped establish this cloister to the glory of God, albeit the least in virtues. An Ave Maria from me. It is not permitted to sell this book, for it has been written on many holy days."
column19: Oostmalle. Regularissen S. Maria / Onser liever vrouwen Presentatie
column26: Oostmalle. Regularissen S. Maria / Onser liever vrouwen Presentatie Belgium Oostmalle

column11: In the period after the introduction of the reform, Engelthal received a German martyrology from the Nuremberg St. Catherine's Monastery, which Sister Christina Kamrerin completed on October 28, 1518. She wrote it for the prioress Birgitta Haller and the convent. The manuscript is now in the Gera City Archives (HB 7623) and was made known by Antje Willing: The Library of the St. Catherine's Monastery in Nuremberg. Synoptic Representation of the Book Lists Vol. 1 (2012), p. LXXXII (see also http://www.handschriftencensus.de/10308 with a link to the archive description by Paul Sparmberg).
column26: Nuremberg, Dominican St. Katharina nunnery Germany Nuremberg
column29: Part I: 15th century (Rau p. 299); Part II: 1518 (page 218v)

Antje Willing (Hg.), Die Bibliothek des Klosters St. Katharina zu Nürnberg. Synoptische Darstellung der Bücherverzeichnisse, 2 Bde., Berlin 2012, S. LXXXII, Anm. 184.

column11:
Also contains a library catalogue of the convent of St. Margaret, Gouda (f.238v)
Cinq de ces sœurs ont écrit le ms. La Haye, Bif.roy. 129 G 4 (daté de 1460; notre n° 484); deux des sœurs (Ava Thrici et Gheeze Yzenoudi) ont écrit le ms. London, B.L. Add. 22562, daté de 1449 (CMD-GB 1 no. 266). Il est extrêmement difficile de discerner les mains de ces sœurs; pour ce problème, voir G. Noordzij, 'Die Hânde der sieben Schwestern', Ned. Archief voor Kerkgesch. 56 (1975) 180-188
column16: f.238v°: Explicit collectarius scriptus per manus septem monialium scilicet marie johannis geze yzenoudi. ave tricijacobe gerardi agathe nycolai. marie martini et marie gerardi. finitus anno domini millesimo quadringentesimo quinquagesimo quarto ipso die sancti odulphi confessons (textualis formata). Isti sunt libri latinipertinentes ad librariam conventus sancte Margarete in gouda (catalogue, ajouté après coup en littera hybrida).
column18: f.238 verso: Here ends the collectary written by the hands of seven nuns, namely Marie, Johannis, Geze, Yzenoudi, Ave, Tricijacobe, Gerardi, Agathe, Nycolai, Marie, Martini, and Marie, Gerardi. Finished in the year of our Lord one thousand four hundred fifty-four, on the very day of Saint Odulph, confessor. These are the Latin books belonging to the library of the convent of Saint Margaret in Gouda (catalog, added later in hybrid letter).

column11: Dutch translation of Gerard Zerbolt van Zutphen's De spiritualibus ascensionibus
column16: f.120: Hier is nu dat eynde (...) Ende heeft ghescreven ende gheeyndet bider hulpen ons heren jhesu christi sybrich willem enghels dochter een arm susterkijn wonende in beverwijc mitten regulierissen Intjaer ons heren Mcccc xlvi bid voer haer om goeds willen. Des si god ghelovet nu ende in ewicheit Amen. F.121: Dit boec hoert totten regulierissen in beverwijc (copiste)
column18: f.120: Here is now the end (...) And it was written and finished with the help of our Lord Jesus Christ by Sybrich Willem, daughter of an Englishman, a poor little sister living in Beverwijk with the regular sisters, in the year of our Lord 1446. Pray for her for God's sake. Thus she praised God now and forever. Amen. f.121: This book belongs to the regular sisters in Beverwijk. (Scribe)

column11:
Various attempts to identify this woman as a member of a family from Bremen or a nun from a Cistercian convent in the Diocese of Erfurt could not be substantiated, especially since these attributions conflict with the Middle Rhenish writing style of the manuscript. It is clear that the later hand did not contribute to the manuscript itself, as their contribution is limited to five words, which should therefore be considered an ownership inscription.
Dating the manuscript poses challenges. Earlier research noted that the year “1404” appeared on an erasure, originally intended as “1504.” Since then, the manuscript has been dated to 1504. This late dating is further supported by watermark analysis, indicating that the earliest paper used by the scribe was not in circulation before 1480. However, the manuscript’s layout, which remains very traditional and medieval, aligns more closely with manuscripts from the early 15th century than those from around or after 1500.

column16: f.160: Completus est liber praesens a. d. 1509 ipso die Crisogoni m. quem scripsit Agnes Klencke monialis in Visbeke ad laudem dei ac s. mariae v. sanctique Iohannis bapt. patroni nostri. Oretur igitur pro scriptrice ut post hanc vitam perducatur ad eterna gaudia.
column18: “The present book was completed in the year 1509 on the very day of St. Chrysogonus’ feast, written by the nun Agnes Klencke in Vischbeck, for the praise of God, of the Virgin Mary, and of St. John the Baptist, our patron. Therefore, let prayers be said for the scribe, that after this life she may be led to eternal joy.”

column16:
f.151v
Istum librum procuravit fr. Iacobus ad honorem S. Marie Virg. et eius filio et ordinavit eundem in chorum prioris qui secus fecerit anathema coram summo deo sit et scriptus est a venerabili sorore Katherina de Brugg moniali in rubeo monasterio sub a.d. 1366 Quicunque cantat vel legat in eo habeat nostri memoriam aput deum. Ego kathe dicta zebrugg in rubeo monasterio.
column18: “This book was procured by Brother Jacob in honor of the Virgin Mary and her Son, and he placed it in the prior’s choir. Whoever does otherwise [with this book] may be anathema before the Almighty God. It was written by the venerable Sister Katherine of Brugg, a nun in the Red Monastery, in the year of our Lord 1366. Whoever sings or reads from it, may they keep us in memory before God. I, Katherine, called ‘Zebrugg,’ in the Red Monastery.”
