column16: [Hunc librum mihi donavit reverenda et generosa dna Iustina a Lupffen abbatissa ecclesie XI milium virginum eumque propria sua manu conscripsit mihique Stephano Isaaco praedictae ecclesiae canonico eium perp. memoriae signum tradidit. Sit ei deus propitius. a. 1571.]
column18: “This book was given to me by the reverend and noble Lady Iustina a Lupffen, abbess of the Church of the Eleven Thousand Virgins, and she wrote it with her own hand, giving it to me, Stephen Isaac, a canon of the same church, as a sign of perpetual remembrance. May God be merciful to her. In the year 1571.”

column16: f.146v: Explicit exp/iciunt / que cordis intima promunt / scriptando manu /totoque corporis usu /ut clare patebit I oculo quas [ ?) cuncta rimabit / Scripta cum floribus / picturam sie sociamus/ omnia hec fecit / et famula sola peregit / in Meding claustro / Luneborch prope situato/ ordinis ut fateor / Cisterciensis et utor / Sed si queratur / quod nomen mihi debetur /omnibus et cognita / de Winsen sie vocitata / Elyzabeth proprio / de quo et gloria Christo /anno milleno quadruplex centum addito deno / sexaginta tribus cum quinario sociatus /corporis in festo Christi die venerando / Iubente venerabili domino preposito Tylemanno /de Bauenstede et necessaria ministrando I ob amorem dilecte stte amice Elyzabeth / de Bauenstede
column18: f.146v: "Here ends what the deepest thoughts of the heart reveal, written by hand and with the full use of the body, as will be clearly seen by the eye that examines all. Written with flowers, so let us join illustration with text. All this was done and completed by the servant alone in the cloister of Meding, situated near Luneburg. I confess that I belong to the Cistercian order and use the name known to all, called Elisabeth of Winsen. To my own glory and to the glory of Christ, in the year one thousand, four hundred, and ten, with ten added and sixty-three with five combined, on the venerable feast day of Christ, by the command of the venerable Lord Provost Tylemann of Bavensted, and for the sake of ministering to the needs, for the love of my beloved friend, Elisabeth of Bavensted."

column16: Incipit: A treshaute et puissante Princesse Elizabeth Roine d'Angleterre et cetera, Madame, combien que ie soye peu exercée ... De votre Majestie La treshumble, tresobeissante et tresaffectionnée servante a Jamais, Esther Langlois, Fille Françoise. Explicit: de pouvoir a Jamais vous faire treshumble service. Huius ipsius Libelli Prosopopoeia, Filia me scripsit mandante vtroque Parente/ Exilii calamo taedia discutiens.
column18:
Incipit: “To the most high and powerful Princess Elizabeth, Queen of England, etc., Madam, although I am little practiced… From Your Majesty’s most humble, most obedient, and most affectionate servant forever, Esther Langlois, a French daughter.”

Explicit: “To be forever able to render you most humble service. The personification of this very little book — my daughter wrote me, at the command of both parents / driving away the tedium of exile with her pen.”

column11:
f.63r–125v; 126ra–145vb: Conradus de Soltau, Glossa super Psalterium
Two complementary excerpts. Listed in Stegmüller Repertorium Biblicum 2, no. 2018 (this manuscript is not mentioned). The prologue begins on f.126ra. The scribe is also the compiler of these excerpts. Fols. 63v, 64r, and 145vb contain revealing notes about her work. On f.125va, the colophon reads: “This gloss on the Psalter was finished and completed on the Saturday within the Octave of Corpus Christi (June 14) in the year of our Lord 1460.”

column11:
Written in a bastarda script predominantly by Sister Regula, except for:
        •        f.46ra (7 lines)
        •        f.222vb–223rb (two contemporary hands)
        •        f.51v (an addition around 1500).
Corrections and additions, mostly by the original scribe, are present.

Book of Holy Maidens and Women (f.1ra–223rb)
        •        Introduction: Discusses the four cardinal virtues symbolized by the four rivers of paradise (Ortus voluptatis).
        •        Legends: A collection of 57 legends of female saints, beginning with St. Mary Magdalene (Maria stabat ad monumentum foris plorans).
        •        Provenance: Compiled by Sister Regula, as noted in secondary literature (e.g., K. Kunze).
        •        Literature: The legend of Mary of Egypt has been edited by K. Kunze (1978).
        2.        Pseudo-Eusebius, Epistola ad Damasum de Morte Hieronymi, German Translation (f.223va–228rb, 267va–278rb)
        •        A medieval German adaptation of the Latin text (BHL 3866), attributed to Pseudo-Eusebius, concerning the death of St. Jerome.
        •        The German translation does not match other known Middle High German versions.
        3.        Pseudo-Jerome, Letter to His Mother on Virtues (f.229ra–240rb)
        •        An instructional and exhortative letter, in which “Jerome” advises his mother on virtuous living.
        •        The manuscript’s version is not mentioned in key reference works.
        4.        The Golden Pater Noster (f.240rb–243rb)
        •        An expanded meditation on the Pater Noster (Our Father) prayer, reflecting on its theological implications.
        •        Includes parallels with Patrologia Latina (PL 149, 569–576).
        5.        A Short Gloss on the Pater Noster (f.243rb–244ra)
        •        A brief guide on the meaning and spiritual significance of the prayer.
        6.        The School of Virtues (f.244ra–252vb)
        •        A didactic dialogue between a master and a novice (later referred to as a novitiate), discussing ascetic virtues and leading to eternal life.
        7.        Epistola ad Moniales (f.252vb–255ra)
        •        An exhortative letter to nuns, urging them to heed divine inspiration and embrace the love of Christ.
        8.        Dicta on the Gift of Tears and Prayer (f.255ra–255vb)
        •        Spiritual reflections and teachings attributed to Augustine, Basil, Paschasius, and Bernard.
        9.        An Epistle to an Abbess (f.255va–259ra)
        •        A letter emphasizing love and obedience, comparing divine love to the strength of death, and exalting Christ as the bridegroom of virgins.
Ascetic Instructions (f.259ra–262va)
        •        A text composed for the “entertainment of young cloistered nuns” by a learned priest.
        •        Focuses on ascetic ideals and encouragement, referring to the nuns as Christ’s chosen spouses.
        •        Likely written specifically for the Lichtenthal convent.
        2.        Another Epistle on Five Virtues (f.262va–264vb)
        •        Opens with Ponite corda vestra in virtute eius (Ps 47,14), emphasizing the virtues that adorn a faithful life.
        •        Encourages the practice of virtues to achieve eternal blessedness.
        •        Ends with a devotional note from the scribe, requesting a recitation of one Ave Maria.
        •        Mentions Liber Monasterii Lucida Vallis, linking it to Lichtenthal Abbey (often called Lucida Vallis in Latin).
        3.        On True Poverty (f.265ra–266ra)
        •        Draws on Matthew 12:1 to explore the virtue of poverty in imitation of Christ and his disciples.
        •        Provides a theological framework for embracing material poverty as a spiritual ideal.
        4.        A Consolatory Sermon by St. Bernard (f.266ra–267ra)
        •        Begins with Bonum est nos hic esse (Mt 17:4), using Bernard of Clairvaux’s alleged reflections to address monastic audiences.
        •        Discusses the joys and trials of cloistered life and the ultimate reward of eternal glory.
        5.        Poem on the Meaning of Suffering (f.267ra)
        •        A six-stanza poem offering solace to those enduring hardships, linking suffering to the promise of the Kingdom of Heaven.
        •        Contains irregularities in verse and stanza structure, reflecting its devotional rather than literary focus.
        6.        Return to Pseudo-Eusebius, Epistola ad Damasum (f.267va–278rb)
        •        This section resumes from f.223va, completing the translation of Pseudo-Eusebius’s text on the death of St. Jerome.

column11: Anna Schott (ca. 1450-after 1521), daughter of the Strasbourg mayor Peter Schott (1427-1504) and sister of the jurist, theologian, and humanist Peter Schott (1460-1490), can be traced in Strasbourg as a Dominican nun of the convents St. Agnes and St. Margaret and St. Agnes (from 1475). She was extensively educated. During the fire of the Strasbourg city library in 1870, a manuscript written by her around 1500 (.Historia sanctorum") was lost (Schlechter, Schott, p. 467). In Schwarzach 19, it is the second known Anna Schott manuscript; it was considered lost (Cowie/Cowie (see Lit.), p.753).

column11: Magdalena Steimerin appears as the abbess in the annual accounts of the Strasbourg Abbey of St. Clare in 1485/86 and 1486/87 (StA Straßburg, AH 10819, 1485/86, p. 2, 1486/87, p. 1). Expenditures for a Klarenbuch are listed in the accounts for 1489/90 and 1490/91: Item Vd. for gold for the book of St. Clare (StA Straßburg, AH 10819, 1489/90, p. 16); Item IIII s. for the book of St. Clare to be bound (StA Straßburg, AH 10819, 1490/91, p. 27); see Rf.bf.r (see ref.), p. 51 f and note 33 f.

column16: f.81v: "Scrita nel monast[er]io de le done de Sa[n] Fra[n]çesco della crose de Vei[n]esia de lordene de S[an]c[t]a Chiara de hoserva[n]çia. Nelliani del n[ost]ro signor mis[er] Ih[es]u Chr[ist]o 1500 finito a di 3 deçe[m]brio. S[uor] Le? Bol?. E tu lezitore prega Dio p[er] el scritore. Amen. De s[uor] Lena [...]. Sc[ri]to de sua mano."
column18: "Written in the monastery of the women of Saint Francis of the Cross in Venice, of the Order of Saint Clare of observance. In the year of our Lord Jesus Christ 1500, finished on the 3rd of December. Sister Le? Bol?. And you, reader, pray to God for the scribe. Amen. By Sister Lena [...]. Written by her hand."

column11: This manuscript was written in Vadstena Abbey, in the nuns scriptorium. The parchment was payed by sr Birgitta Gudmundi and it was completed at S Michaels eve 1517. It was written by one of the nuns, keeping her identity secret in the colophon on f.37v. It contained music and was intended for use in the church. There are closely related manuscripts in both Uppsala and Stockholm Libraries, either written or decorated by the same nun/nuns. The nuns had taken influence from their sisters i the Netherlands in the design of the large pen-flourished initials. One of the nuns who most frequently painted her large decorated initials in the same style as here was Christina Hansdotter Brask, but she seem to have hade successors. A very similar design can be found in KB A 12, UUB C 431, C 443, C 484, RA E 9002. Some of these are by Christina Hansdotter Brask and from the same period as this manuscript. The present mss is however executed by a much more stable hand than the Brask mss from the same period. A more suitable candidate is Katarina Gudmundsdotter, whose palaeography is in accordance with the scribe of this mss.
column16: f.37v: “Thässen bok aer skriffuet uppå thz perman som systr birgitta iohannis gudmundi aategudh alzwallogher the siälena miskwnne bidhin kära systra för henne oc glömen ey mik sum skreff oc wrt thenna bok lyktat oppa sancte michaells affton anno domino MDXVII gudh till hedher oc edher almaent oppa badha chora till hugnat”.
column18: “This book is written on the parchment owned by Sister Birgitta Johannis Gudhmundi. May God, all-merciful, have mercy on her soul. Dear sisters, pray for her and do not forget me, who wrote this book, which was completed on the eve of Saint Michael, in the year of our Lord 1517, to the honor of God and for the spiritual benefit of you all, both in the choir and beyond.”

column18:
“With the book finished, praise be to Christ. Pray for the scribe who wrote this book; her name is Elizabeth.
In 1260, under the first abbess, Agnes Graddin von Preyssing, this great office book was written by the nun Elizabeth.
In 1462, another nun, Elizabeth Hyttlen, also completed the Gradual Book. She served as cantor for 35 years.”

Finiti anno domini MoCCCCo XLIXo in festo decollationis sancti Johannis Baptiste ante summam missam. Et habebat ad hoc pergamenum sibi ex caritate prouisum de venerabili presbitero domino nycolao Wyt tunc temporis earundem patre spirituali et sibi ipsius spirtualiter ac in domino sat reuerenter dilectio...' column18: "Here ends. To God be praise Almighty – the five books about the life and conduct of the holy fathers, written by the hands of sisters Aue Trici and Gheeze Ysenoudi, on their feast days, for their beloved fellow sisters, in their memory. Finished in the year of our Lord 1449, on the feast of the beheading of Saint John the Baptist before High Mass. And for this purpose, she had parchment provided for her out of charity by the venerable priest Lord Nicholas Wyt, at that time their spiritual father and, with great reverence, her spiritual father in the Lord..."

column16: f.210v: "Item diit boeck is volscreven int jaer ons heren vijftien hondert ende xxx ende heeft geeynt op sante antonys avont ende heeft gescreven suster foelsken hoeymans diet uut mynnen om gods wil int sieck huys gescreven heeft in hoeren enen tachtichsten jaren een Ave maria uut mynnen om gods wil."
column18: "Also, this book was fully written in the year of our Lord fifteen hundred and thirty, and was completed on the eve of Saint Anthony, and it was written by Sister Foelsken Hoeymans, who wrote it out of love for God, in the infirmary, in her eighty-first year. An Ave Maria out of love for God."

column11: The date '1134' at the end of the note is a post-medieval addition, but the names of five of the nuns are found at the end of a manuscript dated 1130 and produced in the same abbey. Moreover, four among them are mentioned in the mid-12th-century necrology of the same house (see Thoma 1951).
column16: f.166r: 'Hec sunt nomina illarum quae scripserunt librum istum. / Gerdrut. Sibilia. Dierwic. Walderat. Hadewic. / Lugart. Derta (or Ota). Cunigunt. Ipse namque scripserunt mo/nasteriensibus dominis quatinus deum pro eis rogent ut a pe/nis eas liberet & in paradyso collocet. Quisquis eis ab/stulerit anatematizatus sit': (a) ff.1v-29v; (b) ff.30r-50v; ff.51r-63v; ff.64r-93v; ff.94r-119v; ff.120r-145v; ff.146r-153r; ff.154r-167v.
column18: "These are the names of those who wrote this book: Gerdrut, Sibilia, Dierwic, Walderat, Hadewic, Lugart, Derta (or Ota), Cunigunt. They wrote it for the lords of the monastery so that they may pray to God for them to be liberated from punishment and placed in paradise. Whoever takes it away from them shall be cursed."

column11: Lambeth Palace Library MS 546 is a collection of devotional material written by a number of late fifteenth- or early sixteenth-century hands. The main contents are 'The xv Sorowes of oure lady' (fos 7v-20v) and the 'golden letany' (fos 34r-51v, with a preface on fos 29r-33v),4 with devotions in English, and prayers in English and Latin making up the rest of the volume. It is with one of these devotions, specifically its colophon, that the present note is concerned.
column16: f.55r: Good Syster of your charyte I you pray remember the scrybeler when that ye may wit/i on aue maria or els thys swete word ihesu have marcy on my wreched syster whose name by the marcy of god rj trust"1 shall be wrytyn In the boke of lyfe Good deuote Syster I pray you to lerne thys lesson well of your master our sauyour cryst ihesu that sayth lerne of me for I am mylde and meke in hart and pray for me that I may do and haue the same
column18: "f.55r: Good sister, in your charity, I pray you to remember the scribe when you may, with an Ave Maria or else this sweet word: 'Jhesu, have mercy on my wretched sister, whose name, by the mercy of God, I trust shall be written in the book of life.' Good devout sister, I pray you to learn this lesson well from your master, our Savior Christ Jhesu, who says, 'Learn of me, for I am mild and meek in heart,' and pray for me that I may do and have the same."

column11: An Antiphonal contains the choral parts sung during the celebration of the Divine Office or Mass celebrated by a monastic or other community. This type of choirbook was usually written in large format so that the whole choir could read the music at once. This example was made at the convent of St Klara in Cologne by one of the nuns, Sister Loppa de Speculo. Another surviving leaf records that Sister Jutta paid for the book while Loppa carried out the writing, lining (putting in the staves for the music), notation and illumination 'in the year 1350, when there was a great plague everywhere'. This was one of a series of books produced in the convent. The Abbess, Heylwigis von Beechoven, who had ruled the convent since 1344, is portrayed kneeling by the historiated initial of the Descent of the Holy Ghost on the Virgin and Apostles associating her prayer with this crucial event, when the Holy Spirit came to earth and the mission of the Apostles to spread the Christian revelation began. The prayer of her convent was thus part of the mission.

column16: Cum ageretur a partu virginis annus vicesimus secundus post mille quingentos scripsit librum hunc soror Magdalena Buxtehuden hic regulari professione Christo dicata. Sumptus provenere ex diversis fidelium elemosinis. Exoretur deus pro omnibus qui manus hoc porrexere adiutrices.
column18:
When the 22nd year after the birth of the Virgin’s Son was being counted (i.e., in the year 1522), this book was written by Sister Magdalena Buxtehuden, here consecrated to Christ by religious profession.
The costs were covered by various offerings from the faithful.
May God be entreated on behalf of all who extended helping hands in this work.

column16: (f.126r) Hie ist volendet di legend von sand Franciscen. Die hat geschriben Elspet von Amberk in den iar, do man zalt von Chistes geburt tausent und driuhundert und in dem xxxvij iar. So hat Katerina von Purchhausen geschriben di legend von sancto Antonio. Und diu was in den lxvij iar alt, da si di legend schreip. Und di legend wurden peid geschriben vnd erleuht und volpraht nah sand Bartholomeus des na’htes tages. Swer di legend les, der pit got fur si, und fur [durchgestrichen] vᵒch fur di, di daz permeid und daz pinten habent verrihte, daz uns Got allen helfe zu den erlichen scharen des lieben herren sand Franciscen und der werden frowen sand Chlaren. Amen.
column18: (f.126r) Here ends the legend of Saint Francis. This was written by Elspet von Amberk in the year counted from Christ's birth as one thousand three hundred and thirty-seven. Then Katerina von Purchhausen wrote the legend of Saint Anthony. She was sixty-seven years old when she wrote the legend. The legends were completed, illuminated, and perfected after Saint Bartholomew's day at night. Whoever reads the legend, pray to God for her, and for [crossed out] also for those who have sponsored and arranged it, may God help us all to the honorable company of the beloved Saint Francis and the venerable lady Saint Clare. Amen.

column11:
273 sheets (bound together from 2 parts: I: sheets 1-106; II: sheets 107-273)
	1.	First hand: from 107r, line 14 to 222r, and from 239r to 273r. The scribe identifies herself:
	•	109r: “el”, 190v: “eis”, 222r: “soror Elisabeth” – identified as Elisabeth Muntpratin the Elder (1459–1531), a member of the Dominican convent of St. Katharina in St. Gallen from 1472.
	•	See CMD-CH 3, Text volume, p. 34, no. 86; p. 101f., no. 285; p. 288 for more manuscripts and literature attributed to her, with figures 440 and 442.
	2.	Second hand: 222v–225v.
	3.	Third hand: 107r, lines 1–13, and 227r–238v.

column16: Liber Bartholomeus ich bekenn und waiss daz ir ain fraind seit gelerter lu"tt...so han ich... aus latein zu teuschtz pracht (229r)--SHE TRANSLATED!; COLOPHON (241r): Siech und schweig, hör und leid, Sich und schweig, hoer und leid ... so bistu güt. Scriptum et finitum per me sororem Elisabeth Warrüßin professe in cenobio sante Katherine ordinis predicatorum anno clomini M°CCCC°LXXIII in vigilia sanctorum Fabiani et Sebastiani martirum (=19. Jan.). Sit laus deo, 1473.01.19, 1473 (Initium for the treatise is "siech und schwieg...")
column18:
Translation Note (f.229r): “Book of Bartholomew: I acknowledge and know that you are a friend, a learned person… so I have translated it from Latin into German.”

Colophon (f.241r):

“See and be silent, listen and endure. See and be silent, listen and endure… and thus you will be good.”
(This is also the incipit of the treatise: “siech und schwieg…”)

“Written and completed by me, Sister Elisabeth Warrüßin, professed in the convent of Saint Katherine of the Order of Preachers, in the year of our Lord 1473, on the vigil of Saints Fabian and Sebastian, martyrs (i.e. January 19).”

“Praise be to God.”

column16: f.Iv: Gedenckt der lieben unser geislich muter Anna Ebyn die daz puch und gar und vil pu/e/cher dem convent hat geschriben die ungezelt sind (librarian's entry). Also, on 1r, librarian has written "Daz puch ist der ffrawen zu Pillennrewt und sol allczeit pey dem clostr beleyben. In the 4th item (14v-24r), Joh. von Marienwerder's 37 Zeichen der Gottesliebe der Dorothea von Montau, Anna Ebin announces "Aber an eim roten puch da etlich heyligen an steen (=Wolf cod. 17.9.Aug.4o, see Ringler VL 2nd ed 2, 295 and MTU 72 s. 55-57) hab ich dy geschriben ... alz ez meister Nycloz prediger zum newen spital zu Nurmberg Dorothee peichtigers schulgesell beschryben hat. (15r). For 9th item, Schwesternbuch von Weiler, colophon reads "Geendet am eritag nach der h. trinitat in die Marci und Marcelliani (=18 June) anno domini M. CCCC. LIIII. im covent zu Bildenrew/e/t. At end of 17th item (145r-174v), Vita of H. Eufrasia, dt. von Kaspar KreSS, "Geendet am freytag nach dem achten tag dez obersten in die sancte Prysce ... anno domini M. CCCC. LX. (=18 Jan)... Pitet got fu"r dye schreyberin und auch fu"r den dew"tschmacher diser legend eins gelerten pryster sanct Benedicten ordens zu sancto Egydigio (!) zu Nu"rmbeg genant mgr. C. Kr. (=Kaspar KreSS). A SECOND HAND COPIED Item 22 (252v-274v) shows that she consciously copied this as a "buchlein" -- in sections. For Bonaventura, De quinque festivitatibus pueri Jesu (dt), she says "Also hat ende das puchelein wi Yesus Xc kind ist worden und entfangen geportn geislich etc. 1461

Anf.f.80v: 'Ich minne den heiligen krist in des brutbette ich bin gegangen . . . bit fur die armen engelbirne daz si got bekere des ist not ir armen sele.' f.81r leer. Schl.f.81v: 'Liebe muter habe unseren herren lip . . . wenne daz unser minne ceginge daz enceme deme grozen herren niht der unser minne gemeisteret hat.'
column18: f.80v-81v: Mystical outpourings of the recluse Engelbirn. Beginning on f.80v: 'I love the Holy Christ I have gone into the bridal bed . . . pray for poor Engelbirn that she may be aware of God it is necessary for her poor soul.' f.81r is blank. Conclusion on f.81v: 'Dear mother, have our Lord's body . . . when our love comes to that which belongs to the great Lord who has created our love.'

column16: Anno Domini MCCCCLXXVI scriptus est hic liber per manus sororis Katherina Mast monialis per fessae in valle ducis orate pro ea propter Deum ex caritate. Pro monasterio Villariensi.
column18: In the year of our Lord 1476, this book was written by the hand of Sister Katherina Mast, nun of the monastery of Fessae in the valley of the duke. Pray for her for the sake of God out of charity. For the monastery of Villariensi.

column16: (77r) Qui me scribebat Elisabeth nomen habebat petit unum Ave Maria soror Susanna und (144v) Soror ELISABET DE SENGIN
column18: "(77r) The one who was writing me, Elisabeth, had the name. Pray one Ave Maria. Sister Susanna. And (144v) Sister ELISABET DE SENGIN."

column11: Salzburg, Diemuod (Sister Erzb. Konrad I, Salzburg)
column16:
Latin (Verse Colophon):
“Materia libri fecit Diemuod pia scribi.
Sancto Ruoberto celi pro munere certo.
Celestis vite scribant in ordine scribe.”
column18:
“The content of the book was caused to be written by the pious Diemuod,
As a sure offering to Saint Rupert of Heaven.
May the scribes be written in the ranks of heavenly life.”

column16: (Imago Adelhaidis quae codicem scripsit); Hernad 2000 p. 45 transcribes the text "Finis adest operis mercedem posco laboris. Et qui me scribebat Adelhaidis nomen habebat. Sanctus Bernhardus. Dominus noster Jhesus Christus ipse erit merces tua, fiat fiat." (144r); Adelhaid is before Hl. Bernhard.
column18: “The end of the work is here, I ask for the reward of my labor. And the one who wrote me had the name Adelhaid. Saint Bernard. Our Lord Jesus Christ himself will be your reward, let it be, let it be.”

column16: (1r) das ist der erst vnd scholt vorn styn (getilgt); (13r) dis ist der ander sechstern vund geho"rt nach dem hernach (405v) des puchs ist als XXXV sechstern. THOSE ARE STRUCTURAL COMMENTS, THE BOOK IS BOUND IN SEXTERNS. Colophon (405v): Das puch ward auSS geschriben an der helligen marter tag Johannes vnd Paulus tag als man zalt von Christus gepurt MCCCC. vnd ym L(X)XVII jar (erste X getilgt). Item das puch hot geschriben swester Hrabra Pfinczigin in Bilenrewt sancti Augustini ordinis regularium cananicarum czu lob vnd ere der ho"hsten trinitat vnd wer das nu"czt der gedenk ir gen got ym leben vnd todt was in got vermant etc.
column18:
(1r) This is the first and sold in the section (erased); (13r) This is the second section and follows from the next (405v) of the book, as it contains XXXV sections.

Colophon (405v): This book was completed on the feast day of the Holy Martyrs John and Paul, according to the reckoning from the birth of Christ, 1500, and in the year L(X)XVII (the first X erased). Furthermore, this book was written by Sister Hrabra Pfinczigin in Bilenrewt, of the Order of Saint Augustine, Regular Canons, for the praise and glory of the Most Holy Trinity, and for the remembrance of her and her service to God in life and death, may she be united with God, etc.

column8: Ms. Munich CLM 29400 / 8 Unidentified nun-scribe A, Chelles
column11: Written in Northeast France in the centre which produced the Cologne manuscripts of Augustine for Archbishop Hildebald (795–819), apparently the convent of Chelles. The fragment was used as a fly-leaf in a printed book (Asc. 837) which probably belonged to the small Augustinian house at Bernried in Bavaria: an entry saec. XVI referring to the obit of 'Johan Ducziner Brobst zu Berñriedt' (†15 August 1535) is seen on the recto.

column11:
Written by 3 scribes. The third of which copied ff.1-11 at the end of the 15th century to replace leaves that were either lost or mutilated. 
The first two scribes (fff; 12-117) signed and dated the codex on f.117r: John the Priest and his mother Zoe, 1257. There are additions in several later hands.

column11:
Written in Strasbourg by Sister Catherina INgolt of the convent of the Rewerin (s. Mary Magd.) for the use of the convent.
Previously recorded in the catalogues of colophons as: Univ. Libr. 6

Another manuscript produced in the same convent is Austin, University of Texas, Harry Ransom Research Center, HRC 114

Written for use in the convent of the Sorores poenitentes/Reuerinnen(St. Mary Magdelen) of Strasbourg; nr. 3329 in a catalogue; obtained in London, ca. 1927, by Mr. Acton Griscom; given to the library (1929) by a group of friends
column16: f.207v: Zu lobe und erwurdikeit des almehtigen gottes ouch umb willen eins gemeinen nutzes der andechtigen swester des ordens sant marie magdalene sust genant der orden der ruwerin So hat geschriben dis buechelin Katherina Ingolt ein swester des selben ordens und conuentes zu strossburg mit irer hant grossem ernst flis und arbeit und hat daz volbroht mit der hilff gottes uff sant Thiburcius und valerianus tag Anno domini M cccc lxxxv
column18: f.207v: “In praise and honor of Almighty God, and also for the common benefit of the devout sisters of the Order of Saint Mary Magdalene, also called the Order of the Penitents, this little book was written by Katherina Ingolt, a sister of this same order and convent in Strasbourg, with her own hand, with great diligence, effort, and labor. She completed it with God’s help on the feast day of Saints Tiburtius and Valerian, in the year of our Lord 1485.”

column16:
f.274v: Hier neempt eijnde dit boeck ghenoempt dat beelt der duechden ghemaeckt (...) duer den subtijlen ende verlichten doctoor bruer peete (sic) dore van Orliens vander predicaren oerdene. Ende nu overgheset uut Fransoijs int duijtschen int minderbrueren clooster tot Gorcum. 
Desen boeck heeft ons ghedaen te scrijven die Eerweerdighe heere Egidius seghers. den welcken selven eerweerdighen heere heeft dien ghetranslateert uut Fransoijs int duijtsche, ende es ghescreven van mij suster marie vander hochstadt voleijndt in die maent Junius Anno M vc ender lxvij Jhesu Maria. Anna.
flyleaf: tot behoef van convent te Cortenberch. (Other contemporary hand)
column18:
f.274 verso: Here ends this book called "The Image of Virtues" made (...) by the subtle and enlightened doctor Brother Peter of Orléans from the Dominican order. And now translated from French into Dutch in the Minorite Friars' monastery at Gorinchem.

This book was done to be written by the Reverend Sir Egidius Seghers. The same Reverend Sir himself translated it from French into Dutch, and it was written by me, Sister Marie van der Hochstadt, completed in the month of June in the year 1567, Jesus Maria. Anna.

Flyleaf: For the use of the convent at Cortenberch. (Another contemporary hand)

column11:
Bastarda script by 9 hands:
        1.        fols. 1r–48r, 48v–72r, 125r–131r: Cecilia Rotin (Schneider I, fig. 11)
        2.        fols. 48rv, 120r–124v, 144v–145r: probably Hand 1 (ibid., fig. 12)
        3.        fols. 60v, 72v, 131v–135r: Dorothea Schurstabin (ibid., fig. 9)
        4.        fols. 73r–112v
        5.        fols. 112v–119r: Barbara Rutzin (ibid., fig. 5)
        6.        fols. 131v–132r
        7.        fols. 136r–143r
        8.        fols. 146r–156v
        9.        fols. 145v, 157r–180r: Hand 3 (ibid., fig. 14)

Paper analysis by G. Piccard suggests the likely writing dates: fols. 1–156 between 1429–1432; fols. 157–180 between 1452–1455.

column11:
Composite Manuscript
Paper and parchment. 80 folios. 14 × 10.5 cm. Nuremberg. 15th century.
Fols. 1–33, 33a, 34–64, 64a, 65–78.
Parchment wrapper (coperta). Spine reinforcement in brown leather; formerly with ties and lead buttons.

Dialect: North Bavarian.
From the Nuremberg Katharinenkloster; ownership inscriptions on fols. 1v and 78v.
Formerly owned by Clara Imhoff (†1495; Würfel p. 49), see MBK III, 3, p. 589, lines 1–7.
In 1847 in the possession of Moritz Maximilian Maier (cf. Archiv der Gesellschaft für ältere deutsche Geschichtskunde 9 [1847], p. 551).
Fol. 1r: Aufseß stamp (Lugt 2749).

References: Fries p. 139; MBK III, 3, pp. 574; 589, lines 1–7.

⸻

I

Fols. 1–43 — Paper. Quires irregular. Writing space 8 × 6 cm. Bastarda script by 2 hands; fol. 33a is a later correction in the hand of Dorothea Schurstabin (Schneider I, fig. 9). Red headings. Majuscules stroked in red. Red Lombards.
Paper analysis by G. Piccard gives a likely writing period of 1425–1428.

1v Table of contents.
2r–5r Tobias Blessing. Printed in Anzeiger (loc. cit.), edited using this manuscript by Möllenhoff–Scherer, Denkmäler deutscher Poesie und Prosa, ³1892, no. XLVII,4, vol. 1, pp. 183–192; vol. 2, pp. 290–305.
5r–10v Another blessing (Ich gesegent mich heut mit guten stunden …), printed in Anzeiger (loc. cit.).
10v–12v Indulgence prayer (Hie vacht der himlisch konig …), promises 6,000 + 600 + 66 days’ indulgence from Pope Leo.
12v–21v Meditation on the 24 Hours of Christ’s Passion (Hie vacht daz leiden Jhesus Cristus …), structured by each hour from the Last Supper to the morning scourging; see T. Brandis, Der Harder, 1964, p. 98.
21v–35r Meditation on the 12 Hours of Christ’s Passion (Das sind die zwelff stund des tags …), structured from the morning councils of the bishops to the crucifixion.
35r–37v Prophetic sayings about Christ (Isaiah; Augustine).
38r–43v Marian Mass (Salve sancta parens).

⸻

II

Fols. 44–64a — Writing space 9.5 × 6.5 cm. 15–24 lines. Bastarda by 2 hands. Red introductions, majuscules stroked in red, 2–5 line red Lombards.
Paper analysis by G. Piccard: fols. 45–56 not before 1433; fols. 57 ff. not before 1440.

44 Blank.
45r–51r Marian prayer with 300-day indulgence (O du allermilczte fraw …).
51r–54r St. Peter’s Prayer (O her Jhesu Crist ein schopjfe (!) vnd ein erlosser der werlt …), with legend and spiritual benefit; found in the Liber Catagenum (see Kornrumpf p. 339).
54r–56r Marian prayer in verse with 20,000-day indulgence (O fraw vnd magt mynnecleich …); first 23 verses printed from this MS by Bartsch, Erlösung, p. 353L; also used by G. Milchsack, Unser vrouwen klage, PBB 5 (1878), pp. 193–357.
57r–63v Pseudo-Bernard of Clairvaux, Salve mundi salutare, German prose translation (O biß gegrußet Jhesu ein heyl der werlt …), ending … dich zu loben ymmer vnd ewiglich. Amen; Latin text PL 184, 1319ff.; same translation in Schneider I, p. 74.
64r–v Praise of Justice (verse: Gerechtikeit ist ein schacz vber alle gron …).

⸻

III

Fols. 65–78 — Parchment. Writing space 8.5 × 6 cm. 15–16 lines. Bastarda by 1 hand (possibly Kunigund Niklasin). Red introductions and headings. Two- to three-line red Lombards.

65r–78r Meditation on the Passion of Christ, with introduction citing Anselm (Interrogatio Anselmi), the Evangelium Nicodemi, and Birgitta. Begins: Do nu Judas aus gegangen was …; ends: … und wiß wie daz waz daz mich mein iungern niht mohten.
column26: Nuremberg, Dominican St. Katharina nunnery Germany Nuremberg

column11:
Indulgences for the Katharinenkloster – Statutes
Paper. 83 folios. 14.5 × 10.5 cm. 15th century.
Red parchment binding; front and back pastedowns are parchment leaves with Latin hymns in the hand of Kunigund Niklasin, 15th century.

From the Nuremberg Katharinenkloster; fol. 83r: Das gehen der priorin vnd swester Margret Karturserin vnd dem ganczen couent zu sant Katherina zu Nurinberg … (“The procession of the prioress and Sister Margret Karturserin and the entire convent of St. Catherine in Nuremberg …”).
Fol. 1r: Aufseß stamp (Lugt 2749).

Fries, p. 27 ff.

⸻

I

Fols. 1–72 – Nuremberg – Mid-15th century (1451–1452)
Sexternions. Writing space 10 × 7 cm. Bastarda script by several hands, including fol. 11v: Hand 13 of the Katharinenkloster (Schneider I, fig. 27); fols. 50v–57v and 69v–72r: Hand 9 (ibid., fig. 20).
Dialect: Nuremberg.
Paper analysis by G. Piccard suggests a likely writing period c. 1451/52.

1r–10v Indulgences granted by the pope found in the churches of the friars and sisters of the Dominican Order (Item den pebstlichen applas vint man in den kirchen …), ending: wer nit hot gelawben an den aplaß der wirt sein beraubt (“whoever does not believe in the indulgence will be deprived of it”).

10v–12v Prayers: “Each sister should recite daily with devotion the following prayers … O Lord Jesus Christ, may your mercy be always with us …” (Schneider I, p. 423); Almighty and merciful God, take me into your grace and forgive me all my sins …; “If you wish to gain the indulgence, say this prayer … Lord, I enter your house and pray in your holy temple, in the dwelling of eternal life, to be led there without intermediary. Amen.”

13r–60v Indulgences for the Katharinenkloster from the years 1286–1470 (cf. Fries, loc. cit.).
61–68 Blank.
69v–70r Report on an altar consecration in the Katharinenkirche, 22 August 1464.
71r–72r Notice of a further indulgence.

⸻

II

Fols. 73–83 – Schönensteinbach – Late 15th century (1470–1473)
One quire and an inserted loose bifolium (fols. 80–81), added after the book was bound. Bastarda script (to 79v) and Textura. Red headings and Lombards.
Dialect: Alsatian.
Paper analysis by G. Piccard suggests a likely writing period of 1470–1473.

73r–79v Statutes of the reformed Dominican nuns: “The following points are extracted from the Latin letters of privileges of the masters of the Order, in brief. Thus the masters have granted these ordinances and privileges to the sisters of the observance in the German lands …” ending: … what pertains to confession and lending they may, with gratitude, make good use of, etc.

80r Indulgence feasts in Schönensteinbach: “On the following high feasts one receives the great indulgence …”
80r–v Absolution formula: Forma absolucionis apena culpa atque plenarie remissionis omnibus sororibus monasterii Schönensteinbach … (“Formula of absolution from penalty and guilt, and of full remission, for all the sisters of the monastery of Schönensteinbach …”).

⸻

column16: f.Nach cristi gepurt 1452 Iar habent diss puch geschriben Swester Margaretha Imhof und Swester Margaretha Karteuserin zu nutz iren Kloster czu Sant Kathrein in Nurnberg. Prediger ordens. Pit got für sie.
column18: “After the birth of Christ in the year 1452, this book was written by Sister Margaretha Imhof and Sister Margaretha, a Carthusian, for the benefit of their monastery at St. Kathrein in Nuremberg, of the Order of Preachers. Pray to God for them.”

column16: f.1r: "Nach Christi gepurt M°CCCC° in dem LXIII iar hat diß boch geschriben swester Margareta Karteuserin zu nucz irem closter zu sant Katherina zu Nurmberg prediger ordens. Pit got fur sie.“
column18: f.1r: After the birth of Christ, in the year 1463, this book was written by Sister Margareta Kartheuserin, for the benefit of her convent of Saint Catherine in Nuremberg, of the Order of Preachers (Dominicans). Pray to God for her.

column11:
2 hands: 
1st hand: f.1ra–202ra,
2nd hand: f.205ra–307vb.
Later additions by two further hands:
1st: f.301r–v,
2nd: f.307vb–308ra.

On the inside of the front cover: a small parchment slip glued in, containing a table of contents written by Kunigund Niklasin, reading:
“Item in this book are found first the 24 harps… then about Saint Catherine of Siena.”

On f.1r: Swester Kungund Clos Schryberin (Sister Kunigund Clos, scribe); see also IV,6.

Brought into the convent by Kunigund Schreiberin (MBK III, 3, p. 615).

column11:
Two-column layout, book cursive script by various hands:
        1.        1r-54vb, 260ra-268vb: Hand of Kunigund Niklasin.
        2.        33ra-34rb, 102ra-117vb.
        3.        55ra-67vb, 81vb-82va, 153ra-166vb, 186ra-1862ra.
        4.        68r.
        5.        68va-81vb.
        6.        83ra-85rb, 219ra-232vb: Hand of Margareta, a Carthusian.
        7.        85rb-101vb, 186ra-218rb.
        8.        118ra-152vb: Hand of Barbara Rutzin.
        9.        233ra-246vb.
        10.        246vb-259vb.

Often written quire by quire; when one hand finishes, the remaining part of the quire is left blank or the blank f.s are cut out.

column64:
f.2rv = Register
f.3ra-334rb = Johannes Cassianus: 'Collationes patrum'

column11:
The ms. bore the signature E LXIII in Nuremberg's St. Catherine's Monastery .
Continuation in Nuremberg, Stadtbibl., Cod. Cent. V, 5
written in book cursive by the hand of Ursula Geiselherin; a second hand appears on f.s 185rb-189ra, 217vb-219rb; corrections and additions by a third hand.

Written by Ursula Geiselherin based on an exemplar from the Klarakloster (Poor Clares) in Nuremberg.

The exemplar is preserved in Berlin, germ. f.1276 (see Degering I, p. 171), formerly Cheltenham, Phillipps 19491 (see Priebsch, Deutsche Handschriften in England I (1896), p. 127, no. 131).

The copy made at the Katharinenkloster is in two volumes; Volume II = Cent. V, 5.

column11:
Parchment is used for f.s 1, 156-157, 230, 265-266, 277-278, and consistently for the outer double leaf of each quire.
cursive book script by three different hands:
        1.        f.s 7r-145v, 164r-225v, 227r-257v by Kunigund Niklasin.
        2.        f.s 2r-4v, 148r-158r, 171r-v, 226r-v, 230r-v, 258r-281v, and fragments at 5r and 289r by Klara Keiperin.
        3.        Later additions at the end of the 15th or early 16th century (282r after the text).

Copied by Kunigund Niklasin and Klara Keiperin from a book borrowed from the convent by a virgin named Anna Winterin, which was later passed to Margareta Scheurerin in Pforzheim.

Of the original three-volume work (previously signed E I–III), only this second volume has survived.

Keiperin hinten dorczu.

column11:
Contains addenda written on f.129v-131v in the monastery of St. Katharina Nuremberg, including a text on f.130-131v with a note by the Kunigund scribe
Is this Kunigund Niklasin?

Gothic cursive script by several hands:
	•	Hand 1: fols. 1r–93r and 127r–129v
	•	Hand 2: fols. 93r–124v
	•	Hand 3: f.129v
	•	Hand 4: fols. 130r–131v, the hand of the scribe Kunigund, as seen on f.131v:
“Küngünt Schreyberin scripsit do pit got für mit einem avemaria dez begert sy daz irgotgnedig sey.”
(“Küngünt the scribe wrote [this]; she asks God with a Hail Mary that He may be merciful to her.”)
Hands 3 and 4 are additions, written in the Katharinenkloster.
column16: f.131v: Küngünt Schreyberin scripsit do pit got für mit einem avemaria dez begert sy daz ir gotg nedig sey.
column18: "f.131v: Küngünt the scribe wrote this, pray to God for her with an Ave Maria as she desires that her needs be fulfilled by God."

column16:
148ra vnd durch meiner mü willen vnd arbaitt willen
wartt ich nicht anders Ions von den lewten neur allain daz si ir andechtige pet hincz dem aller-
parmherczigsten richter für mich vergiessen amen. Diez puch ist geschriben worden do man
czalt noch Xpi vnsers lieben herren gepurd M°CCCC° vnd in dem XXXVI jar an dem
nechsten mitwoch vor dem palmtag (28. März). Pitt got für die schreiberin die dicz puch
geschriben hat.
column18: “For the sake of my toil and effort, I ask nothing else from people except that they pour out their devout prayers to the most merciful judge on my behalf.Amen. This book was written in the year 1436 after the birth of Christ, our dear Lord, on the Wednesday before Palm Sunday (March 28). Pray to God for the female scribe who wrote this book.”

column18:
the front pastedown:
“In the year of our Lord 1462. This book belongs to the convent of St. Catherine in Nuremberg of the Order of Preachers, and it was written by Sister Kunigunde Holzschubin, a convent sister of the same house, for our convent, and she paid for the parchment and materials herself.Let all pray for her, whether she be living or dead, etc.”

column11:
Fols. 1r of Vol. 1 and f.4r of Vol. 2 decorated by the nun Barbara Gwichtmacherin from the Katharinenkloster (cf.Fischer, Buchmalerei, p. 74f., fig. 29; Schneider, op. cit., p. XXf.).
Comparative analysis of the remaining historiated initials suggests attribution to five different artists, though Fischer proposes only four illuminators (op. cit., p. 79f.).

column11:
•        The main section was written by a single hand: Margareta, the Carthusian (died 1489) (referenced in Würfel, p. 46, and MBK III, 3, p. 613).
        •        Additions by several other hands until around 1500.
	•	Nuremberg dialect with slight Alemannic influences (as Margareta had spent 1422–28 in Schönensteinbach, Alsace).

column11:
Bound together in the second half of the 15th century from parts of different origins.
Part 1: 2-25
Part 2: 25-208

Agnes Pabenbergerin, a member of the Katharinenkloster since 1428, moved to Tulln in 1436.

f.1v contains a table of contents by Klara Keiperin: “In this book there is first the Life of St. Margaret of Hungary, of the Dominican Order ... followed by the Passion of Christ and some general sermons.”
column16: f. 25r: Es ist zu wissen das die legend der heiligen wirdigen junckfrawn sant Margrethn nicht beslissung hat vmb des willen das si noch nicht erhaben ist ... Pittet got für vnsern erwirdigen getrewen liben vater vikari Jorg Valder der dise legend mit müe aus latein zu deüczsch pracht hat. Auch pitt ich euch mein allerherzigistn libsten muter vnd swester das ir got pittfür die schreiberinn s(wester) Agnes Pabnbergerin wann ich euch das mit ganzer begird meins herzen geschribn hab das ir mein dapei gedenkt zu got vnd der junckfrawn Maria mit einem avemaria. (Darunter von anderer Hand: gern gern.)
column18:
f. 25r:
It should be known that the legend of the holy, worthy virgin Saint Margaret has no conclusion, because she has not yet been elevated [to sainthood]…
Pray to God for our venerable, faithful, dear father, Vicar Jörg Valder, who with effort has brought this legend from Latin into German.
I also beg you, my most beloved mother and sister, to pray to God for the scribe, Sister Agnes Pabnbergerin, for I have written this for you with the whole desire of my heart, so that you may remember me before God and the Virgin Mary with an Ave Maria.
(Underneath, in another hand: Gladly, gladly.)

column16:
f. 179r: Anno domini M CCCC 18 in die sancti Stepfani (26. Dez.)
hora undecima vel quasi finivi. Pit got für den Schreiber mit einem pater noster vnd
avemaria das euch wol geling.
column18: f. 179r: In the year of our Lord 1418, on the feast of Saint Stephen (26 December), at the eleventh hour or thereabouts, I finished. Pray to God for the scribe with one Pater noster and one Ave Maria, so that all may go well for you.

Spiritual collective manuscript; in it, among other things:
f.1r-67v = Thomas Peuntner : 'Little Book of the Love of God' (2nd version) (N1)
f.75v-91r = Venturin von Bergamo : Letter to the sisters of the Benedictine monastery Comps
sheet 211r = 'The twelve councilors of Jesus Christ'
sheets 281r-291r = Johannes Vend : treatise for monastery women
sheets 292r-311r = Adolf von Essen : 'Our Virgin Wen Mariae Rosengertlin'
sheets 311v-313r = Dominic of Prussia : Rosary clauses

column11:
Parchment: 1, 180, 189-190, 198, 207-208, 219-220.
book cursive script by two different hands:
        1.        2r-24r and 180r-262r by the hand of Gertraud Tetzlin;
        2.        25r-179r by the hand of Klara Keiperin

On 1r, an old table of contents, but the texts listed there are now in a different order in the manuscript, and some are missing; the manuscript was later rebound:
	•	“Item in the book, first, many beautiful sermons on how one should adorn and prepare the heart for God” (now 180r-251r)
	•	“Item, how one should prepare oneself for the Holy Sacrament” (154r-179v)
	•	“Item, The Twelve Deaths” (25r-153v)
	•	“Item, Saint Bernardino’s sermon on the Passion of Christ”
	•	“Item, On the Ten Commandments” (now missing)
	•	“Item, finally, about a holy virgin named Lydeweyg” (252r-262r).

column16:
113r unter dem Text: 0 min ainigi vnd allergetrüwesti muter bitgotfür din trüws kind
S. Elizabet Munt(in) die dir dis vss gantzer trüw geschr(iben) haut u>ie wol die geschr(ift) bos ist so ist doch die
liebi gantz vnd gut.
column18:
f.113r (below the text):
        •        “O my unique and most faithful mother, pray to God for your faithful child S. Elisabeth Muntin, who has written this for you out of complete loyalty. Even if the writing is poor, the love is whole and good.”

column11:
copied book for sacristan Katharina von Mu"lheim
(Perhaps Katharina von Mühlheim, who was the first sacristan in 1428 after the Reform. Other sisters copied the manuscript). 
Written in cursive book hand by multiple scribes:
        1.        f.1r-7v
        2.        f.8v-260r
        3.        Additional supplements in numerous places by a younger hand.
column16:
8v: pittent got fu"r mich swester ku"sterin denn ich dise ding mit fleiss zusammengesucht han. Pittent auch fur die swester die in geschriben hat. 
On f.8: "Miner recht lieben sv .. svester M[a]rg[ret] V[er]nan zv/o/ sa[nt] Katrinen zu/o/ Nu/o/renber[g]." Margaretha Vernan kam 1428 aus Scho"nensteinbach, d. 1475
column18:
8v: May God have mercy on me, Sister Custodian, for I have diligently gathered these things. Also, may God have mercy on the sister who wrote it down. 
On f.8: “My very dear sister Margaretha Vernan, of Saint Catherine in Nuremberg.” Margaretha Vernan came from Schönensteinbach in 1428 and passed away in 1475.
column26: Nuremberg, Dominican St. Katharina nunnery Germany Nuremberg

Ott, hg. von Kristina Freienhagen-Baumgardt, Pia Rudolph und Nicola Zotz, Bd. 8,3/4 (Lektionar - Losbücher), München 2019, S. 436f.(Nr. 77.7.1.) und Abb. 133. [online] [PDF online] [zur Beschreibung]

Tauler: Sermons
1. fols. 3r–11r – Vetter no. 45
2. fols. 11r–16r – Vetter no. 3
3. fols. 16r–23v – Vetter no. 2
4. fols. 23v–30v – L 79
Not listed in Vetter; cf.Philipp Strauch, “Zu Taulers Predigten,” PBB 44 (1920), pp. 1–26.
5. fols. 30v–38r – Vetter no. 57
6. fols. 38r–41v – Vetter no. 14
7. fols. 41v–49r – Vetter no. 8
Here with different Gospel citation:
Si quis sitit veniat et bibat.
In this Gospel we read that there was a feast among the Jews…
8. fols. 49v–53r – Vetter no. 60 g
9. fols. 53r–64v – Vetter no. 60 h
Here in a more detailed version.
10. fols. 64v–70v – Vetter no. 66
11. fols. 70v–75r – Vetter no. 16

13. fols. 83r–88r – Vetter no. 41

15. fols. 89r–89v – Vetter no. 59 (On confession)

column10: De Hamel identified Mary Nevel's hand in this volume, but O'Mara disagrees with that identification
column11:
ff.29r-31r, 63r-79v, 149r-153r
This too casts some doubt over Mary as scribe here, unless she worked on manuscripts intended for sisters and brothers, which would be highly unusual. On balance my view is that Mary was not responsible for the parts of this manuscript highlighted by de Hamel, though the hand closely resembles hers. (O'Mara)

column16: Colophon, f.156v: "Era ’l sicondo di vespar sonato/ nel glorioso giorno che concepta/ fu l’umil Vergin sancta et benedecta/ per chui ’l primo peccar fu ristorato./ A octo giorni del mese ultimato la faticata penna asciutta et necta/ alquanto riposai et con herecta/ mente l’ora vigesima uscì dallato./ Sonavan gli anni del nostro signore/ cinque cinquanta quattrocento et mille/ quando Maria di Matheo cimatore/ finì copiare el testo et le postille/ di questo clar poeta almo, et de core/ che ’nfino al ciel mandò le sue faville./Laus Deo sit semper benedictus."
column18: "The second hour of the evening had sounded on the glorious day of the conception of the humble Virgin, holy and blessed, who was free from original sin. On the eighth day of the last month I gave some rest to my weary pen, dry and clean, and the twentieth hour came forth alongside with upright mind. The year of our Lord 1455 was sounding when Maria daughter of Matteo the cloth-shearer finished copying the text and commentary of this poet, renowned and noble, and with a heart that sent its sparks as far as heaven. Praise the Lord, may He always be blessed.", translated by B. Richardson, Women and the Circulation of Texts in Renaissance Italy (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2020), p 94

column10: This manuscript's script and decoration is very similar to the Chelles' manuscript of Köln, Erzbischöfliche Diözesan- und Dombibliothek, Cod. 63, 65, 67 (see E.A. Lowe, CLA, vol. 2, no. 238).
column11:
Can't be consulted (restricted)
Written in North-east France or possibly Cologne, as script and ornamentation in the type developed by the nuns of Chelles suggest; the MS has close affinity with the group of three MSS of St Augustine (Cologne, Dombibliothek 63, 65, 67) written by nuns for Hildebald, Archbishop of Cologne (785–819). Belonged to St Faron, Meaux, till the French Revolution, then to Gosselin, later to Remusat, at whose sale it was bought by Messrs Payne, the London booksellers, in 1833.

Extracted from the binding of an incunable (early printed book): a copy of Vincent of Beauvais, Speculum Historiale from the press of Johannes Mentelin, Strasbourg 1473 (now Douce 306).
Ziegler, Sakramentar Gelasianum, n. 18 associated them with Chelles, McKitterick argues they form a paleographical group with Bodleian, Vat. Reg. lat. 316 (R. McKitterick, 'Nuns' Scriptoria in England and Francia in the Eighth Century' Francia 19 (1992) 1–35 at p. 11)

column10: The roll was sent to 122 religious houses in the southern half of England, each writing an answer to a request for prayers made by Agnes, Prioress of Hedingham, for the soul of her predecessor Lucy.
Ascribed to Chelles by Bischoff, to Jouarre by McKitterick.
column11:
Can't be consulted (restricted)
At least fifteen hands.
(note: Jouarre was a double monastery, so these scribes could be women or men)
Origin North France, doubtless Chelles. The peculiar uncial and the decoration connect this MS with the group represented by the famous Sacramentary, Vatic. Regin. Lat. 316 (CLA 1.105). On f.1 is added in Anglo-Saxon script saec. VIII–IX Charlemagne's Letter to Abbot Baugulf of Fulda, and on f.260 a library catalogue, perhaps of Würzburg (see CLA plate). Belonged to St Kilian's of Würzburg certainly by the ninth century, as is shown by the entry on f.1v ('. . . faciat eum sancto Kiliano restitui'). The same page has the Würzburg ex-libris saec. XIII. Acquired by Archbishop Laud before 1638.
Ascribed to Chelles by Bischoff, to Jouarre by McKitterick.
column26: Chelles, Benedictine nunnery France Chelles or Jouarre

column16: « Explicit la benoites Passion de Nostre Seigneur Jhesu Crist, qui fut escripte et copulée l'an de graice Nostre Seigneur M IIIIc IIIIxx et VI, le jour de feste saint Gregoire, a la louuange (sic) et a l'asaucement du hault nons de Jhesus, et pour bien, profit et augmentaction de l'ame et du corps de très excellant et nobles dame Ysabiaulz de Croy, escripte par ma propre mains, suer Barbe Wyesse, religieuse indigne du couvent de Sainte Clare, cituée au Nuefchastelz, en Lorraine. » f.138v
column18: "Here ends the blessed Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ, which was written and completed in the year of the grace of Our Lord 1496, on the feast day of Saint Gregory, to the praise and exaltation of the high name of Jesus, and for the well-being, profit, and enhancement of the soul and body of the most excellent and noble lady Ysabiaulz de Croy, written by my own hands, Sister Barbe Wyesse, unworthy nun of the convent of Saint Clare, situated in Neufchâteau, Lorraine." column11:
f.36v
Le ms. Français 1176 est un des vingt-cinq manuscrits entièrement copiés de la main de Christine de Pizan. Selon l’ Album Christine de Pizan, ce manuscrit est le plus ancien témoin du texte, daté de 1405. 

Corrections de la main de Christine de Pizan : additions indiquées dans la marge et rapportées dans l'interligne (f.58) ; additions avec signes de renvoi (f.20v, 43, 63) ; au f.76, préparation de la rubrique en écriture cursive. Nombreux mots, souvent déjà exponctués, barrés de rouge. Au verso de la 3e garde de parchemin, table de l'ouvrage ajoutée à l'encre rouge de la main de l'auteur.

Selon Christine Reno et Inès Villela-Petit, ce manuscrit serait une commande du duc de Berry et l’Epitre à la reine ne figurait pas dans le projet initial. L'Epitre à la reine a été identifié comme un autographe par Charity Cannon Willard.
column16: « A tres excellent Redoubtee & puissant et tres princesse. Ma dame ysabel Royne de France ...- ... Escript le ve jour d'octombre. l'an de grace mil iiij C et/ cinq. Vostre treshumble obeissant Creature/ cristine de Pizan. Prennez en gré s'il vous plaist cest escript / De ma main fait aprés mienuit une heure / Noble seigneur pour qui je l'ai escript / Prennez en gré / Quant vous plaira mieulz vous sera rescript / Mais n'avoye nul autre clerc a l'eure / Prennez en gré s'il...» (f.53r)
column18:
f.53r: “To the most excellent, revered, powerful, and most noble princess,
My lady Isabel, Queen of France…

Written on the eve of October, in the year of grace 1405.

Your most humble and obedient servant,
Christine de Pizan.

Please accept this writing, if it pleases you,
Made by my own hand after midnight, at one o’clock.
Noble lord, for whom I have written it,
Please accept it.
When it pleases you, it can be copied more finely.
But I had no other clerk at the time—
Please accept it…”

column18:
f.53r: To the most excellent, revered, powerful and very noble princess, my lady Ysabel, Queen of France…
Written on the 5th day of October, in the year of grace 1405. Your very humble, obedient servant, Christine de Pizan.

Please receive this writing kindly, if it pleases you /
Written by my own hand at one hour past midnight /
Noble lord for whom I wrote it /
Please receive it kindly /
When you wish, it shall be rewritten better /
But I had no other clerk at the time /
Please receive it kindly…

column11: Les manuscrits de Christine de Pizan ont été écrits par trois mains bien reconnaissables : P, R et X (Christine de Pizan elle-même). Le ms Français 835 a été transcrit, dans sa majeure partie par R, identifié à P. de Cruce : cf.Delsaux, « Profil d’un copiste des manuscrits originaux de Christine de Pisan : P. de La Croix, alias la main R », article à paraître dans Scriptorium. P a copié les ff.441vb, l. 26 à 44vb. La main X a fait quelques corrections : mouche ou restauration sur laquelle l’auteur a réécrit, à l’encre noire, les mots manquants au f.100 : cf.G. Ouy et C. Reno, « Identification des autographes de Christine de Pizan », dans Scriptorium, 34, 1980, p. 221-238.

column11: Hugo Ripelin, Compendium theologicae veritatis, written between the lines and on the margins of a codex containing biblical texts from the 12th century. The space intended for the gloss, which was left blank, was occupied by the new text. The dimensions of the manuscript (ff.195) are 320x215 mm, the space for the original text is 208x90 mm for 18 lines on a full page. Many of the sheets were partially cut, presumably to make parchment. In 1354, before the new text was added, the codex had belonged to Nicasius, curate of 'Casiacum' (Chezy-sur-Marne, Aisne), as can be deduced from the ex libris on f.195v.The manuscript was later transferred to Saint-Germain-des-Prés (ex libris of the 16th century on f.195v and of the 18th century, with the signature 116, on the unnumbered sheet preceding f.1).
column16: Explicit compendium theologice virtutis (sic). Deo dicimus gratias. Scriptum per Henrietam anno Domini M°CCCLVI (the name and date are difficult to read due to ink smudges). Another mention of the copyist, in her own hand, is found in the upper margin of f.1r: Perscriptum a Henrieta de Lathilliaco, anno LV (not a clear reading), iovis post festum beati Luce (22 October 1355). The reasons for the transcription are explained on the same f.1r:Incipit compendium theologie sancti Thome de Aquino, hic subscriptum interlineariter, ne pargamenum sit occiosum.
column18:
Explicit Compendium Theologicae Virtutis (sic). We give thanks to God. Written by Henrietta in the year of our Lord 1356 (the name and date are difficult to read due to ink smudges).

Another mention of the copyist, in her own hand, is found in the upper margin of f.1r: Written by Henrietta of Lathilliaco, in the year 55 (not a clear reading), on Thursday after the feast of Saint Luke (22 October 1355).

The reasons for the transcription are explained on the same f.1r: Here begins the Compendium of Theology by Saint Thomas Aquinas, transcribed here interlinearly, so that the parchment may not remain idle.

Codex Pithou
Provient peut-être de l'église du Mans
Written in North France, probably in the convent that produced the three Cologne manuscripts written by nuns for Archbishop Hildebald of Cologne (785–819) and also the Paris manuscript Lat. 18282 (CLA 5.674). Belonged to Pithou whose autographed notes are in the manuscript. Later the property of Colbert in whose collection it was number 1863, and number 3887.14.14 in the Royal collection.

column11:
Des annotations et corrections interlinéaires sans doute de la main de la copiste : f.4r, 5r, 33r-34r, 39r, 42r, 44r, 46v-54r ; et d’autres mains : f.41r-43v, 47r-47v. Des annotations marginales de diverses mains : au f.1r, la cote Colbert, la cote Regius répétée deux fois, la cote actuelle, une ligne d’un chant religieux (« Nunctio uere quia misit dominus angelimi »), et des neumes (orisci catalans et neumes aquitains ; on en trouve aussi au f.54v) ; d’autres annotations à connotation religieuse sont à noter aux f.6r, 42v et 54v ; un certain nombre d’annotations sont illisibles ou effacées (f.11r, 22r, 40r et 54r) ; on peut également mentionner un astérisque au f.45r, un « y » au f.49r et, d’une main moderne, « 307 » sur le f.54v. 
Comme l’indiquent C. Jeudy (1974, p. 129-130) et B. Bischoff (2014, p. 128-129) dans leur notice respective, le manuscrit a été copié dans le troisième quart du IXe siècle en France, dans un scriptorium d’influence insulaire, par une copiste du nom d’Eugenia, qui donne son nom dans une souscription rédigée en lettres grecques (mais en langue latine) au f.54r (voir H. OMONT, 1905, p. 15 pour la transposition). Il a peut-être été copié dans le Sud de la France ou en Catalogne, ou du moins s’y est trouvé très vite après sa copie, car la main légèrement postérieure à la première (fin du IXe siècle) qui ajoute les carmina des f.54r et 54v est caractérisée par des traits wisigothiques et des neumes d’Aquitaine et orisci catalans ont été notés sur les f.1r et 54v vers la même période.

Excerpta et regular de re grammatica
f.73-117. [Commentum in secundam partem Doctrinalis Alexandri de Villa Dei] : « Iste liber secundus sequitur librum primum …Hic iubet ordo libri vocum regimen reserari… -…nos perducat Jhesus Marie filius in secula seculorum benedictus ». — F.118-126. [Regula Dominus quae pars]: « Dominus que pars. Nomen. Quare. Quia significat…- ut in Donato ». — f.126v-130. [De constructione] : « Prima regula congruitatum est ista…-… Verbum multociens substantivum petis extra. » — f.130-136v. [De constructione] : « Sortes currit. Sortes est nominativi casus…-…citra mare dicere possum ». — f.137v-139v. Schémas et notes. — f.144-154v. [De constructione] : « Quando negativum etc. quando obliquus negativus construitur ….-…et ab his saturnalibus ». —

column16: f.144vB in hand of Raffaella: “Finito è il presente libro scripto per mano d’una monacha indegnamente consecrata nel monasterio del Paradiso, il cui nome sia scripto nel libro della vita, a dì quatordici di dicenbre M CCCC LXXVII. A llaude (et) gloria della somma (et)d eterna sapientia. Deo gratias. Poi ch’ài letto il libro (et) la visione coll’altre cose che qui sono scripte priega per me misera, peccatore. Dà il cuore a Dio intero (et) non diviso se gustar vuogli questo libro sancto (et) rendilo al monasterio del Paradiso”
column18: f.144vB, in the hand of Raffaella: "Finished is this present book written by the hand of a nun, unworthily consecrated in the monastery of Paradiso, whose name is written in the book of life, on the fourteenth day of December 1477. To the praise and glory of the highest and eternal wisdom. Thanks be to God. After you have read the book and the vision with the other things written here, pray for me, a miserable sinner. Give your heart entirely to God if you wish to taste this holy book, and return it to the monastery of Paradiso."

column16: Colophon f.118r (end of Augustine's Rule) lists eleven nuns and their confessor; 'Dit sijn der gheender namen die dit boexsken ghescreven hebben uut caritaten. Ons eerweerdighe pater heer Philips Nycholaes god sij sijn loen. Suster Beatrix Noeys, suster Margarete Bont, suster Janne van den Velde, suster Marie van Hansbeke, suster Katherie Tymmermans, suster Maria Meerts, suster Margarete Joerdaens, suster Janne Colijns, suster Anne Joerdaens, suster Rijckmoet van Zelken, suster Maergarete van den Rade. Int boeck des levens sij haerder alder name'. Free Library catalogue entry mentions 13 hand changes, but the last hand change covers the sermon (which may not be covered by the colophon)
column18:
Colophon f.118r (end of Augustine's Rule) lists eleven nuns and their confessor; "This is the list of those whose names have written this booklet out of charity. Our honorable father, Mr. Philips Nycholaes, may God be his reward. column10: Colophon and Identification of scribe by Peter Kidd
column16: "Qui me scribebat nome(n) katherina mast habebat. Premia scriptricis. sint vite dona p(er)he(n)nis"
column18: "The one who was writing me had the name Katherina Mast. May the rewards of the writer be the gifts of eternal life."
column26: Val-le-Duc, Cistercian abbey of Villers Belgium Liège?

column4: Philadelphia, University of Pennsylvania, Oversize Ms. Codex 255
column11: Written in a formal book script (f.1r-1v) by one hand that breaks off abruptly, with the text beginning again in a later semi-cursive humanistic script by a second hand. Works 2-6 begin with a few words in a larger, Gothic script. The sixth work has many corrections in another hand.;
column26: Verona, Santo Spirito Italy Verona
column62: Melissa Moreton, '"Scritto di bellissima lettera": nuns' book production in fifteenth and sixteenth-century Italy and sixteenth-century Italy', PhD dissertation, University of Iowa, 2013.
column64: [Italian religious miscellany]vita di S. Giochino, vita della vergine Teodosia, il pianto della Vergine, text by S. Tomaso d'Aquino

column16: f.184v-185r: "Completus est iste libellus orarius anno domini M cccc lxxviii ipso die Sancti Ambrosii episcopi. Quem scripsit Soror Wendelmodis Roltemans ad instanciam carissime neptis eius Leve Ter Bruggen honeste matrone. Et Soror Agnes Martini illuminavit. Sancti moniales monasterii ordinis sancti Benedicti ad Sanctam Katharinam In Syloe prope Groenyncgen Urbem inclitam et opulentam in frysia. Eundem orarium prefata Leve Ter Bruggen tamquam entenium[?] memorabile propinando dedit illustri et honesto viro Johanni De Valle rosarum Alias Vanden Roesendael"
column18: f.184v-185r: "This little prayer book was completed in the year of our Lord 1478, on the very day of Saint Ambrose the Bishop. It was written by Sister Wendelmodis Roltemans at the request of her dear niece Leve Ter Bruggen, an honorable matron. And Sister Agnes Martini illuminated it. The holy nuns of the monastery of the Order of Saint Benedict at Saint Catherine in Syloe, near the renowned and prosperous city of Groningen in Friesland. The aforementioned Leve Ter Bruggen, as a memorable gift, gave this prayer book to the illustrious and honorable man John of the Valley of Roses, also known as Vanden Roesendael."
column19: Selwerd bij Groningen, Benedictijnen en Benedictinessen St.Catharina
column26: Selwerd bij Groningen, Benedictijnen en Benedictinessen St.Catharina Netherlands Groningen

column16: f.171: Amen. Dyss puch ist geschriben und volendt am abent des heiligen apostel und ewang. Mathei als man zalt nach Cristi gepurt unssers lieben herrn 1517 iar. Pytt got fur die schreiberyn swester Appolonia Polanderijn
column18: f.171: Amen. This book was written and completed on the evening of the Holy Apostle and Evangelist Matthew, as one counts from the birth of Christ our Lord in the year 1517. May God grant for the scribe, Sister Appolonia Pollanderin.
column62: Saint-Benoît de Port-Valais (Abbey : Bouveret, Switzerland). Colophons de Manuscrits Occidentaux Des Origines Au XVIe Siècle. Fribourg: Suisse, Éditions universitaires, 1965.

column16: f.312v: ...geschriben und vollendt mit der hilff Gotes am obent des heiligen Erczengels sant Michaelis als man schreib nach Cristi unssers lieben herren gepurt 1500 und in dem 14 jar... pit got fur die letzte schreiberin Appolonia Pollanderin... die ewigen seligkeit. Amen.
column18: f.312v: …written and completed with God’s help on the feast of the Holy Archangel Saint Michael, as one writes after the birth of our Lord Jesus Christ in the year 1500, and in the 14th year… May God grant the eternal bliss to the last scribe, Appolonia Pollanderin… Amen.
column26: Clarrissenkl. Eger.
column62: Saint-Benoît de Port-Valais (Abbey : Bouveret, Switzerland). Colophons de Manuscrits Occidentaux Des Origines Au XVIe Siècle. Fribourg: Suisse, Éditions universitaires, 1965.

column16: Dycz puch ist volent wurden an unser heylygen muter und haubtfrawen sant Claren tag, als sy erhebt ist wurden von einer swesster irs ordens. Got geb ir und uns all dy ewygen freud und das ewyg vaterlant, do alle wun und frewd ist an endt. Amen. (CMO 21732, Cmo VI/312)
column18: This book was completed on our holy mother and lady, Saint Clare’s day, when she was elevated, by a sister of her order. May God grant her and all of us eternal joy and the eternal homeland, where all joy and happiness end. Amen.

column4: Prague University, DH 140 s. 15-16 f.141v; cf ibid DH 147. (DS says Praha Národní Knihovna XVI.G.18)
column6: DH 140 s. 15-16 f.141v; cf ibid DH 147. (DS says Praha Národní Knihovna XVI.G.18)
column16: ... amen. amen. Margaretha von Schonbergk hat diss geschriben mit yrer lyncken hant. nemet vor gut libe Swester Juliana und bittet och got vor mich. amen.
column18: … amen. amen. Margaretha von Schönbergk has written this with her left hand. She asks for the good sister Juliana and also prays to God for me. amen.
column62: Saint-Benoît de Port-Valais (Abbey : Bouveret, Switzerland). Colophons de manuscrits occidentaux des origines au XVIe siècle. Vol. 4. Fribourg, Suisse, Editions universitaires, 1965. http://archive.org/details/colophonsdemanus0004sain.

column16: Wer disses puchlein vint der geb es durch got wider swester Angnes Keisserin oder swester Yrsala Wickersteterin der es auch peider ist. (f.99). Disse vorgeschriben predig hat uns swester Margaretta Gruntherin aptesin sant clar ordens von Nurnberg geschikt und begert von einer iden swester. einen. pater noster und ein ave maria der heiligen schar. das sie got fur sie piten. (f.127). Amen. Pitt got fur mich aller liebsten swester. (f.323).
column18:
Whoever finds this little book, may they give it through God’s mercy to Sister Agnes Keisserin or Sister Yrsala Wickersteterin, who are both of them. (f.99).

This prescribed sermon was sent to us by Sister Margaretta Gruntherin, Abbess of the Order of Saint Clare of Nuremberg, who requested from a certain Sister a Pater Noster and an Ave Maria for the holy assembly, that she might pray to God for her. (f.127).

Amen. May God pray for me, my dearest sister. (f.323).
column19: Nuremberg, Poor Clare Monastery of St. Klara

column16: Wer disses puchlein vint der geb es durch got wider swester Angnes Keisserin oder swester Yrsala Wickersteterin der es auch peider ist. (f.99). Disse vorgeschriben predig hat uns swester Margaretta Gruntherin aptesin sant clar ordens von Nurnberg geschikt und begert von einer iden swester. einen. pater noster und ein ave maria der heiligen schar. das sie got fur sie piten. (f.127). Amen. Pitt got fur mich aller liebsten swester. (f.323).
column18:
Whoever finds this little book, may they give it through God’s mercy to Sister Agnes Keisserin or Sister Yrsala Wickersteterin, who are both of them. (f.99).

This prescribed sermon was sent to us by Sister Margaretta Gruntherin, Abbess of the Order of Saint Clare of Nuremberg, who requested from a certain Sister a Pater Noster and an Ave Maria for the holy assembly, that she might pray to God for her. (f.127).

Amen. May God pray for me, my dearest sister. (f.323).

column16: Hie ist ein end der regel sant Clarn swester. Regula te salvat, si servas que tibi narrat. Ein Swester die regel geschriben hat, da man zalt von cristus 1505 iar, geendet an sant Erhardi des heiligen pishoff, in Convent in Eger
column18: Here is the end of the rule of the Saint Clare sisters. The rule saves you, if you keep what it tells you. A sister wrote the rule, in the year 1505 after the birth of Christ, finished on Saint Erhard’s Day, at the Holy Bishop’s, in the convent in Eger.

column11: Lana dei Galvagni is not self-identified as a nun – but the contents of the ms. point to that conclusion – especially the “Regula perfecte religionis”. It was sent to a “Fra Giustino romano cappuccino predicatore” from Venice (f.218r). Lana states her name as “Lana de Galvagni fiola che fu de miser zan Bertolameo” (f.219v) – is this the Venetian Zuan? If so, this would again point to its production as Venetian. Lana wrote “Franciscus et Claram” on f.219v – was she possibly from a house of Clarissans? The ms. came from the Augustinian convent of Gesù e Maria in Rome
column16: f.219v, written on a fragment in Lana’s hand: “Franciscus / et Claram” centered, then below, “Questo libro si è scrito per mane/ de Lana de i Galvagni,/ fiola che fu de miser zan / Bertolameo. (Iesu) Maria.”
column18: "Francis / and Clare" centered, then below, "This book was written by the hand of Lana de i Galvagni, daughter of the late Sir Zan Bertolameo. Jesus Mary."

f.179v: Finitus Anno Millesimo quadringentesimo lxxix. Per manu sororis Diewaris peregrini in festo sancti willibrordi confessoris. Et maxima pars scripta est in celebribus festis Orate pro ea. 
f.(garde): Liber magistri garlaci de scoten ad usum aduarie pauli monialis in beverwijck ad eiusdem vitam a prefato magistro aduarie concessus cum parte estivali etc.
column18:
f.179 verso: Finished in the year one thousand four hundred seventy-nine. By the hand of Sister Diewaris Peregrini on the feast of Saint Willibrord, confessor. And the majority of it was written on celebrated feast days. Pray for her.

Guard f.: The book of Master Garlacus de Scoten for the use of Sister Pauli, nun in Beverwijck, granted by the aforementioned Master Garlacus for her life, with the summer part, etc.

column16: Item der tracktat ist zu taucz gemacht vnd verpracht von der erwirdigen frumen frawen vnd swester vrsula Saczenhoferin dy vor zeiten ain chlosterfraw ist gewesen zu regenspurg in dem chloster nidern munstern zu Sant erhart vnd dar nach sich hat geben durch gottes willen vnter dy gehorsam des erwirdigen herrn herrn vnd vater in got abbt Rueprecht chauczel zu Sant peter zu salczpurg." AQI St Peter Catalog 1982 p. 290.
column18: Furthermore, the tractate was presented and handed over by the venerable and pious lady and sister Ursula Saczenhoferin, who in the past had been a nun in Regensburg at the Niedermünster convent dedicated to Saint Erhart, and later, through God’s will, placed herself under the obedience of the venerable lord and father in God, Abbot Rueprecht Chauczel, at Saint Peter’s in Salzburg.

column16: 128r–v Kolophon. Dis büchlin wart geendet durch mich schwester Dorothea Schermanyn in dem closter Gnodental in der stat Baszel sant Claren ordens der observantz uff vigilia visitacionis Marie virginis anno im xvc xv und gehört der geistlichen und andechtigen schwester Anna Lowlin ouch in Gnodental und begert dz sy got für sy well bitten umm ein gůt selig end.
column18: "Colophon: This little book was completed by me, Sister Dorothea Schermanyn, in the Cloister of Gnodental in the city of Basel, of the Order of St. Clare of the Observance, on the Vigil of the Visitation of the Virgin Mary in the year 1515. It belongs to the spiritual and devout Sister Anna Lowlin, also in Gnodental, and she desires that you pray to God for her for a good and blessed end."

column11:
Lecture en allemand des Evangiles et des Epîtres selon l’année liturgique (Proprium de tempore, Proprium de sanctis et Commune sanctorum) en provenance du couvent des dominicaines de Sainte-Catherine de Saint-Gall, copiée d’après un modèle du couvent des dominicaines de Sainte-Catherine de Nuremberg en 1483 par Elisabeth Muntprat, une des copistes les plus actives de ce couvent de femmes. 

SEE: PXL_20231003_193945245.jpg
column16: f.304: Explicit Liber iste. Dis bůch ist volendet vnd geschriben von der gnad gocz durch Schwoͤster Elizabeth Muntpratin zů Sant Katherina prediger ordens an aller hailgen Octaaf in dem iar da man zalt nach der gebůrt Jhesu christi MoCCCCo lxxxiij iar bittend gott fv́r die schriberin des begert sy von ganczem. herczen lebind vnd todt,
column18: "Here ends this book. This book was completed and written by the grace of God by Sister Elizabeth Muntpratin of St. Catherine of the Dominican Order, on the Octave of All Saints in the year of our Lord 1483. She prays to God for the scribe, who desires this from the bottom of her heart, living and dead."

column11:
Dorothea von Hof (1458-1501)
Dorothea ( Dorathe ) von Hof (born 1458, last mentioned in 1483), who was close to the St. Gallen Dominican Sisters , aged 16 in 1474 with a J erg (Georg von Hof?) married, 1477 conventual of a monastery that is not known with certainty, perhaps the St. Catherine's Monastery in St. Gallen, of which she is a possible patron
column16: f.221r: Anno domyny M cccc lxxxiij Jar han ich dorathe Von hoͮf dis buͦch vß geschriben Am naͤchsten tag nach sant vͦrlrichs [sic] tag Liebe u̍berwint alle ding D. V. H.
column18: "f.221r: Anno Domini 1483, I, Dorothea von Hof, wrote this book on the day after Saint Ulrich's Day. Love overcomes all things. D.V.H."

column11: Manuscrit composite du XVe siècle, en provenance du couvent dominicain Sainte-Catherine à Saint-Gall. Le codex composé de cinq fascicules reliés, en langue allemande, contient en plus d'un traité sur la Passion (« Les quarante bouquets de myrrhe de la Passion du Christ »), l'histoire de la fondation du couvent dominicain de Sainte-Catherine à Diessenhofen, le livre des sœurs de Diessenhofen et de Tösser, les légendes d'Elisabeth de Hongrie, de Marguerite de Hongrie, d'Ida de Toggenburg et de Louis de Toulouse, ainsi qu'un court extrait du Liber specialis gratiae de Mechthild von Hackeborn en traduction allemande. (fas)

column16: Diss buchly ward uss geschriben und volendet an dem abent unsers vatters s. Ludwicus barfussen orden (d)a m(an) z(a"hlt) n(ach) d(er) g(eburt) ch(risti) 1400 un in dem 98 ior. Biten got fu"r die schriberin mit ain Ave Maria. (CMO)
column18:
This book was written by me, Katheryna von [possibly Dienes?] Remchingen, professed at the convent of Frauenalb, and completed on the day that also happened to be the feast of Saint Mark the Evangelist, in the year counted as 1518.
For God’s sake, I ask: when I am dead, remember me in this, and in all goodness.

column16: f.106v: Soror Jutta de alfter persoluit istum librum cum suis expensis et elemosynis. Orate pro ea et pro quibus intendit deuote et soror lorra de specula perfecit scribendo liniando notando illuminando quam non excludatis ex cordibus vestris nex non ex oracionibus vestris deuotis anno domini mcccl maximam pestilencia ubique existente.
column18: “f.106v: Sister Jutta of Alfter paid for this book with her own expenses and alms. Pray for her and for those for whom she devoutly intends [her prayers], and Sister Lorra of Spiegel completed it by writing, ruling, noting, and illuminating. Do not exclude her from your hearts nor from your devout prayers, in the year of our Lord 1350, when the great pestilence was raging everywhere.”
column26: Cologne, Poor Clares Saint Klara Germany Cologne
