column11: The main scribe Magdalena Panholczin and a second scribe also named Magdalene, are both mentioned in damaged text on f 360r.
column16:
f.325: Die episteln hat zu dewchs gemacht der erwiendig geistleich herr maister hans amman aus der weissen aw pey rafelspuerkch den geistleichen jankchfrawn vnd swestern zu den himelparten zu wienn da er dann prior ist gewesen mer dann xx jar dem fot genedig sey. Vnd die episteln hat nach im abgeschriben swester magdalena die got der almochtig vnd sein liebe mueter maria haben in itt huet.
f.360: Anno domini tausent cccc vnd im lxviii jar an vnser lieben frawn tag concepcionis in dem aduent ist das puech aus geschriben warden ist das puech aus geschriben warden vnd gehert zu den himelparten in das klaster zu wienn vnd hat geschriben swester magdalena panholezin. Pitt got für sey mit ainem aue maria. Deo gracias.
column18:
f.325:
“The Epistles were translated by the venerable and spiritual Master Hans Amman from Weissenau near Rafelspuerkch for the spiritual virgins and sisters at the Himmelspforten convent in Vienna, where he served as prior for more than twenty years. May God be gracious to his soul. The Epistles were later copied by Sister Magdalena, whom Almighty God and His beloved Mother Mary hold in their care.”

f.360:
“In the year of our Lord 1468, on the Feast of the Conception of Our Lady, during Advent, this book was completed. It belongs to the Himmelspforten convent in Vienna and was written by Sister Magdalena Panholezin. Pray to God for her with an Ave Maria. Thanks be to God.”
column26: Vienna, monastery Himmelpfort Austria Vienna

column16:
f.325: Die episteln hat zu dewchs gemacht der erwiendig geistleich herr maister hans amman aus der weissen aw pey rafelspuerkch den geistleichen jankchfrawn vnd swestern zu den himelparten zu wienn da er dann prior ist gewesen mer dann xx jar dem fot genedig sey. Vnd die episteln hat nach im abgeschriben swester magdalena die got der almochtig vnd sein liebe mueter maria haben in itt huet.
f.360: Anno domini tausent cccc vnd im lxviii jar an vnser lieben frawn tag concepcionis in dem aduent ist das puech aus geschriben warden ist das puech aus geschriben warden vnd gehert zu den himelparten in das klaster zu wienn vnd hat geschriben swester magdalena panholezin. Pitt got für sey mit ainem aue maria. Deo gracias.
column18:
f.325:
“The Epistles were translated by the venerable and spiritual Master Hans Amman from Weissenau near Rafelspuerkch for the spiritual virgins and sisters at the Himmelspforten convent in Vienna, where he served as prior for more than twenty years. May God be gracious to his soul. The Epistles were later copied by Sister Magdalena, whom Almighty God and His beloved Mother Mary hold in their care.”

f.360:
“In the year of our Lord 1468, on the Feast of the Conception of Our Lady, during Advent, this book was completed. It belongs to the Himmelspforten convent in Vienna and was written by Sister Magdalena Panholezin. Pray to God for her with an Ave Maria. Thanks be to God.”

f.156v: Thenna bok laeth systher aelseby giordz dotter skriffwa aat conuentenne tha hon war swmma cantrix wppa thz perman som köptis for thz silff baeltet som henna modhersysther hustru cristin biörn nielsons gaff ther til thz war swa goth som xxiiij mark hwilkin bok skriffwen war aff enne conwentz syster som war anno domini m dij i them tima war kaera modher syster anna fickonis war abbatissa gudhi til hedhers oc jdher allom minom kaera systrom til andelikin hugnat.
column18:
“This book was written by Sister Katerina Gudhmundi and Sister Anna Girmundi, each for their half share.
f.156v: This book was commissioned by Sister Elseby, the daughter of Gyrd, for the convent when she was serving as the cantor. It was written on parchment purchased with the silver belt gifted by her maternal aunt, Mistress Kristin Björn Nielson, which was valued at 24 marks. This book was written by a sister of the convent in the year of our Lord 1502, during the time when our beloved Mother Sister Anna Fickonis was abbess, to the honor of God and for the spiritual benefit of all my dear sisters.”

column16: f.164: Thaenna firescripna book waende war kaere fadher ok brodher haer mathias laurencii conwaendz brodher j wastztenom aff latino ok j swaensko mz storom kaerlek ok jnnerlikom godh wilia gudhi til hedhers ok jomfru mario ok allom os til hwgnadh ... Bidhin thy kaera systra for honom ... Bidhin ok jaemwael for ware kaere modher syster margarete clawissa dotther abdissa som thenna bokena laet waendha at hon matte triffwas j allo godho swa wael likamlika som andelika.
column18: “f.164: This aforementioned book was translated by our dear father and brother, Brother Matthias Laurencii, a convent brother at Vadstena, from Latin into Swedish with great love and heartfelt goodwill, to the honor of God, the Virgin Mary, and for the benefit of us all. … Dear sisters, pray for him … And also pray for our dear mother, Sister Margareta Clawisdotter, abbess, who had this book translated, that she may thrive in all goodness, both physical and spiritual.”

column11:
Anna Karlsdotter (d. before 1450), anglicized as Anna Charles in the Syon Martyrology (London, British Library, MS Additional 22285), who was responsible for a Latin and Swedish prayer-book (Stockholm, Kungliga bibliotheket, MS A82a), as brought to light by Claes Gejrot.6 Given that she was one of the four professed sisters who came from Vadstena to help establish Syon, it would be easy to conclude that later English postulants learnt something about manuscripts from Anna and perhaps her fellow Swedes, but there is no proof.


        1.        Hand 1: (Later addition?) Schedula in cursive script.
        2.        Hand 2: (Later addition?) Schedula in cursive script, f.5v (textualis).
        3.        Hand 3: Fols. 1r–3v, likely also 6r–13v, and possibly 53r–103r (textualis).
        4.        Hand 4: Likely 13v–25r and possibly 53r–103r (textualis).
        5.        Hand 5: Likely 25r–53r and possibly 53r–103r (textualis).
        6.        Hand 6: Fols. 103r–108r (textualis).
        7.        Hand 7: Fols. 108v–124v (textualis).
        8.        Hand 8: f.125v (cursive).
        9.        Hand 9: Fols. 125v–131r (cursive).
        10.        Hand 10: Fols. 131r–138v (cursive).
        11.        Hand 11: (Later addition?) f.140v (cursive).

(Reference: Gejrot 1994, pp. 18–19.)

Scribe: A. K. [Anna Karlsdotter], Vadstena, f.140v.

column11: Une partie du C08 a été rédigée dans les années 1473-1486 lorsque Margareta Claesdotter était abbesse. Le nom de l'écrivain be peut pas être déterminé ici de manière tout à fait objective. Dans la deuxième partie, le nom du scribe est certain, mais l'époque n'est pas assez précise. Cependant en 1486, Anna Fickesdotter devint prieure et cela aurait probablement été mentionné d'une manière ou d'une autre si le manuscrit avait été écrit après cette années. Mais il ne fait aucun doute que la main est la même dans les deux parties. Kristina Johansdotter Brask a écrit le directorium chori.

f.220v: “This book was completed in the year of Our Lord 1470 on the Feast of Saint Peter in Chains, the holy apostle.”

f.222: “With the help of Almighty God and His dear Mother, and through my own efforts, I, Sister Hilliken Kyesendaels, professed nun of the enclosed convent of Saint Barbara’s Garden in the city of Berck, ask that you recite an Ave Maria from time to time for Jesus’ sake on behalf of the poor scribe.”

column16: Vollend zu/o/ lob vnd eren / Maria vnd got dem heren / Vnd zu/o/ andau"cht aller maist / Margreten Vesslerin sie hayst. / Ain werde schwester lobesan /Zu/o/ Wilperg in dem stetlin clan / Wel sie bestetgen gottes gwalt / Mit all irn schwestern ju"ng vnd alt. / Wa sy ir gebet vff messenn / Dyss buchlins schryber nit vergessen / Das gschriben ist im iar fu"rwar / Tu"ssend funffhu"ndert verczehen iar / Am abend Magdalene zart / Der all ir su"nd vergeben ward / Wel vns erwerberben (!) gottes segen / Hie vnd dort daz ewig leben. / Amen. / 1514. (57r); Gand Nr. 183: "perhaps a Wildberger Begine"
column18:
Completed in praise and honor / Of Mary and God the Lord /
And in deepest devotion above all / Margreten Vesslerin is her name. /
A worthy and praiseworthy sister / From Wilperg, in the little town nearby, /
Who confirmed God’s power / With all her sisters, young and old. /
When they offer their prayers during Mass, / Let them not forget the scribe of this book, /
Which was written in truth in the year / One thousand five hundred and fourteen, /
On the eve of tender Magdalene / Who was forgiven all her sins. /
May she secure for us God’s blessing / Here and there, eternal life. /
Amen. / 1514.

column11:
Writer of the main parts: Sister Barbara von Rottenburg in the Dominican monastery Maria-Reut(h)in (Fiala/Irtenkauf p. 84)
Based on the documents used for binding, this (collective) manuscript originates from the Dominican convent of Reutin. According to G. Piccard’s watermark analysis, it was not begun before 1515 and was completed by around 1529.
The main scribe of its primary sections is Sister Barbara von Rottenburg of Reutin (Gand No. 175), who identifies herself in a manuscript she authored (Cod. theol. et phil. oct. 31, f.64r). She is considered the primary scribe of Reutin from around 1488 to 1534. Her works include:
        •        Cod. theol. et phil. qu. 77 (1488-1492),
        •        Cod. theol. et phil. oct. 31 (1492),
        •        Cod. brev. 27 (1511),
        •        Cod. brev. 73 (1521),
        •        Cod. theol. et phil. qu. 49a-b (1524),
        •        Cod. brev. 49 (1529),
        •        Cod. theol. et phil. oct. 33 (1534).

column11:
Bastarda currens script by several hands
An analysis of the watermarks by G. Piccard suggests a probable period of inscription between 1490-1492. The Dominican litany (119v) and the German rubrics written by a second, later hand (e.g., “Barbara von Rottenburg,” see Cod. brev. 63) indicate its origin in the Dominican convent of Reutin.

column11:
several hands: Hd. 2 = Barbara von Rottenburg
The manuscript is composed of partially incomplete prayer booklets written by various hands at different times. The initial section was written in 1496 at the Benedictine Monastery of Lorch: “56v Written in Lorch in the year 1496 by Clemens of the convent brothers of Lorch” (likely Clemens Aurifabri, prior in 1490; see Württembergische Geschichtsquellen, Vol. 12, 1910, p. 86).
The second hand is attributed to Sister Barbara of Rottenburg from Reutin (see Cod.brev.63), suggesting Reutin as the manuscript’s library of origin. Her work is dated to 1521 (83v).

column64:
Prayer book:
        •        57r–71r: Passion prayers beginning “Protect me at all times and especially at my last departure…” including (on 59r) a list of saints predominantly of Dominican origin.
70r: Morning prayer addressed to Eternal Wisdom: “O most beautiful, most radiant, eternal Wisdom…”
        •        71v–83v: Prayers to saints including Mary Magdalene, (76r) Anna, (78r) George, (79r) Nicholas, (80r) Dorothea, (80v) Barbara, (81v) Margaret, (82v) Catherine. At 83v, the date mentioned earlier is repeated.
        •        88r–100v: Prayer by St. Bernard when Jesus descended to him from the Cross: “Hail, Jesus, the salvation of the world…”
        •        101r: Blank.
        •        101v: Rubric for the Rosary of Christ, incomplete.
        •        142r–153v: Exhortation for the contemplation of the sovereignty of God

column64:
Prayer book;
1r–1v: Rubric for prayers of Pope Urban IV.
        •        2r–55r: Daily prayers from Sunday to Saturday: “Almighty Father, eternal God, whose power enables the mind to comprehend …” These prayers follow a fixed sequence: God the Father, God the Son, Holy Spirit, Trinity, Mary, Angels, John.
        •        56v: Scribe’s colophon
        •        102r–111r: “A short teaching of the devout father Bonagratia (Bonaventure) of the Franciscan Order,” a spiritual guide: “Dearest brothers, at your request and desire, I have compiled for you a brief teaching…”

column11: Since the text was almost certainly written by a nun named Sophia , it is very likely that the book decoration was also inserted in a nunnery, more precisely a Cistercian convent (see the calendar). Not the first, but perhaps the second owner was Margareta von Isenburg in the Marienborn monastery near Büdingen, which can provisionally be considered the place of origin. Judit 's entry on the endpaper and the document fragment provide the time frame.

column11: TRAVELING REFORMER: “Sister in the Monastery of St. Catherine in Colmar (France). Further attested in the Monastery of Sylo in Sélestat (Alsace, France) as ‘Under-administrator and Sacristan’ (in the year 1464). In 1466, she served as reformer and first prioress of the Observant branch in Engelport, near Guebwiller (Alsace, France). She transcribed several large choir books. ‘A well-skilled sister in painting and writing, and she was relied upon when needed.’ 1464/66 (Kramer, Scriptores).”

244 v: Completum est hoc opus psalterii per manus Barbare Gretzingerin de Lindow conventualis monasterii montis Marie. Anno domini milesimo (sic) quadringentesimo quinquagesimo quarto ipsa die nativitatis Marie. Etatis sue anno vicesimo quinto
258 r: Anno domini millesimo quadringentesimo quinquagesimo quinto circa festum nativitatis Marie virginis completum est hoc psalterium per manus Barbare Gretzingerin de Lindow sororis conventualis in Berg prope Gamertingen etatis annorum viginti sex …
column18:
Page 244 verso: This work of the Psalter is completed by the hand of Barbara Gretzingerin from Lindow, a member of the convent of Mount Mary. In the year of our Lord one thousand four hundred fifty-four, on the very day of the Nativity of Mary. In the twenty-fifth year of her age.

Page 258 recto: In the year of our Lord one thousand four hundred fifty-five, around the feast of the Nativity of the Virgin Mary, this Psalter was completed by the hand of Barbara Gretzingerin from Lindow, a sister of the convent in Berg near Gamertingen, at the age of twenty-six ...

column11:
The writer has also written her name at the top of each page. On 227 r there is also a coat of arms in addition to her name, which is exceptionally placed at the beginning of the layer in the lower edge of the page: red field with a recessed chevron left in the parchment background and three quinces (?) in yellow ( Schraut , Fig. 5);

An Alheid called Quidenbomen is documented as abbess of the Cistercian monastery Marienborn (Eckartshausen, district of Büdingen) in 1339-1342 (Hessisches Urkundenbuch 2, edited by Heinrich Reimer (Publications from the Imperial Prussian State Archives 51) Leipzig 1892, p. 523f.No ...​​​​​ ​1777, p. 183 No. 131; for monastery history see Simon ibid., vol. 1, pp. 109-117, and Georg Wilhelm Justin Wagner , The former spiritual monasteries in the Grand Duchy of Hesse 1, Darmstadt 1873, pp. 199-210) .
column16: f.15r: Que hunc librum scribebat Alheidis Quidenbeumen nomen habebat. Anno domini MCCCXLIIII. Orate misericorditer pro ea.
column18: On f.15 recto: This book was scribed by Alheidis Quidenbeumen. In the year of our Lord one thousand three hundred and forty-four. Pray mercifully for her.

column16:
According to the colophon of f.207r, copied by Aef Dircsdr, Jacob Gherijtsdr, Aechte Claesdr, Maria Martijnsdr and Maria Gherijtsdr and owned by the Canonesses Regular St. Margaret, Gouda
F.207: (par la copiste du texte précédent:) Dit boec hoert toe den nonnen regulierissen van sinte augustijns oerde tot sinte margrieten binnen der goude a/ter die kerc. (Puis d'une autre main:) Ende is ghescreven uut minnen des heilighen daghes ende buten die tijt des ghemenen arbeyts totter eeren gods ende salicheit der sielen alle der gheenre diet lesen ende horen lesen. Intjaer ons heren. M cccc (le premier c gratté) ende lx. van suster aef dires dochter, susterjacob gherijts dochter, suster aechte claes dochter, suster maria martijns dochter ende suster maria gherijts dochter, nonnen, haren gheminden susteren tot een testament, ende een ewighe ghedenckenisse na haerre doot. welker namen ghescreven moeten wesen inder herten gods. Amen.
column18:
According to the colophon on f.207 recto, copied by Aef Dircsdr, Jacob Gherijtsdr, Aechte Claesdr, Maria Martijnsdr, and Maria Gherijtsdr, and owned by the Canonesses Regular St. Margaret in Gouda.

f.207 recto (by the copier of the preceding text): This book belongs to the Canonesses Regular of the Order of Saint Augustine at Saint Margaret's in Gouda, next to the church. (Then, in another hand): And it was written out of love for the holy day and outside the time of common work, for the glory of God and the salvation of souls, for all those who read and hear it read. In the year of our Lord one thousand four hundred sixty, by Sister Aef Dircsdr, Sister Jacob Gherijtsdr, Sister Aechte Claesdr, Sister Maria Martijnsdr, and Sister Maria Gherijtsdr, nuns, to their beloved sisters as a testament and everlasting remembrance after their death. Whose names must be written in the hearts of God. Amen.
column19: Gouda, Canonesses Regular of St. Margaret

column11:
Lijsbeth Mols (-1538) [12e priorin]
FIrst text Mainly Latin, Prologue and some excerpts in Dutch
Second text is Dutch translation from the Latin
column16: f.3r: "Desen boeck heft ghescreuen. Ende met groeten aerbeyt vergadert onse gheminde mede suster. suster lijsbeth mols. Ende dat inden tijt dat sij aen die schiue diende. Ende sij heeft begheert dat desen boeck altoes op den choer sal ligghen. omtrint oft voer die priorinne op dat een yeghelijc daer in mach vinden na sijn beliefte. Ende sij bidt ende begheert zeere oetmoedelijc uwer alder deuoet ghebeth voer haer arm ziele. die v oec wilen inden last der priorinscap onweerdich ghedient heeft. xxxiii Requiescant in pace Amen" (f.362r, door de kopiiste: "desen boeck hout in .xlvj. quaternen")
column18: On f.3 recto: This book was written and diligently compiled by our beloved sister, Sister Lijsbeth Mols, during the time she served in the refectory. She has requested that this book always remain on the choir, near or before the prioress, so that everyone may find therein according to their desires. And she earnestly prays and humbly requests your devout prayers for her poor soul, which also once served unworthily under the burden of the prioress's office. Requiescant in pace, Amen. (On f.362 recto, by the copyist: "this book contains 46 quires.")

column11:
M. Gro (=Mary Groters?)
According to the colophon on f.210v, copied by "M Gro", problably Marie Groters, who also copied UB, Leiden: ms. 604, and destined for Agnees van Enghelen, who problably was a Sister of the Common Life of St. Andrew (Ten Orten/Jerusalem) in's-Hertogenbosch
column16: F.210v°: (en rouge:) Item dit boeck waert ghescreven intjaer ons heren doe men screef dusent vyfhondert en xviii en waert gheeynt des donredaechs nae beloken paesschen. (en noir:) Item dese collacien heeft suster agnees van enghelen alleen onthouden van onsen lieven eerwerdighen vader heer bernaert en den convent ghelaten den ghenen horen orber in te doen die daer minne toe hebben en si heeft begheert dattet sal blyven in die leberye en dattet anders nyemont voer syn eyghen houden en sal want syt alleen becosticht en bearbeyt heeft. En om die minne gods een ave maria voer die scryftster (!) want si cleyn van doechden is M Gro
column18:
f.210 verso:
(in red:) Item, this book was written in the year of our Lord when they wrote one thousand five hundred and eighteen and was finished on the Thursday after Low Sunday.
(in black:) Item, these collections were solely memorized by Sister Agnes van Enghelen from our beloved venerable father, Lord Bernaert, and left to the convent for those who have love for them, and she has requested that it shall remain in the library and that nobody else shall claim it as their own, for she alone has endowed and labored over it. And for the love of God, an Ave Maria for the scribe, as she is lacking in virtues. M. Gro.

column16: f.228: Item dit boeck waert begonnen int jaer ons heren M° cccc ende Ixxviii Opter heiliger xim meechdendach Ende het waert geeindet Op der heiliger mertelerssen sinte Margarten dach int Jaer doe men screef M0 cccc ende Ixxviiij. Bidt om gods wil voer die scrivers van mynnen dat sij hemelrijck moet gewinnen Suster katrijn van rade is haer name. bidt sunderlingen Marien der glorioser moeder gods voer hoer in wes eren sij dit boeck gescreven het. Ave. maria, rosa. etc
column18: f.228: This book was begun in the year of our Lord 1478 on the holy feast day of Saint Margaret the Virgin. And it was finished on the feast day of the holy martyrs Saint Margaret in the year when it was written, 1479. Pray for the scribes out of love that they may attain the kingdom of heaven. Sister Katrijn van Rade is her name. Especially pray to Mary, the glorious Mother of God, for her in whose honor she wrote this book. Ave Maria, Rosa, etc.

column16:
Suscipe completi laudes Rex xpe labo
Quas cordis leti vox subdita reddit amoris
Francisti meritis scis est attribuen
Quidquid dixeritis doctores esse tenendum
Donis Agnetis liburm complevimus i
Quem cum scribetis iuncti benedicito xpistum
Sit /////// operis oratio sancta legen
Que iungat superis nos firmo cardina mentis
column18:
“Receive the praises of the completed work, King Christ,
Which the voice of a heart in joy submissively returns in love.
By the merits of Francis, you know it is attributed.
Whatever you say, teachers, must be held.
With the gifts of Agnes, we have completed the book.
When you write, joined together, bless Christ.
May the holy prayer of this work join us with the heavens,
Firmly establishing the hinges of the mind.”
column62: Saint-Benoît de Port-Valais (Abbey : Bouveret, Switzerland). Colophons de Manuscrits Occidentaux Des Origines Au XVIe Siècle. Fribourg: Suisse, Éditions universitaires, 1965.

column16: Scriptrix mente pia solum petit Ave Maria. Lateo monitus, testudo est michi nidus, Nam prebet hoc vitis, quod nec michi das Sunamitis (f.163). Scriptrix... (ut supra) Quondam priorissa Confluencie in Insula sita (f.174)
column18:
The scribe, with a pious mind, seeks only the Ave Maria.
I lie hidden, warned, a turtle is my shelter,
For the vine gives this, which the Shunammite does not give me (f.163).
The scribe… (as above) formerly prioress of Constance on the Island (f.174).

column16: Iste liber scriptus est per me Margaretam professam huius monasterii beatiss. Marie v. Et est finitus a.d. 1467 in vig. Visitationis v. Marie etc. (f.57). Obiit Barbara de Bopardia scriba huius monasterii 1562 (f.49). Katherina de Disyngen quondam scriba huius monasterii per annos circiter 40 obiit a. 1555. (f.49v).
column18:
This book was written by me, Margareta, professed of this monastery of the most blessed Virgin Mary, and was finished in the year of our Lord 1467 on the eve of the Visitation of the Virgin Mary, etc. (f.57).
Barbara of Boppard, scribe of this monastery, passed away in 1562 (f.49).
Katharina of Disyngen, formerly a scribe of this monastery for approximately 40 years, passed away in 1555 (f.49v).
column62: Saint-Benoît de Port-Valais (Abbey : Bouveret, Switzerland). Colophons de manuscrits occidentaux des origines au XVIe siècle. Vol. 4. Fribourg, Suisse, Editions universitaires, 1965. http://archive.org/details/colophonsdemanus0004sain.

column16: Summus honor celi / Filius ipse ipse pater / Hoc opus explerunt / Inde sibi veniam / Qui te sustulerit / spes grata Maria fideli / remanes in virgine mater / Aleith Claricia querunt / te venerando piam / hunc anathema ferit. (f.192v). % Mater Ide Lifmundis fecit hec scribi. anima eius requiescat in pace. (f.193)
column18:
The greatest honor of heaven,
the Son Himself, the Father Himself,
completed this work.
From Him, may forgiveness
be given to whoever carries you.
O gracious hope, Mary faithful,
you remain a virgin mother.
Aleith and Claricia seek you,
venerating you, O pious one.
This [text] invokes a curse upon [him who acts against it].

Mother Ida Lifmund had this written. May her soul rest in peace.
column62: Saint-Benoît de Port-Valais (Abbey : Bouveret, Switzerland). Colophons de Manuscrits Occidentaux Des Origines Au XVIe Siècle. Fribourg: Suisse, Éditions universitaires, 1965.

column16: f.262v: Zu lob und er got dem almachtigen, Marie und allen heiligen und dem menschen zu underweisung, und aus haissen der erwirdigen geistleichen frawn Ludmille, priorin, meiner lieben muetter und frawn, ich swester Barbara, verluepte der regel sand Augustin und der ordnung und statutt Praemonstratensium zu Pernekch, hab geschriben das gegenwuertig puech mit aygner hant, das gemacht und gepredigt hat der hach gelert maister Gorig zu Wien, und ich hab das volentt an dem nagsten tag nach Colomanni des heiligen m[artyre]r. Die schreiberin pitt zu lan ain Ave Maria umb ir meue die sy hat gehabt mit dem schreiben
column18: On f.262 verso: To praise and give glory to Almighty God, to Mary, and to all the saints, and for the instruction of humanity, and from the desire of the venerable spiritual lady Ludmille, prioress, my dear mother and lady, I, Sister Barbara, devoted to the rule of St. Augustine and to the order and statutes of the Premonstratensians at Pernegg, have written this present book with my own hand, which was composed and preached by the highly learned Master Gorig at Vienna, and I completed it on the next day after the feast of St. Coloman the martyr. The scribe asks you, as an act of charity, to say an Ave Maria for her soul, for the effort she put into writing.

column11:
Whereas according to the Byvanck database, this manuscript may have been made in the eastern part of the Northern Netherlands, according the Database BNM, it was made in Amstelland
Provenance
The manuscript was written by a certain Beatris Dircs Bonen dochter for a convent of Canonesses Regular, dedicated to St. Nicholas and St. Mary Magdalene. According to the Database BNM, the formula on f.17r-17v suggests that the manuscript was made for the Canonesses Regular of St. Mary Magdalene (Op het Spui), Amsterdam. According to Stooker & Verbeij (1997), the formula could have also been for the Canonesses Regular of St. Mary Magdalene, Zaltbommel.
column16: f.111v: "Inden jaer ons heren doemen screef M iiii[c] ende lxxxvi soe heeft suster beatris dircs bonen dochter dit boecskijn ghescreven Doe si out was lxii jaer Ende ghewoent hadde in den cloester xlv jaer Bidt voer hoer om godswille Ende leest een pater noster ende iii ave maria."
column18: f.111 verso: "In the year of our Lord one thousand four hundred and eighty-six, Sister Beatris Dircs, daughter of Bonen, wrote this little book when she was sixty-two years old and had lived in the cloister for forty-five years. Pray for her for God's sake, and recite a Our Father and three Hail Marys."

column16:
.176r – on fig. 5c “Iste liber est monasterii Sancti Spiritus de Verona quem scripsit domina soror Scolastica de Mafeis. 1484. Que obiit die primo [then another ‘die’ crossed out] mai. 1492. in hora tertie. Cuius anima requiescat in pace.” 
then next to this note, in adjacent column, same hand: “Questo libro si è de la venerabile religiosa madona suor Scolastica di Mafei, el quale scripse de sua mane propria del anno 1484 et madona suor Veronica lo aminiò de penna. Monache de Sancto Spiritu.”
column18:
On f.176 recto, next to figure 5c, it says, "This book belongs to the monastery of the Holy Spirit of Verona, written by the lady Sister Scolastica de Mafeis. 1484. Who died on the first day [then another 'day' crossed out] of May. 1492. at the third hour. May her soul rest in peace."

Next to this note, in the adjacent column, in the same hand: "This book belongs to the venerable nun Lady Sister Scolastica di Mafei, which she wrote with her own hand in the year 1484, and the lady Sister Veronica adorned it with a feather pen. Nuns of the Holy Spirit."

f.89r: inside a ribbon banner is the portrait of the nun-scribe in Augustinian (says miglio, a mulieribus, 262) habit with a gesture of prayer – text on banner reads: “Ancilla Ihesu Christi Maria Ormani filia scripsit MCCCCLIII. Qui scripsit scribat semper cum dno vivat. Vivat in celis in suo nomine felix. 
Qui legentium orationes pro merito karitatis expostulat a.d. 1453 die 25 mensis Madii. Deo gratias. Amen.
column18: “The handmaid of Jesus Christ, Maria, daughter of Ormano, wrote [this] in the year 1453. May the one who wrote always write, may they live with the Lord. May they live happily in heaven in His name. The one who wrote requests the prayers of the readers for the sake of charity. Year 1453, 25th day of May. Thanks be to God. Amen.”

column18:
f.117v: in the year of our Lord 1468, on the 8th day of May, this book was completed by Sister Katherinen Wijgaerts, a professed nun at St. Elizabeth's convent in Brussels, in the Wormoesbroec near St. Lawrence's Chapel.

Furthermore, I, Sister Katherine Wijgaerts, would earnestly request that after my death, the prioress approves that this booklet remains available to all the prioresses, whoever she may be, and that it be kept on the choir for anyone who wishes to study it occasionally.

column4: Vienna, Österreichischen Nationalbibliothek, Theol. lat. Hier. 896
column16: f.302: An dem 1316 iar von christes gebort. Is ditz büch erzüget. Von der hoch-geborn vrowen Elzebeten der werden zwire kuninginnen. zu einem ewigen zügnisse iris namen und allers geschlechtes fürsten und kunige om welch closter ditz büch wirt gegeben daz men ir da ewicliche gedenke zum ersten der di da tot sin daz di slafen in Gotes fride und zu der exigen freude kumen. di da noch leben daz sich die freuwen selde und lanklebens; der nach-kümelinge daz si in tusent geslechte wachsen. Amen.
column18: “In the year 1316 after the birth of Christ, this book was produced by the noble lady Elisabeth, descendant of two illustrious queens, as an eternal testament to her name and that of her entire lineage of princes and kings. Whichever monastery receives this book, may she be eternally remembered there. First, for those who are deceased, may they rest in God’s peace and come to eternal joy. For those who are still living, may they enjoy happiness and long life. For their descendants, may they flourish for a thousand generations. Amen.”

column16:
f.187: 1482. Bidt voor huer diet heeft ghescreven Dat soe ghewinne dat eewich leven. Amen.
f.205: 1482
f.at the end of ms: item ic zuster katheline govaerst cam int cloester van bethanie den hersten dach van april int jaer ons heeren als men scref m ccc ende lxxiii hout zinde in dier tijt xvii jaer bit voer haer ziele om gods will. Dese bouc behoert toe zuster katheline govaerst bij consente van haer huerverste hu biddic die dese bouc hebben zal naer mijn over lijden dat ghij voer mijn ziele bidden wilt also ic mi in hu betrauwe.
column18:
f.187: 1482. Pray for her who has written this, that she may gain eternal life. Amen.
f.205: 1482
Note at the end of the manuscript: Likewise, I, Sister Katheline Govaerst, entered the convent of Bethany on the day of Easter in the year of our Lord, as it was written in 1373. Having been there for seventeen years, pray for her soul for God's sake. This book belongs to Sister Katheline Govaerst, with the consent of her superiors. I ask those who shall have this book after my passing to pray for my soul, as I trust myself to you.
column26: Bruges, Soeurs tertiaires de Béthanie Belgium Bruges

column16: f.196v: "Dit boeck hoert tot sinte annen cloester te delft den regularissen ende het is ghescreven overmits der hant lijsbet meyster jans dochter der nonnen ende het wart begonnen int jaer ons heren M cccc ende lxxxvii ende het wort gheeyndet op den manendach naden vierden sondach inden advent int jaer ons heren M cccc ende lxxxviii ende men en selt niet vercopen want het veel op heilighe daghen ghescreven is bidt voer haer om gods willen"
column18: f.196v: This book belongs to the convent of Saint Anne in Delft, belonging to the regular sisters. It was written by the hand of Lijsbet, daughter of Master Jan, one of the nuns. It was started in the year of our Lord 1487 and completed on the Monday after the fourth Sunday in Advent in the year of our Lord 1488. It shall not be sold because it was written on holy days. Please pray for her, for the love of God.
column19: Delft, Augustinian Canonesses Regular of St. Agnes
column26: Delft, Augustinian Canonesses Regular of St. Agnes  Netherlands Delft

column16: f.196v! Dit boeck hoert tot sinte annen cloester te delft den regularissen ende het is ghescreven overmits der hant lijsbet meyster jans dochter der nonnen ende het wart begonnen int jaer ons heren M cccc ende lxxxvii ende het wort gheeyndet op den manendach naden vierden sondach inden advent (f.197) int jaer ons heren M cccc ende lxxxviii ende men en selt niet vercopen want het veel op eilighe daghen ghescreven is (added:) bidt voer haer om gods willen
column18: f.196v: This book belongs to the convent of Saint Anne in Delft, to the Regular Sisters, and it was written by the hand of Lisbet, daughter of Master Jan, one of the nuns. It was begun in the year of our Lord 1487 and finished on the Monday after the fourth Sunday in Advent (f.197) in the year of our Lord 1488. It shall not be sold because it was written on holy days. Please pray for her for the sake of God.

column16: Hie endet ... und wart geedet uf unsser lieben frauwen octava nativitas Marie in dem iaere unssers herren Ihu xpi da man schreiff 1461. lieben sustern haen ich Greta van van Wysschel obel geschreven so vertzyet myr und biddet den lieben Ihm dat ich mych gebesser et in omnibus moribus meis. Diss boich ist des Iunffrawen cloesters zu Schoenawe.
column18: “Here ends … and was completed on the octave of the Nativity of Mary in the year of our Lord Jesus Christ, 1461. Dear sisters, I, Greta van Wysschel, have humbly written this—so forgive me and pray to the dear Lord Jesus that I may improve myself in all my ways. This book belongs to the convent of the Virgins of Schönawe.”
column62: Saint-Benoît de Port-Valais (Abbey : Bouveret, Switzerland). Colophons de manuscrits occidentaux des origines au XVIe siècle. Vol. 4. Fribourg, Suisse, Editions universitaires, 1965. http://archive.org/details/colophonsdemanus0004sain.

column11:
Ce manuscrit, qui dans la recherche scientifique antérieure a souvent été appelé « Chronique », est le « Konventsbuch » de St. Katharina à Saint-Gall (61r:...und sol dis also in des convents buoch gesetz werden...). On y trouve des entrées chronologiques concernant les intérêts économiques du couvent. Le manuscrit a été établi au cours de la réforme au moment où le couvent passait de propriété privée à une propriété commune. Ainsi, ce livre permettait à la direction du couvent de St. Katharina de rendre compte auprès de la communauté des possessions gérées. Il permettait également aux sœurs de connaître l’état de leurs biens initialement déposés au couvent. Le manuscrit contient des contributions concernant les activités de construction, l’équipement, le scriptorium, les contentieux, les donations, mais aussi des entrées relatives à certaines soeurs, directeurs de conscience ou ouvriers, ainsi que, épisodiquement, des entrées concernant l’histoire du couvent.
 The chronicle contains reports and notes from a wide variety of areas of contemporary convent history: Angela Varnbühler 's investing hand begins (ex post) with her election as prioress in 1476, and continues with a list of the conventuals as well as reports from the implementation of the first Steps to reform the monastery. The other entries, in chronological order, concern a wide variety of events from everyday convent life: entry of novices and their later profession; News of death (from conventuals, relatives and friends); Endowments (of seasons and interest) and gifts; Book production in the scriptorium; Economy of the monastery (conductor's annual accounts, administration, land acquisition [fields, forests, vineyards]); Expansion and conversion as well as artistic furnishings of the monastery buildings; Contemporary events from the history of the monastery and order - even the event of the solar eclipse in 1485 found its way into the chronicle with an entry by the prioress (f.45r ).
column26: St. Gallen, St. Katharina Monastery Switzerland St. Gallen
column62: Mengis Simone, Writing women around 1500. Scriptorium and library of the Dominican monastery of St. Katharina St. Gallen (Scrinium Friburgense 28), Berlin/New York 2013

column11: After the council of the city of St. Gallen lifted the enclosure of the Dominican monastery of St. Catherine on May 2, 1528, and the convent gradually dissolved, only Regula Keller and two sisters remained in the monastery buildings, where she continued to copy the Rule of Augustine and the Constitutions of the Order of Preachers until 1543. The reading of the Rule and Constitutions was emphasized more strongly in Reformed monasteries, in keeping with the nature of the Observance. (men)
column16: f.104v: Hie habend end die constitucion der schwesteren prediger ordens M ccccc xliij Iar daz bis buoch folendet ist vor sant gallen tag von schwester regel kellerin von zürich, die begert ein aue maria: deo gracias.
column18:
f.104v: Here end the constitutions of the sisters of the Order of Preachers. In the year 1543.
This book was completed before the feast of Saint Gall by Sister Regel Kellerin of Zurich, who asks for an Ave Maria. Thanks be to God.
column19: St. Gallen, Convent of St. Catherine
column26: St. Gallen, Convent of St. Catherine Switzerland St Gallen
column36:
Watermark of a small bear with a short head and tiny ears, another bear with a longer snout on pages 87 and 89 , and another variant on page 90 with a wide-open snout and ears resembling a bump on the head. Precisely identifying the bear marks is difficult, as only parts are visible, and the paper is very thick.
The empty pages 107 ff.have later watermarks: a large crown and at least one other watermark.
Engler-Maurer , Rulebook (1998) identifies the bear WZ, without mentioning variants, with
Piccard , watermark XV/2 (1987), section I, no. 287, without indication of place and date (recte: Tuttlingen, 1525).
column62:

S. 149 (Nr. 414), Abb.-Bd. S. 283 (Abb. 678-679).
Igna Marion Kramp (Hg.), Mittelalterliche und frühneuzeitliche deutsche Übersetzungen des pseudo-hugonischen Kommentars zur Augustinusregel (Corpus Victorinum. Textus historici 2), Münster 2008, S. 18 (Nr. 72), 25.
Igna Marion Kramp, Renovamini spiritu / Ernüwent den geist üwers gemütes. Deutsche Übersetzungen als Modernisierung im späten Mittelalter (Corpus Victorinum. Instrumenta 2), Münster 2009, S. 95f., 102.

column64:
f.1v = Ownership entry for the Dominican Convent Wil
f.2r-9v = 'Augustinian Rule'
f.9v-75r = Hugo of St. Victor : 'Expositio in regulam beati Augustini' (German [Katharinentaler] translation) (Wy 1 )
f.75v-104v = 'Dominican Constitutions' for nuns

column16: f.447v-448r: Dis buch ist uss geschriben worden a.n als man zalt nach christus geburt m CCC vnd lxxxiiij iar in der octau visitacio. Bittent got fur die zwo schwostren mit aim aue maria die diss buch mit grosser arbeit vnd fliss gecorien hand als man es wol sicht S potenciana t vnd S efrosina K
column18:
“This book was written in the year 1384 after the birth of Christ, in the octave of the Feast of the Visitation.
Pray to God for the two sisters with an Ave Maria, who wrote this book with great effort and diligence, as one can clearly see.
Sister Potenciana T. and Sister Euphrosina K.”

column4: Wil, Dominikarinnenkloster St. Katharina, No inventory number
column11:
Main hand and accounting entries written by Prioress Anna Krumm, e.g., fols. 1r–2r [1v blank], ljrv, lxiijr–lxviv, and throughout
        •        Alternating with the hand of Angela Varnbühler, in semi-cursive; both using brown ink
        •        f.lxxiiijv: a 7-line entry in almost black ink by Elisabeth Schaigenwiler
        •        Additional hands from around 1450, including some otherwise unknown female scribes

Numerous marginal annotations by Regula Keller in the first half of the 16th century (ca. 1530 and after), using a very fine quill
	•	Examples:
	•	f.1r: “The estates were sold during the adversities of the Lutheran times by the people of St. Gallen”
	•	f.4v: “The estate was also sold in the turbulent Lutheran times by the people of St. Gallen”
	•	f.11r: “The estate was sold by the people of St. Gallen as they authorized us”
(see also fig. 25)
column19: convent of St. Katharina in Wil, Canton of St. Gallen
column26: convent of St. Katharina in Wil, Canton of St. Gallen Switzerland Wil
column36: a distinctive ox head (without additional mark) with eyes, ears, and nostrils, the nose contours extending obliquely to the left from the corners of the eyes, with three "curls" between the horns. Similar, but not identical to Piccard , Watermark II/2 (1966), Section I, No. 701 (Ansbach, Bamberg, Koblenz, Rothenburg, 1451-1468); similar also to Briquet , Filigree IV (1907), No. 14329 (including Toulouse 1441-1454; Avignon 1447) and No. 14332 (including Montpellier 1458); variants of Nos. 14336-14340 (including St. Gallen until 1433; Geneva 1438-1488).
column46: Few pages fully written; many are blank, e.g., fols. 84–99

column26: convent of St. Katharina in Wil, Canton of St. Gallen Switzerland Wil
column36: a distinctive ox head (without additional mark) with eyes, ears, and nostrils, the nose contours extending obliquely to the left from the corners of the eyes, with three "curls" between the horns. Similar, but not identical to Piccard , Watermark II/2 (1966), Section I, No. 701 (Ansbach, Bamberg, Koblenz, Rothenburg, 1451-1468); similar also to Briquet , Filigree IV (1907), No. 14329 (including Toulouse 1441-1454; Avignon 1447) and No. 14332 (including Montpellier 1458); variants of Nos. 14336-14340 (including St. Gallen until 1433; Geneva 1438-1488).
column46: Few pages fully written; many are blank, e.g., fols. 84–99

column11:
Livre des soeurs
Le titre de ce manuscrit est trompeur : il ne signifie pas, comme d'habitude dans la recherche, un recueil de brèves biographies de sœurs décédées dans un couvent particulier, composé par leurs proches dans les générations suivantes. Le livre des soeurs de Saint-Gall se compose de deux parties, écrites probablement au début des années 1480. La première partie ff.jr-xxiiijv (p. 5-14r de la nouvelle pagination) contient les registres des chartes de l’histoire des couvents dans les années 1228-1488, avec des renvois aux documents concernés; la deuxième partie, ff.xxvir-xxxvjr: correspondance entre les dominicaines de Saint-Gall et celles du couvent de Sainte-Catherine à Nuremberg; ff.xlviijr-CClvjr: cette partie n'est plus sous forme de lettres (avec des allocutions ou des formules de salutations, etc.), mais plutôt sous forme de résumés des usages de Nuremberg, rédigés sous forme de rapports et regroupés par thème; f.CCLIXr-CCLXIVv: registre. (men)
Main and rest hand Elisabeth Muntprat , mostly in very small semi-cursive bastarda, replaced passim by Angela Varnbühler , partly in her characteristic book hand, partly in right-leaning semi-cursive; a few short sections also by Regina Sattler (f.CClr ), Cordula von Schönau (f.Ljv - Liijr ) and the later prioress Sapientia Wirt (f.CCxliiijr ).

Schrift und Hände: Haupt- und Anlagehand Elisabeth Muntprat, zumeist in sehr kleiner halbkursiver Bastarda, abgelöst passim von Angela Varnbühler, teils in ihrer charakteristischen Buchschrift, teils in rechtsgeneigter Halbkursive; wenige kurze Abschnitte auch von Regina Sattler (f.CClr), Cordula von Schönau (f.Ljv-Liijr) und der späteren Priorin Sapientia Wirt (f.CCxliiijr).
column26: St. Gallen, St. Katharina Monastery Switzerland St. Gallen

column11:
The library does not allow to look for watermarks.
The dialect suggests origin in Bavaria.
Based on the wording of the prayers, the book was intended for women.
The additions from f.126r onward were made by a female scribe. We do not know the scribe of the rest of the manuscript.
The rest of the manuscript is catalogued (black notebook)
column16: 138r E: biss an den jungsten tag dass sich lyb und sel wider gesammlen in dem lob gottes. Amen. Bittent got ouch tru"wlich fu"r mich arme ellende schryberin und Maria syn werde mu/e/ter.
column18: “Until the last day, when love and soul shall be reunited in the praise of God. Amen. Please, pray sincerely to God for me, the poor, wretched scribe, and for Mary, His blessed mother.”

column11: Hand on fols. 25r–169v is the same as in Cod. Guelf. 982 Helmst., fols. 89r–192r, by a scriptrix of the Hamersleben Group (for palaeographical classification see Härtel, Geschrieben und gemalt, pp. 90f.).

column7: 1v–23v, 26r–41r, 42v–43v, 56r–70v (also occasional interlinear corrections and additions on some leaves written by the other hands).
column8: Ms. Wolfenbüttel, Herzog August Bibliothek Cod. Guelf. 1034 Helmst., Hamersleben group 1
column11:
Main text in carolino-gothica by at least five hands of the so-called “Hamersleben group”:
        •        Hand 1 (main hand): 1v–23v, 26r–41r, 42v–43v, 56r–70v (also occasional interlinear corrections and additions on some leaves written by the other hands).
        •        Hand 2: 24r–25v, 35v (only an insertion), 41r–42v.
        •        Then, from 42v–55v, almost every entry is by a different hand, including the two first and probably two further hands.
        •        Hand 5: 70v–79v.
The additional notes and verses inserted on 2r–3r, 4v–6v, 7v–9r, 10v, 12r–v, 14v–15r, 16r–v, 17v–18r, 25r, 27r, and 68r–70v are by a hand of the so-called “Scriptrix group.”

column11: This is the Latin translation, by the reformer and chronicler Johannes Busch, of an anonymous Middle Dutch meditation text; see C. C. de Bruin, De dietse oertekst van de anonieme ‘Epistola de vita et passione domini nostri Ihesu Christi et aliis devotis exercitiis’, in Nederlandsch archief voor kerkgeschiedenis NS 34 (1944/45), 1–23. It is the only known copy explicitly intended for a women’s convent, as the original form of address frater has been replaced with soror.
column14: Slightly irregular Bastarda with cursive features

column46: Quire centres reinforced with parchment guards; an additional paper wrapper (max. 2 cm wide) laid around the last quire.

column16: [Istum libellum scripsit nobis utilis ac fidelis soror notstra Mechtildis Wolders ultimo vite sue tempore sancta exigente obedientia necnon pro ampliori devotione circa passionem dominicam habendam. Quo completo obdormivit in domino. Omnes legentes in eo ob speciale ipsius anime refregerium devoto corde dicant: Requescat in pace. Amen.].f.52v
column18: “This little book was written for us by our useful and faithful sister, Mechtildis Wolders, at the end of her life, compelled by holy obedience, and also for a greater devotion to be had regarding the Passion of the Lord. When this was completed, she fell asleep in the Lord. Let all who read it, for the special refreshment of her soul, say with a devout heart: Rest in peace. Amen.”
column26: Unknown Germany Unknown

column8: Ms. Wolfenbüttel, Herzog August Bibliothek Cod. Guelf. 1196 Helmst., Scriptrix group, Lampsringe hand 1
column11:
Regular carolino-gothica by three hands of the so-called “Scriptrix group”:
 Hand 1 (1r–59v, 102r–103v, and 104r–155v): upright and even, still markedly rounded carolino-gothica by the so-called scriptrix, also found in Cod. Guelf. 482a Helmst., 1r–82v; 510 Helmst.; 511 Helmst., 78r–150r; 519 Helmst.; 723 Helmst.; 903 Helmst., 1r–75r; and 943 Helmst., from the closing rubric of which the notname of the scribe derives. The codices whose scribes are particularly close to the “Scriptrix” also include Cod. Guelf. 443 Helmst., 447 Helmst., and 718 Helmst., 10v–97r, whereas Cod. Guelf. 1030 Helmst., previously counted in this group, should probably be excluded.
        •        Hand 2: 59v–72v.
        •        Hand 3: 73r–102r and 103v–104r.

column64:
1r–59v – John Chrysostom: Ad Theodorum de reparatione lapsi. Begins Quis dabit capiti meo aquam et oculis meis fontem lacrimarum? (Jer 9:1) … Breaks off in ch. 21; no chapter/section divisions. Edition: J. Dumortier, SCr 117 (1966), 257–322, here to p. 318, l. 8.

59v–72v – Anselm of Canterbury: Proslogion. Includes Tabula capitum (59v) and text (60r–72r); lacks prologue; chapters indicated only by paragraph marks. Edition: PL 158, 223B–242C; F. S. Schmitt, Opera omnia I (1946), 93–122.

73r–116v – Augustine of Hippo: Contra Faustum Manichaeum (part). Contains lib. 12,7–48 and 22,83–95. Editions: PL 42, 257–280, 451–464; CSEL 25, 336–377, 685–702.

116v–155r – Rupert of Deutz: De sancta trinitate et operibus eius (part). Contains selected chapters on the works of the Holy Spirit, some Scripture quotations abbreviated. Edition: CC CM 24–26.

156v – Pen trials: only the words Ave Maria, clumsily written.

column8: Ms. Wolfenbüttel, Herzog August Bibliothek Cod. Guelf. 1196 Helmst., Scriptrix group, Lampsringe hand 2
column11:
Regular carolino-gothica by three hands of the so-called “Scriptrix group”:
 Hand 1 (1r–59v, 102r–103v, and 104r–155v): upright and even, still markedly rounded carolino-gothica by the so-called scriptrix, also found in Cod. Guelf. 482a Helmst., 1r–82v; 510 Helmst.; 511 Helmst., 78r–150r; 519 Helmst.; 723 Helmst.; 903 Helmst., 1r–75r; and 943 Helmst., from the closing rubric of which the notname of the scribe derives. The codices whose scribes are particularly close to the “Scriptrix” also include Cod. Guelf. 443 Helmst., 447 Helmst., and 718 Helmst., 10v–97r, whereas Cod. Guelf. 1030 Helmst., previously counted in this group, should probably be excluded.
        •        Hand 2: 59v–72v.
        •        Hand 3: 73r–102r and 103v–104r.

column8: Ms. Wolfenbüttel, Herzog August Bibliothek Cod. Guelf. 1235 Helmst., Scriptrix
column11: By various hands.
column64:
1.	fols. 2–4. Blessed Bernard of Clairvaux, Dulciloquium de incarnatione Domini Iesu Christi.
“Ave, puer parvule
Celorum rex sublimis,
Nobilis infantule,
O Deus magne nimis.”
	2.	fol. 4v. Prayer of Blessed Bernard.
	3.	fols. 5–11. Prayers, including one “for the souls” in which prayers are offered for Adelhey­dis, the mother, and Ohevehardus, the father of the scriptrix, and for a certain Hogherus. Beginning defective.
	4.	fols. 12–191v. Prayers and readings, including (fols. 52–56) some in Low German.
	5.	fols. 192–199v. The Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ according to John.
	6.	fols. 200–220. Prayers and readings.
	7.	fols. 220v–223. Monastic rules.
	8.	fols. 223–224. About a certain saint.
	9.	fols. 224–226. About the apostles.
	10.	fols. 225v–226v. Prayers for the Mass of the Angels.
	11.	fols. 228–234. Commendatio animarum (Commendation of souls).
	12.	fols. 234v–236v. Prayer in Low German.
	13.	fols. 238–277. On the verse “Veritas liberabit vos” (“The truth shall set you free”): narratives, exhortations, and meditations, in Low German.
	14.	fols. 277v–311v. The three points in which one should exercise oneself for all days of the week, in Low German. “Nu wette, dat du dek alle tid schalt ouen.”
	15.	fols. 311v–314v. About Saint Bernhard (Van sunte Bernt).

column4: Wolfenbüttel, Herzog August Bibliothek, Cod. Guelf. 1265 Helmst.
column11: nun at Woltingerode: MarburgerRep says "Kristina" on f.7r (see pics)
column16: Finito libro sit laus et honor Christo Ihesu. Scriptrix (sic) donetur in celis merces scribentis sicut pura oratio legentis precorde pro amore Dei. Quicunque legis hunc librum, ut sis memor mei. Scriptrix huius delicatissimi libri et lectores inveniantur in libro viventium et cum iustis scribantur. Arnen dicant omnia. (f.180v)
column18:
“When the book is finished, let there be praise and honor to Christ Jesus. May the female scribe (sic) be granted in heaven the reward of one who writes, just as a pure prayer from the heart is offered by the reader for the love of God. Whoever reads this book, may you remember me. May the female scribe of this most delightful book and its readers be found in the Book of Life and be written among the just. Let all say Amen.”
(f.180v)

column11:
(Grashof is questioned in the index)

The first front cover (parchment) is taken from a breviary or similar devotional book (see XIV), and the inner back cover is pasted with a fragment of a lectionary (see XIII). 

2) f.113–213 (Pergamum and 14th century, inserted between the two parts of 1). Psalter.
column16: f.383r: Finito libro laus sit xpo. a.d. 1467 in die Agnetis feria 5. / Christi sit dilectrix Walburgis libri huius scriptrix. / Non bene finivi quia scribere nescivi. / Si quis abstulerit anathema sit. / Orate pro scriptrice unus pater noster.
column18: “The book is finished; praise be to Christ. In the year 1467 on the day of Agnes, Friday. / The beloved of Christ, Walburgis, is the scribe of this book. / I have not finished well because I do not know how to write. / If anyone takes it away, let them be anathema. / Pray for the scribe: one Our Father.”

Elisabeth Kempf (†1485)
Prioress of Unterlinden; credited on f.142r by Brother Johannes.

Unknown Unterlinden nun

Brother Johannes
Dominican friar; attributes the translation and writes prefaces.

column18:
"f.1: Mrs. Ebin Anders' booklet"
f.260r: “This little book … was written by two sisters, Kunigund and Anna, and completed on the Saturday after the eighth day of the Visitation of Mary, in the year of our Lord 1455. The first sister, Kunigund, passed away on the feast of St. Dorothea, virgin and martyr, as mentioned above. [God have mercy on her soul, amen. I, Kartäuser, revised and corrected it in Christian love during Advent 1455.]”

f.260r: “This little book … was written by two sisters, Kunigund and Anna, and completed on the Saturday after the eighth day of the Visitation of Mary, in the year of our Lord 1455. column11: From the receipt form on 4r it is evident that the tablets were written in the Convent of St Mary Magdalene (Süsternkloster) in Hildesheim (see below). Incised on the front cover: E.MI (Eileka von Minden?, mentioned 1316; cf. Urkundenbuch der Stadt Hildesheim, vol. 1, p. 371)
column19: Hildesheim, Convent of St Mary Magdalene.
column64:
1v Hymn to St Stephen (?). The few remains suggest a rhythmic structure. Recognisable words (selection): 1v (front cover!): … umbra. nebu(la) deficiens no(x) … constat hodie mundo (gen)erosa … 2v: … hoc festum / am(osum) … 3r: … Steph(anus) hanc vi sancte quondam … 3v: … sine fine, cum Christo Stepha(nus) … (lau?)des.

3v Hymn. A: Pueri concurrite, Jhesum mecum que(rite) … One stanza. The scribe skipped a tablet and wrote the ending in a blank space on 5r: … que regnant in anima, gaude.

4r Receipt form. A: Nos N. praepositus N. priorisa totumque collegium domus beate Ma(rie) Mag(dalene) extra muros hildesienses publice protestantur, nos recepisse ab N. dicto N. burgensi in Hildesia …

4v Medical recipes. A: Quando cerula est acida, que statim accessit, in isto tempore debemus de ructa in salvea bibere, quia ructa acuit visum …

5r E: … vitare debemus quasi venenum, ne aliquem virum propter corporis ei(?), ante detrimentum.

5v Order for bell-ringing. A: In vigilia pasche campana pulsetur …

6r Stylus trials.

6v Orders. A: Per totam communem septimanam nisi in sabato et nisi festum simplex fuerit, erit requiem summa missa … 8r E: … sepulcrum deponatur et altare sicut in festo duplici preparetur. Tablet 7v almost entirely lost text.

8v Orders. A: In annunciacione asperges … Below: A: In nomine domini compulse{ntur?} …

9r Orders. A: In purificacione clerus cantat Ave gracia … Below: A: Misse ante septuagesimam …

9v Traces of erased writing.

10r Orders. Beginning and end of the first order missing. Below: A: In vigilia nativitatis ora prima (?) missa rorate ? …

⸻

column8: Ms. Wolfenbüttel, Herzog August Bibliothek Cod. Guelf. 475 Helmst., scriptix group
column11:
Carolino-Gothica by four different hands.
        •        The main hand (Hand 1) is associated with the Scriptrix group (a network of identified female scribes at Lamspringe).
        •        Hands 2–4 show affinities with the Hamersleben group.
Hand 1 (main hand): 1r line 4 – 200v line 10.
Hand 2: 1v, line 4 – end of page.
Hand 3: 24v, lines 19–20 (on erasure).
Hand 4: 189r, lines 20–23.

Hand 1 (main hand) is, according to Cohen-Mushlin, identical in script to the Augustinus text in 903 Helmst., fols. 1r–75r, which Härtel assigns to the Scriptrix group (Cohen-Mushlin, 165; Härtel Geschrieben und gemalt, 85).
	•	Hand 2 has, according to Cohen-Mushlin, similarities to both hands of 204 Helmst., to 903 Helmst., fols. 75v–142v (Hand 2 – the hand of the Gregory text), and to 480 Helmst., fol. 1v (Cohen-Mushlin, 165).

        •        Cohen-Mushlin attributes several image captions and possibly much of the artwork to the scribe/artist Ermengard, active in other Lamspringe codices (e.g., 204 Helmst.). Two principal artist-hands:
        •        Hand A (Ermengard?): 102r, 148v, and most historiated initials.
        •        Hand B: 164r, showing slightly different proportions and palette.
        •        Stylistic links to other Lamspringe manuscripts and to Cologne workshop influences.
column64:
1.	1r – Ownership note and table of contents (added in 15th c.).
	2.	1v–102r – Recognitiones of Pseudo-Clement I, Pope, in Rufinus’ epitome.
	3.	102v–107r – Epistula Clementis ad Jacobum (Letter of Clement to James).
	4.	107v–111r – Passio Sancti Clementis (Martyrdom of St. Clement).
	5.	111r–112v – Passio SS. Processi et Martiniani.
	6.	112v–118v – Passio S. Apollinaris.
	7.	118v–121v – Passio SS. Nazarii et Celsi.
	8.	121v–124v – Passio SS. Nerei et Achillei and related texts.
	9.	124v–125v – Rescriptum Marcelli.
	10.	126r–126v – Passio SS. Petronillae et Feliculae and others.
	11.	127v–129r – Passio S. Domitillae.
	12.	129r–132v – Passio SS. Gallicani, Johannis et Pauli.
	13.	132v–137r – Passio SS. Cypriani, Justinae et Theoctisti.
	14.	137r–146v – Poenitentia of Cyprian.
	15.	146v–148v – Passio SS. Cypriani et Justinae.
	16.	149r–163r – Gregory of Tours, Liber de miraculis beati Andreae apostoli.
	17.	164r–175r – Acts of Thomas the Apostle.
	18.	175v–181r – Passio S. Pantaleonis.
	19.	181r–186v – Passio S. Kiliani.
	20.	186v–189r – Vita S. Burchardi.
	21.	189r–194r – Passio S. Julianae.
	22.	194r–200v – Passio S. Gangolfi.
	23.	200v–201v – Miracles of St. Thomas in India.

        •        The main hand (Hand 1) is associated with the Scriptrix group (a network of identified female scribes at Lamspringe).
        •        Hands 2–4 show affinities with the Hamersleben group.
Hand 1 (main hand): 1r line 4 – 200v line 10.
Hand 2: 1v, line 4 – end of page.
Hand 3: 24v, lines 19–20 (on erasure).
Hand 4: 189r, lines 20–23.

Hand 1 (main hand) is, according to Cohen-Mushlin, identical in script to the Augustinus text in 903 Helmst., fols. 1r–75r, which Härtel assigns to the Scriptrix group (Cohen-Mushlin, 165; Härtel Geschrieben und gemalt, 85).
        •        Hand 2 has, according to Cohen-Mushlin, similarities to both hands of 204 Helmst., to 903 Helmst., fols. 75v–142v (Hand 2 – the hand of the Gregory text), and to 480 Helmst., fol. 1v (Cohen-Mushlin, 165).

        •        Cohen-Mushlin attributes several image captions and possibly much of the artwork to the scribe/artist Ermengard, active in other Lamspringe codices (e.g., 204 Helmst.). Two principal artist-hands:
        •        Hand A (Ermengard?): 102r, 148v, and most historiated initials.
        •        Hand B: 164r, showing slightly different proportions and palette.
        •        Stylistic links to other Lamspringe manuscripts and to Cologne workshop influences.

column11: Carolino-gothica by numerous hands (probably eleven); exact differentiation impossible, since many contributions consist of only a few consecutive pages. At least one hand (1v), and probably more, belongs to the so-called “Hamersleben group” (cf. Cod. Guelf. 475 Helmst.; Härtel, p. 20 passim; Cohen-Mushlin, pp. 165–167, on this MS). column11:
During the period in which the Hs. was created, four bearers of this name have been handed down among the Marienberg choir women: the sexton Sophia Barnstorf and the conventual nuns Sophia von Braunschweig , Sophia von Werle and Sophia von Meinersen 
Around 1510, the Graduale was supplemented (Part II) and then re-bound after identifying the scribe's hand and the binding stamp in the Benedictine monastery of Clus in accordance with the requirements of the reformed liturgy of the Bursfeld Benedictine Congregation. 

In the catalogue of Colophons of the Bouveret, noted as wolfenbüttel 542.
column16:
The inside of the front cover and the endpaper contain fragments of a manuscript similar to the Graduale, the back dirt page belonged to a lectionario or breviario from the 14th century and the inside of the back cover is covered with a fragment of a liturgical parchment manuscript, also from the 14th century. At the foot of this fragment is written:
Qui scripsit, scribat et longo tempore vivat. Amen.
Que me scribebat, Sophia nomen habebat. Explicitly liber iste.
column18:
"The inside of the front cover and the endpaper contain fragments of a manuscript similar to the Graduale, the back dirt page belonged to a lectionario or breviario from the 14th century and the inside of the back cover is covered with a fragment of a liturgical parchment manuscript, also from the 14th century. At the foot of this fragment is written:
Who wrote, may continue writing and live long. Amen.
The one who wrote me, had the name Sophia. This book is finished."

column11:
The expulsion of the Steterburg convent (or part of it) to the Cistercian monastery of Wienhausen, mentioned by the writer, is not documented in any other historiographical or documentary sources.
The liturgical texts following the Windesheim custom and the Commemorationes of the house and order patrons James, Christopher and Augustine prove that the codex was intended for the writer's home convent, the Augustinian canonry of Steterburg, which had been reformed in 1452 according to the Windesheim customs. — On March 18, 1572, it was transferred with the other Steterburg codices to the court library in Wolfenbüttel,
column16: a.d. etc. etc. (14)56 completus est liber iste per me sororem inutilem Alheydem Kalves religiosam ac professam in monasterio Stederborch. pro quo sit Deus benedictus in secula. Pacienciam habete quia male scripsi in anno meo 73 cum magno labore in cenobio Wynhusen in expulsione monasterii nostri. Oretis deum pro me unam angelicam salutationem vel Requiem eternam in xpi amore.
column18: “In the year 1456, this book was completed by me, Sister Alheydem Kalves, an useless religious and professed in the monastery of Stederborch. For which may God be blessed forever. Have patience, for I have written poorly in my 73rd year with great labor in the convent of Wynhusen during the expulsion of our monastery. Pray to God for me, one angelic greeting or eternal rest in the love of Christ.”

column11:
Carolino-gothic script by the hand of the nun known as “Scriptrix” (on the scribe see 943 Helmst.; other manuscripts from the group: 443 Helmst., 447 Helmst., 482a [1r–81v], 510 Helmst., 511 Helmst., 718 Helmst. [10v–97r], 723 Helmst., 903 Helmst. [1r–75r], 943 Helmst., 1030 Helmst.).

This Gregory manuscript is assigned by Härtel to the Lamspringe nun who calls herself Scriptrix (for the scribe group see 943 Helmst.; Härtel, Geschrieben und gemalt, 21f.). It shows the type of decorated display and initial majuscules common in this group, also found in 510 Helmst., 943 Helmst., and 723 Helmst. (cf. Härtel, Geschrieben und gemalt, p. 23, figs. 1–3). The initial ornament is closely related to that in 510 Helmst., 511 Helmst., 1030 Helmst., and 943 Helmst., with 510 Helmst. and 1030 Helmst. representing a slightly later stage with more three-dimensional vine forks and with elements overlapping or entwining the initial shaft. Close parallels to 519 Helmst. are shown by the composite manuscript 511 Helmst., with its coloured backgrounds and narrow leaf shapes (for stylistic parallels see 511 Helmst.). As in 511 Helmst., direct Cologne influences can increasingly be traced, no longer filtered through Lippoldsberg (on Lippoldsberg see 943 Helmst.). The vine/bud type with integrated palmettes and the backwards-curving terminal bud (fol. 1v), as well as the dragon tailpiece with indented and notched outer edges, occur in Cologne manuscripts, particularly from St. Pantaleon (Cologne Cathedral Library, Hs. 162 and Hs. 163, both Cologne [?], 3rd quarter of the 12th c., Glaube und Wissen, cat. no. 72; and Cologne Cathedral Library, Hs. 31, St. Pantaleon, Glaube und Wissen, cat. no. 31).

column16: Dasz puch gehört in die sacristdey tzu Santtha Claren. Es ist geschriben worden do man zeit MV hundert vnd xvij jar. Es ist geschriben worden von einem armen swesterlein s. Claren orden Got zu lob vnd der hoch gelobten iunckfrawen Maria vnd sant Claren meiner lieben Mutter zu eren. Und wer es prachen (brauchen) wirt, der gedenck mein auch mit einem Ave Maria oder mit einem Requiem, swester Anna Newperin.
column18: “This book belongs to the sacristy of St. Clare. It was written in the year 1517. It was written by a poor little sister of the Order of St. Clare, to the praise of God and in honor of the most highly praised Virgin Mary and St. Clare, my dear mother. And whoever makes use of it, may they also remember me with an Ave Maria or a Requiem — Sister Anna Newperin.”

column4: Wolfenbüttel, Herzog August Bibliothek, Cod. Guelf. 654 Helmst.
column11:
Almost the entire codex was written successively by Berthold Raschen, as the colophons and the name entries 68r (in the Lombard) and 249v suggest; For the annotated texts he used a bastarda, and for prominent quotations also a simple textualis – in the older sections 1447–1449 with loops, in the more recent sections around 1461 (2r–64v, 67r–v, 70r–v, 73r–74v, 77r–v, 80r–v, 83r–v, 86r–v, 89r–v, 91r, 92v, 93v and 247v–248r) without loops in strikingly black ink – he wrote the commentaries throughout in younger Gothic cursive, mostly hastily and heavily abbreviated; only the textual additions 272v resemble in style the reading note by Margreta Boddekers.

The codex was written by Berthold Raschen successively between 1447 and 1449 and in 1461, together with and partly in parallel with Cod. Guelf. 693 Helmst. at the schola of St. Martini, the parish church in the old town of Braunschweig. Both codices came to the Augustinian nunnery in Heiningen at an unknown time. While this is confirmed by a note of ownership for Cod. Guelf. 693 Helmst. , the manuscript described here offers the following note on page 249v as evidence: Margreta Boddekers legit in isto libro . The reader can almost certainly be identified with the Heiningen sub-prioress who served from 1568 to 1586 and who took her vows in the monastery in 1513, cf.Taddey , 130, 144, 147, 250 no. 4 and 259 no. 140. For chronological reasons alone, she was certainly not, as Kintzinger suspected ( Kintzinger , 398, ms. mentioned), a pupil of Berthold Raschen at the city school.
column36: Ox head with eyes and nostrils, above a single-contoured rod, above a star: WZIS DE3285-PO-74957 (1459), DE2040-PO-76206 (1444), DE4620-PO-74892 (1448), WZMA AT4000-677_99 , AT4000-677_100 (both 1440–1450, five further types not verifiable). Ox head with eyes and nostrils, above a single-contoured rod, above a star, rod above a circle in the head: WZIS DE4215-PO-76967 , DE4620-PO-76969 (both 1446). Three-mountain, above a two-contoured pole, above a two-contoured cross: WZIS DE0960-Mlf246_102 (1443–1458), DE1335-PO-152304 (1462, one further type not verifiable). Ox, whole figure: WZIS DE0960-Mlf246_1 (1443–1458, two further types not verifiable). Crown without bow, central teeth single-contoured, leaf-shaped ends, open at the top, ring three-contoured: WZIS DE4620-PO-50377 (1445).
column46: 1r–92v and 245r–254v in one column, otherwise in two columns (each column approximately 5 cm wide, with two-column bracket format, the text column is usually 7–8 cm wide, the commentary column approximately 4 cm wide), the number of lines varies depending on the text type between 14 lines (text with interlinear gloss) and 60 lines (commentary).

column11:
Palimpsest, Hildesheim (?) / Corvey (?), 9th/10th century; further fragments of the text in Cod. Guelf. 943 Helmst. and Cod. Guelf. 482a Helmst.; for the text see Wolfenbüttel Helmst., Lesser (forthcoming).

Carolino-gothic script by a hand belonging to the “Scriptrix Group” (other manuscripts from the group: 443 Helmst., 447 Helmst., 482a [1r–81v], 510 Helmst., 511 Helmst., 519 Helmst., 718 Helmst. [10v–97r], 903 Helmst. [1r–75r], 943 Helmst., 1030 Helmst.).

Härtel assigns this Origen commentary to the Lamspringe nun who identifies herself as “Scriptrix”; the decorated initial majuscules with leaf and flower motifs support this identification (for the scribe group see 943 Helmst.; Härtel, Geschrieben und gemalt, pp. 21f.). The simple initial on 1v is by a different, probably later, hand.
As B. Lesser has demonstrated, the text was prepared with consultation of the Georgenberg manuscript of Origen’s homilies, Cod. Guelf. 100 Helmst., providing further evidence of collaboration between the two houses, also visible in book decoration (cf. Cod. Guelf. 510 Helmst.).

column11:
Palimpsest

Their own hands, or those from their immediate environment, can be found in a total of 10 other Lamspringer Codices: 443 Helmst. , 447 Helmst. , 482a Helmst. (1r-81v), 510 Helmst. , 511 Helmst. , 519 Helmst. , 718 Helmst. (10v-97r), 723 Helmst. , 903 Helmst. (1r-75r), 943 Helmst. and 1030 Helmst. (on the separation of hands and the group, see Härtel Written and Painted , 21f.). 

Carolino-Gothica by the hand of the Scriptrix (belonging to the group: 443 Helmst. , 447 Helmst. , 482a [1r-81v], 510 Helmst. , 511 Helmst. , 519 Helmst. , 718 Helmst. [10v-97r], 723 Helmst. , 903 Helmst. [1r-75r], 1030 Helmst .
Characteristic of the Scriptrix group are the extraordinarily numerous and varied initial majuscules in the present manuscript, mostly decorated with dots, which have feather-like palmettes, mythical creature heads, bud, leaf and flower motifs in the trimmings and are occasionally filled with simple wavy lines.

column11:
Carolino-gothic script by several hands. Hand on fols. 89r–192r is the same as in Cod. Guelf. 1012 Helmst., fols. 25r–169v, by a scriptrix of the Hamersleben Group (for palaeographical classification see Härtel, Geschrieben und gemalt, pp. 90f.).

This Breviary was produced by several Lamspringe nuns. Härtel identified two hands (division not always clear, see above), one of them identical with a hand in Cod. Guelf. 1012 Helmst. (from fol. 25r) and one attributable to the Hamersleben Group (see Cod. Guelf. 204 Helmst. for this group).

column11: A collection of manuscripts, written primarily on paper, which can be localized to Bamberg. The first part of the manuscript contains a German mirror of salvation. Erasmus Sternhals is identified as its writer in a colophon. The work was probably made for the Bamberg canon Georg von Löwenstein. This is indicated by the depiction of a kneeling canon and several coats of arms on f.56r. The German-language biography of the Holy Bishop Otto, which is bound in afterwards, also refers to Bamberg. It was written down by two Bamberg Poor Clares and completed in 1483. The third work in the collection is a life of Saint Catherine, dated 1488 and also written by a woman.

f.138rb: Cecilia Sparnecker
[This legend of Saint Ott was begun by Sister Cecilia Sparnecker, who was hindered in her work on it due to bodily illness and passed away. It was completed and written out by Sister Elisabeth Eychelberger in the year 1483 after the birth of Christ, during the time of the honorable mother and devout lady, Abbess Magdalena Kastner.]
